of that parish, bachelor, and Caroline Elizabeth Miller, of that parish, spinster; after the ceremony had taken place it was hinted to me that she was a widow, and I have inserted it above the line in the register; I did not know the parties - they have both made marks: she was described in the bann-book as a spinster - I did not proclaim the banns.

Cross-examined by MR. LAW. Q. Was not the marriage stopped in consequence of what was said? A. It was hinted to me that she was a widow, but I think it was after I had inserted her name as a spinster; and then I inserted widow in this irregular place; I did not notice a ring on her finger, and I do not recollect that I announced that there was an irregularity in the marriage - I have looked at the Marriage Act, but I thought the marriage was not void after the ceremony; I am quite confident I did not notice that she had a ring on her finger; the sexton and clerk are the only witnesses, which is a strong presumption in my mind that no women were present.

MICHAEL HOPWOOD
. I was parish-clerk of St. John, Wapping, in 1825; I signed this register - here is my name - I was present at the marriage, but did not know either of the parties.

COURT. Q. How were the banns published? A. As spinster; after the ceremony had been performed, there was some conversation brought forward, which acquainted the clergyman that she was a widow; this conversation was between William Jones and Caroline Elizabeth Miller - and after the explanation the clergyman entered the word "widow."

SARAH WILLIAMS
. I am wife of
Thomas Williams
, of York-street, Rotherhithe. I have known the prisoner ten year; when I first knew her she was living at her father and mother's house by the name of Caroline Elizabeth Bliss; I perfectly remember her being married, but I was not at her wedding - she was married to
Joseph Miller
, mate of the ship Ann, of London; they lived together about four years; her husband left that ship, and went away in 1824 in the ship Sally, Captain Sinclair, which was lost at sea, and it was supposed all hands perished; I have heard the prisoner and other persons say so - I think the prisoner got her information from the ship's husband; I do not think the owner lived in London; she went into mourning for Miller; I remember her being married again on the 9th of August, 1825; I went with her and William Jones to Wapping church to be married - the ceremony was performed as far as the putting on the ring - there was a ring on her finger, which was her former husband's - and when Mr. Bailey, the minister, came to put on the ring, he said,"Take that ring off your finger;" I said, "No Sir, she is a widow;" (she had said to me in going along, "I will take this ring off;" I said, "No, keep it on;") the minister then said he could not marry them, but did not say why; Mr. Bailey, the minister, then said to the clerk, "How is this, that she has been called spinster if she is a widow?" Mr. Bailey then left the church and went away, and we went away also; we got nearly to the end of the street, when we saw the clergyman returning on the opposite side of the way - he called us back, and he performed the ceremony from where he left off; the ring was put on her finger, and she came home to her mother's house; I stayed there till eleven o'clock at night, when I left them there together; I saw the prisoner the next day, but I have no recollection of seeing Jones that day - I saw him a day or two afterwards, I cannot say how often; I saw him afterwards, it might be three or four times; I saw them together at her mother's two or three days afterwards - they appeared to me as man and wife; William Jones is still alive - he was at the hearing at the office on the 2d of August; I did not sign the book because I am no scholar, and Mr. Bailey said he should take it on himself, and the sexton and clerk signed it - we had a certificate the same day; I am sure the business about the ring took place during the ceremony.

Cross-examined. Q. Is she not a very respectable person? A. Yes; I do not recollect that the clergyman suggested that the banns should be put up again; he suggested that the sexton and clerk should sign the register - I believe the man and woman could neither of them write, they both put their mark - I knew of Jones living apart from her soon after the ceremony, but I did not know of her going by the name of Miller; John Hogg was her last husband, and he is here, and I did not know him.

COURT to
MICHAEL HOPWOOD
. Q. Have you heard the account given by this witness? A. Yes; but it does not bring to my recollection their leaving the church; I know there has been such a circumstance as the clergyman quitting the altar, but I cannot say that that was the case in this wedding - I cannot recollect it, but I cannot say it did not happen; I have known a party to be sent away, and then brought back and the marriage completed.

COURT to THE REV. MR. BAILEY. Q. You have heard what the last witness has said? A. Yes; I have taken particular pains to recollect, and it does not occur to me that the parties left the church - I will not swear they did not; I recollect that I was convinced she did not describeherself a spinster intentionally; I do not recollect any woman being there at all.

BOYD SILVESTER
. I am an officer of the Thames Police. I apprehended the prisoner at her mother's house in St. Mary, Rotherhithe, on the 28th of July, I think it was; I told her she was charged with marrying two husbands; she said she had only one; I said nothing to induce her to confess; she said her first husband was Miller, but he was dead, she said that about four years ago he went on board the Sally, Captain Sinclair, and that all hands were lost; she said she could prove that she had got some money for her child; when she got to the office, I asked if she knew anything about Jones - she said she did, but no one could say she had married him, but one woman, and that woman I might find if I could; when she saw the witness before the Magistrate, she said she was married, but Jones went one way and she went the other - this was at the examination; I showed her the copy of the register at the office; I do not know whether what she said was taken down.
Cross-examined. Q. When did Hogg apply to you about this? A. I think on the 27th; I got a warrant at his desire on the Saturday night, and executed it on the Monday.

ELIZABETH BLISS
. I am the wife of the prisoner's brother - I was present at her marriage to
John Hogg
, on the 14th of October, 1826, at St. Ann, Limehouse.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know Jones? A. No, I have been married nine months; I did not know the prisoner in 1825 - I have seen Hogg write; I believe this to be his hand-writing, it is similar to his hand-writing which I have seen before - the prisoner had a little furniture; I know that her mother has been obliged to pay the rent of the house in which Hogg lived with her as his wife; she went by the name of Miller, and as a widow up to the time of her marriage with Hogg; she has one child by her first husband: I have known her altogether about three years, but have no recollection of her being said to be married to Jones in 1825 - I never knew a person of the name of Jones pretending to be her husband; I lived in the same house, but never saw a person of the name of Jones there, or claiming her as his wife.
Witnesses for the Defence.

ANN BLISS
. I am the prisoner's mother; she is twentytwo years of age - I remember Jones, and the circumstance of its being stated, that the ceremony of marriage had been performed; she came home that day and told me it was no marriage at all - Jones did not come home; she continued to live with me, in the name of Miller, in my house; she never went by the name of Jones, and was never from under my roof - Jones never lived with her as his wife; Hogg has made me pay the rent of the house he lived in since he took up the prisoner - he put a broker in and seized the goods which I had put in the place when they lived together; I paid six sovereigns for the rent.

COURT. Q. Where did Jones live before he married your daughter? A. In the neighbourhood; he did not come with her from church, but he came there in the afternoon; I do not know what became of him that night - I left him in the house when I went to bed, about eleven o'clock, and saw no more of him till next day - my daughter was in the room with him when I went to bed; I do not know where he slept - she slept in the house with me, but not in the same bed; Jones was only about my house two nights, but there is no one can prove that they saw her and him go to bed, or in bed - he afterwards went to his work, and has been at his work; he lived in the neighbourhood, but never troubled her nor me either.

ISABELLA YOUNG
. I live in Rotherhithe, and have known the prisoner from a child; I never knew her but in the name of Miller - after she married Miller till she married Hogg, she went by the name of Miller; I called her so myself, and she answered to it; she is a very respectable woman.

MARY ANN KENT
. I have known the prisoner many years by the name of Miller till she married Hogg.

- WARDLE. I have known her as a neighbour sixteen years; she bore a very respectable character, and went by the name of Miller till she married Hogg - I understood that she had been to church, but it was an illegal marriage, and she lived with her mother.
COURT to ANN BLISS. Q. Was anything said about the marriage when your daughter and Jones were together? A. Yes, he told me the same as she did; and said she had no more demand on him than I had.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
The prisoner entered into recognizances to appear for judgment when called upon.
Before Mr. Justice Guzelee.

1636.
PETER FENN
was indicted for that he, on the 18th of December , at St. George, Bloomsbury, having in his custody and possession, a certain bill of exchange, which is as follows: (i.e.)
Four months after date pay to me or my order the sum of 159l. 10s. 0d. for value received.

To Mr. James Lucett, Old Brompton. P. FENN. on the same day, at the same parish,
feloniously did falsely make, forge and counterfeit, on the said bill of exchange, an acceptance thereof, (which is as follows):-"Accepted, payable at Mr. Weaver's, 34, Parliament-street, Westminster. JAMES LUCETT." with intent to defraud
Sarah Cooke
; against the Statute.

SECOND COUNT, that he, on the same day, at the same parish, having in his custody and possession a certain bill of exchange, which is as follows, (setting it out as before,) upon which said bill of exchange was a false, forged, and counterfeited acceptance thereof, which is as follows -(acceptance set out as before;) on the same day, at the same parish, feloniously did utter and publish as true, the said false, forged, and counterfeited acceptance, with intent to defraud the said Sarah Cooke. he well knowing the same to be false, forged, and counterfeited; against the Statute, &c.
MESSRS. BRODRICK and BARRY conducted the prosecution.

JOHN COOKE
. I am shopman to my mother, who lives at Holborn-bars, her name is Sarah Cooke, her house is in the county of Middlesex. I have known the prisoner fourteen years, and was a pupil of his at Mr. Kirkman's, at Islington - he was a tutor there; when I left there I lost sight of him for about one year, but have known him intimately since for about four years; he has discounted bills with me, he discounted this bill with me on my mother's account, (looking at it;) I acted for my mother; Ithink it was about February or March last, I discounted it at five per cent, and at the same time he observed "My lad, I will be of service to you, and I hope I always shall be;" he then ordered 16l. worth of goods of us, which he said he wanted either to give away or to dispose of, and offered me in payment for those articles a bill of 36l., and said "Give me 20l. in money, and that will settle for the goods;" but when the bill was presented, it was not worth a farthing; my mother sometime afterwards sought after Mr. Fenn, and employed Mr. Vincent, of the Temple - I went with him to Paris, but we did not find the prisoner there - we found him at Calais; he said he was in the act of leaving for England - the packet was then leaving; Mr. Vincent was with me; I saw Mr. Hanbury there; I think I saw two boxes outside the house, but I was so hurried at the time I do not recollect; I do not know what became of Hanbury afterwards - I do not think he was with us two minutes; when I first saw Fenn he was ready to fall upon the earth; he spoke first to me, and said "Oh! God! I am dead man - if I had a hundred necks, I must lose them all;" he afterwards added "Let me go to Newgate quietly - don't put me into irons;" he then held up his hands, and said "Melton, Melton has ruined me! he has robbed me of upwards of 7,000l. in two years;" he might have said more, but I do not recollect it; we did not allow him to go on board, but we secured him; I had this £159 bill with me, and produced it to him; I said "Mr. Fenn, how is that you have been so inhuman as to use me so - I hope this acceptance is a good acceptance;" he looked at it, and observed "James Lucett I have known for years, you may rely on it as a very good acceptance - it is as good as a Bank note;" Mr. Vincent was by at the time, and he asked him the residence of the acceptor - he said "he lives at No. 1, South-parade, Queen's Elms, Old Brompton," which Mr. Vincent wrote on the back of the bill - (here it is;) nothing more was said about it, to my knowledge.

Cross-examined by MR. ALLEY. Q. Is not the Citybar twenty yards beyond your mother's house? A. No, it is opposite - the house is in the county; I have lived there fifteen years, and my mother has been carrying on business for thirty-five years; I have no interest in the business - I merely receive a salary; I am her representative in the business; I have known the prisoner a great length of time - I have not had many transactions with him; I have discounted many bills for him, which he took up, but they were forgeries; he never brought people to me to discount on my solicitation - this letter is my hand-writing; (read.)

"Dear Sir - After no little persuasion, I have got the bill, and send it inclosed; likewise the silk handkerchiefs; if you will have a 200l. at Mr. Melton's for it to night, you will oblige me, and if you will look me out a nice little bill for 50l. at two months, this will save me half a crown; if you will also get another 100l. of Melton, for the one I sent back, it will rub all off."

Witness. The fact was, I had some bills in my hands which Fenn gave me, and represented them as very good bills, but which I was dissatisfied with, and I wanted to have an acceptance of Melton for them; upon my oath, I did not discount these bills for myself, but for my mother - I had the use of her money, which he knew; they were never discounted on my own account; I had not the means when I discounted the bill in question I gave him the difference, deducting the discount; to the best of my knowledge I gave him the money for it at five per cent., but then he gave me another bill in payment for articles purchased - I sometimes gave him money, and sometimes a cheque; we had an account at a banker, in my name, by the advice of all parties; I solemnly state I have no share in the business - I never discounted at more than 5 per cent.
COURT. Q. When was it you found the prisoner at Calais? A. The latter end of March; we brought him to England, and he was taken to a lock-up house in Chancery-lane; he has been in custody ever since.

GEORGE VINCENT
. I am an attorney. I was employed by Mrs. Cook, and went to France with the last witness; we went to Paris for Peter Fenn, but did not find him there - we re-traced our steps to Calais, and found him in company with a man whose name I have learned is Hanbury, at Lawson's, the Crown hotel - we had been up six nights, and declined to go any further, or to let him go; Hanbury remained but a short time with us - they had got their trunks outside the house, and were going to the packet, which was to sail in about five minutes - they had had their breakfast; I told Mr. Lawson that Fenn's trunks must go in again, and we went up stairs, where the prisoner gave Hanbury a 5l. note: Hanbury left the hotel in about three minutes; when I first saw the prisoner, he appeared frantic - paralyzed, and I made a memorandum of what he said at the time; Mr. Cook was there the whole day, but I went to take a walk, as I had got Fenns passport, and I knew he could not leave; what the prisoner said was (reads) "Melton is my ruin - he has obtained 7,000l. of me in the last two years; I will go quietly to Newgate, only don't put me in irons - I will plead guilty, I shall then have about six weeks after I am condemned; I will be seen by no one - I will do as Fauntleroy did, and it will be over in a moment; I was coming to England to deliver myself up to justice;" I produced this bill to him, and asked him what it was - he said it was good, and I marked it "good" in pencil; I told him I doubted its being good, as it appeared to be all in one hand-writing; he said No, it was drawn upon his friend James Lucett, whom he said he had known for twenty years, (I think.) or a great many years, and it was as good as gold - I told him that Old Brompton was a very large place, and to give me the address of James Lucett - he gave it me, and I wrote it on the back of the bill, in his presence, No. 1, South-parade, Queen's Elms, Old Brompton - I came to England with him and Mr. Cook; I have since seen Mr. Lucett.

Cross-examined by MR. ALLEY. Q. Are you the person who was examined yesterday. A. Yes: when he came to London he had not an opportunity of escaping. I gave him leave to go to the Hummums, but my brother watched him there - I did not tell him my brother was watching him; he could have attempted to escape, but he did not to my knowledge.

WILLIAM WEAVER
. I am son of Thomas Weaver, No. 34, Parliament-street, Westminster - I know Mr. James Lucett; I have seen him write - the acceptance on this bill is not his writing; it is made payable at our resience.d

Cross-examined. Q. Mr. Lucett is a physician, is he not? A. Yes; this was his right direction, but he has left there about ten months - I am assistant to my father, who keeps a carpet warehouse, but his private residence is at No. 66, Millbank; I have seen Mr. Lucett write in Parliament-street, at my father's - I know his signature when I see it; I have not been close to him when he wrote - I know his writing, I have some of his writing here; I cannot say exactly when I saw him write - upon my oath he did not write for the purpose of enabling me to be a witness; I cannot tell when it was I saw him write, nor what it was - it was not so late as three months ago.
MR. BARRY. Q. Do you recollect upon what occasion you saw him write? A. On no particular occasion; this is not his writing.
COURT. Q. How are you enabled to speak to his hand-writing at all? A. By the J and the L-I have seen him write, but have not been close to him.
MR. ALLEY. Q. How does he spell his name? A. James Lucett.

JAMES LUCETT
. I am not acquainted with the prisoner - this acceptance is not my hand-writing; I did reside at the place stated at the back of the bill. but I do not reside there now, nor did I on the 14th of December, 1827.(Bill read, see Indictment.)

COURT to JOHN COOK. Q. Did your mother know of your discounting this bill? A. Yes; there was an account opened at the bankers' in my name, at the request of my mother, on account of her age, and at the request of our friends also - Fenn knew I acted for her.

The prisoner here read the same Defence as on his former trial,(see page 710) and with reference to the case in question, stated that he had himself frequently discounted bills for Mr. Lucett, which were payable in Parliament-street; he added the agent from whom I received them brought me a blank acceptance of Lucett's, wishing me to draw it rather than him - having known Lucett for several years, I yielded, and became the drawer, thinking it was Mr. Lucett's acceptance. Vincent has said to day he sent his brother to watch me closely while I was at the Hummums; he can only have said that from hearing my defence yesterday - I still repeat that I was at liberty; the coachman who drove me from where they left me, to the Hummums, asked me if he had not better drive me at once to my private dwelling, or to any other place in the neighbourhood, as I told him I did not like to sleep at such a place as the Hummums; when I once asked Cook why the business was conducted in his mother's name, why her name did not appear in the bills as well as his own, he replied, "The business is my mother's, and should any of these bills prove bad, or he unpaid, if I cannot take them up, I can soon get white-washed in the Bench, and the business be my mother's still."

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 55.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor (through Mr. Brodrick), on account of his good conduct for many years; and by the Jury, on account of the transaction in which the parties had been engaged .

1737.
WILLIAM COX
and
SAMUEL HILDER
were indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
Joseph Newcomb
, on the 5th of September , at St. Giles in the Fields, and stealing therein 17 rings, value 40l. , his property.

WILLIAM BAKER
. I am shopman to Joseph Newcomb - he is a watchmaker , and lives in Great Turnstile, in the parish of St. Giles in the Fields
. On the 5th of September, at nine o'clock in the morning, I saw the two prisoners standing by the lamp-post near my master's window - I observed them for about a quarter of an hour; they were walking about - I went up stairs to breakfast a little afterwards, leaving no one in the shop; I had seen the prisoners just as I went up stairs, which was about a quarter past nine o'clock - I locked the street door when I went up; about ten minutes after I had been up stairs I heard the cry of Stop thief! - I looked out at the window, and saw the prisoners pursued by the witness Scholey; I ran down stairs, and missed two diamond rings from the window - Scholey told me the direction they had taken- I followed them, and overtook them in Brunswick-square; Austin assisted me to take Cox - I then pursued Hilder; he had been stopped by a person, who immediately let him go, and he ran away - I told the person who had hold of Cox, to hold him fast, and I pursued Hilder; when I came up to him, he struck me two blows, but Prestage and I took him - I said he had broken our window and stolen some rings - he said, "Don't lay hold of my collar, take hold of my arm;" we then took them both to the watch-house in the square. Bird brought me five rings on a card, which I knew to be Mr. Newcomb's; and afterwards, when I got back, I received two cards of rings, which had been thrown into a shop - I knew them to be Mr. Newcomb's property; I had seen these rings safe in the morning before I went up to my breakfast; they were in the window - when I came down and missed them, the window was broken, but it was not broken when I went up stairs; I did not miss any more - the glass appeared to me to have been cut, and I found a piece of glass; some of the rings were near where the glass was cut, and some about a foot from it - the glass was not cut large enough for a hand to have been put in; I suppose the rings were got out with a wire - they were worth about 40l.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Are you partner with your uncle, Mr. Newcomb? A. No: I had never seen the prisoner till that morning; the lamp-post is about four yards from the window - I did not see the prisoners searched; there were not many people running - there were not more than six running at the time these men were taken, and not more than a dozen about- I kept hold of Hilder, and went to the watch-house.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. How many people were standing at the lamp-post? A. Three; but one I could not swear to - ours is a common bowwindow; there is an immense number of people passing there - the shop is not separate from the house; the dwelling-house is over the shop; my uncle does not live there constantly, but he does live there.

CHARLES SCHOLEY
. I live at No. 47, Bedford-row. I was passing Great Turnstile about half-past nine o'clock in the morning of the 3d of September - I know Mr. Newcomb's house, and I saw three young men looking in at his window; they were quite close to it - I was looking for Mr. Newcomb, and I saw one of the young men pointing, as if there was something particular to beseen; they then all started off - I went up to the window, and saw it was cut; I gave the alarm; two of them went towards Holborn, but I did not see the third at that time; it struck me he had gone towards Lincoln's Inn-fields; I pointed out to Baker the way the two had gone; that was all I perceived of them - they were in sight when I pointed out to Baker the way they went; I had never seen them before - the prisoners are just the size of the backs of the two men; I did not see their faces.

THOMAS AUSTIN
. I am a fireman. I saw three persons running in Brunswick-square on the 5th of September, and Baker was pursuing them - he was quite exhausted; he did not call to me, but I pursued them about twenty yards, and when they got to the back of the Foundling I stopped Cox: I did not see Hilder stopped - when I took Cox he said he knew nothing of that person (meaning Hilder); I asked him what made him run- he said he heard the alarm, and he was running too; he said, "Don't go to hold me, I will go any where with you - I saw a card thrown over the rails of the Foundling by one of those who were running - I rather think it was Cox; I asked him what made him run, and throw the card over the railings - he said he knew nothing about it; I saw Bird pick it up - there were five rings on it; I rather expect it was Cox threw it.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Did you stop him immediately after it was thrown? A. No - I followed him just round the corner; I lost sight of the card for that time, but it was not picked up till I returned.
Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. You were walking along the square and saw some persons running? A. Not more than three I believe; I ran, and Cox said he ran because he saw others run.

JOHN BIRD
. I live at No. 4, Artichoke-court, Cannon-street - I am a porter. I was coming across Brunswick-square on the 5th of September - I saw the two prisoners running, and Baker pursuing, and just before they got to the gate I saw Cox throw something over into the square; I think they were not more than two yards apart - I got over, and picked up this card, which I gave to Baker in going to the watch-house.
Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Were they running abreast? A. Yes - there were a good many people running after them, but none before them at the time they passed me.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Did you go in pursuit of them? A. No: I got over and took up the card - I did not lose sight of the card, till I gave it to Baker - there are trees and grass in the square, and a quickset hedge; the card was just on the other side of the hedge - I took up the first card I saw - there was no other that I saw.

HENRY GRAMMER
. I am a constable of the Foundling hospital estate. I searched the prisoners at the watch-house- I found on Cox 1l. 6s., and on Hilder 8s. 6d. and two thimbles; this is the card I received from Baker - it has been in my possession from the 5th of September.

WILLIAM BAKER
. This is the card I received from Bird - these rings which are on it are a part of what were taken from my uncle's.

CHARLES JONES
. I live at No. 2, Turnstile, at Mr. Oxley's. On the 5th of September I saw these cards in our shop, which is in the way from Mr. Newcomb's to Brunswick-square - they were about a yard within the shop; I gave them to Baker - there are ten rings on them.

JOHN LIMBRICK
. I have had the care of these two cards of rings ever since, and this piece of glass, which fits the window exactly.

MR. CHURCHILL to
WILLIAM BAKER
. Q. How is your window secured from being broken, is there no latticework outside? A. No - it might be broken by an elbow, if a person ran against it; I have lived there three years and never had a window broken accidentally.

JOHN PRESTAGE
. I was coming across Brunswick-square and saw Hilder in a fighting attitude, striking Baker; I went up and secured him - as we came to the watch-house he begged and prayed of me to let him go; as we came along, Bird was getting over the railings with the rings - Hilder turned round as he saw the rings put into Baker's hand, and said as the gentleman had got his property, I might as well let him go - we then went to the watch-house.
COX's Defence. I am entirely innocent; I was running at the time the mob was, and was taken.

HILDER'S Defence. I was coming from my own house in Princess-street, Whitechapel to Monmouth-street; coming across Brunswick-square, as I went into the square, the prosecutor came to me, and said "You have been to my shop and stole some rings:" I began to shove him, another man came up and took hold of me - I said "Let me go, I know nothing of the property stolen.

COX -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 20.

HILDER -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 25.

1738.
WILLIAM ROWLEY
was indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Frances Cushion
, widow , on the 22d of July , at St. Matthew, Bethnal-green, and stealing therein 3 gowns, value 10s.; 1 petticoat, value 1s.; 1 cloak, value 20s., and 8 half-crowns , her property.

FRANCES CUSHION. I am a widow, and live in Oakleyrow, Bethnal-green
: the house is let out in lodgings - Mr. Payne is the landlord, but he does not live there; I have the top room, and am a silk-winder . I went to the warehouse to carry home my work on Tuesday, the 22d of July - I went out between three and four o'clock; I locked my door, and had the key: I returned between six and seven in the afternoon - the prisoner lived in the kitchen of the house I live in; I went up stairs when I came home, went to unlock my door and almost fell in, because the door was open; I am sure I had locked it when I went out - it appeared to me to have been broken open; I saw my things scattered about - I went to my box and found it had been broken open, and every thing gone out of it; I missed my gowns and my cloak - I went down to the prisoner and said "Mr. Rowley! Mr. Rowley! what shall I do, the door is broken open and I am robbed?" he said "Don't be frightened, and make a piece of work, and perhaps I can tell you where your things are;" he said this in the passage: I then went into his room, and his little girl said "Father, Hannah has brought down a pretty red cloak;" I said "There were some gowns, do you know where they are?" the prisoner then desired her to give them to me, and she gave them to me from under the bed in the room: I said "Mr. Rowley,there was a trifle of money in a Christmas box;" he said"Don't make yourself uneasy about the money, I will make good every farthing that has been taken from you" - I had lost about eight half-crowns; I told him to be sure, that if he would give me the things, I would forgive him - that was after I had got the things, and when I was talking about the money - he did not offer to give me the money, but said he would make it good to me; I then went up to my own place.

GEORGE GROVE
. I am a licensed victualler, and live in Shoreditch. I have known the prisoner from five to six months, by his coming to my house - he is a labourer and a watchman at the Excise-office. Between nine and ten o'clock one evening, he came to me, and brought twelve half-crowns, and said "Mr. Grove, I wish you would take care of these for me;" "Very well (said I) do you know how many there are?" he said "Never mind, I will be back in ten minutes:" when he came back I said "Do you know how many there are?" "Not exactly" said he; said I there is 30s.: I cannot form any judgment when this was- I think I heard of this woman being robbed the next morning, but there was no inquiry about the half-crowns for several days; I had never received any money from him before - the prosecutrix lives about half a mile from me; I do not know what the prisoner's wages are - I have heard from him that he is paid every half quarter, but I do not know.

DANIEL RIERDON
. I am a Police-constable of Bow-street. I have two gowns, a petticoat, and a cloak, which I got from the prosecutrix; I believe on the 22d of July, at her house - I was sent down there, with Brown from Worship-street, in consequence of the robbery; I broke into a room, which was said to be the prisoner's, and there I saw two little children, seven or eight years old; one of them began to cry, and the other said something, but the prisoner was not present - I then went up to the prosecutrix's room, and got these clothes; I saw some marks on her door and on the door-post, but did not look at her box- this was between seven and eight o'clock in the evening.

THOMAS BROWN
. I am a Police-officer of Worship-street. I went to the house, with Rierdon, on the night of the 22d of July; we broke open the lower room door - there was nothing found there: Rierdon went up stairs, but I staid about the door, in case the prisoner should be concealed there - I went again the next day, and found this screw-driver in the prisoner's room, and this old trowel; the prosecutrix's son was with me at that time - I have tried this trowel and screw-driver with the impression on the door and door-post of the prosecutrix's room, and they correspond exactly; I found a small trunk in the room, and this trowel exactly corresponded with the impression on the front of it - the prisoner was taken on the night of the 22d, and delivered to me on the 23d; I believe he was taken about ten o'clock that night, but I was not present - I did not see these things in the room the first night, but the room was in a shocking state with filth and rubbish.

FRANCES CUSHION re-examined. These things are all mine; these are my gowns and cleak - I gave them to the officer; he asked me for them - he asked if these were the things that were taken; I said they were - I am sure they were in my room when I went out to carry my work home- they were in the box, and the box was locked; I saw them in the box when I went to put on my things to go to the warehouse - I went to the Police-office the next day; I could not just then tell how much money I lost, but I look upon it I had about 2l. very near, but in my fright I could not tell exactly what I had - I had at the rate of 2l., but I am no scholar and cannot reckon.

THOMAS BROWN
re-examined. Q. How did you get the information that night? A. Her son and daughter came and told us.

GEORGE GROVE
re-examined. Q. How soon after did you hear of the prisoner's being in custody? A. I have a letter which I received from him, (I believe about a week after I received the money,) saying that he had been taken up, and desired me to send him 10s. by his friend Broadhurst, which I did, and here are the other half-crowns - I believe he has two children.

Prisoner's Defence. I was at work at the Londondocks on the 22d of July - about half-past six o'clock I came home; I had not been in the house a minute when the prosecutrix came down, and said "I have been robbed" I said "God bless me, who could rob you:" "O dear," said she, "I am robbed" - "Let us go up stairs and see," said I; we went up, and I said "God bless me, you have been robbed," but I did not notice the door - we came down to the middle room, where there are two old women- I asked them if they saw any man go up stairs, they said No - I said "It is very odd you sit here, close to the door, and not hear anybody go up stairs:" my little girl looked out at my room door and said "Father, there has been three men up stairs," and I said to the old ladies, in the middle room, "There, don't you hear what Hannah says, that there has been three men here" - she said she did not hear it; I came down, and said to my girl "Go and fetch West, the officer, and I will have my room searched"- as soon as she was gone, my youngest daughter, who is six years old, said to me "Father, Hannah has brought down a red cloak, and it is under the bed;" I said "Get it out," she brought out the cloak and the gowns from under the bed, and gave them to Mrs. Cushion; and then she said she wanted some money; I asked what money - she said she had some money in a leather bag in a box, but that I never saw; I said "Don't make yourself uneasy, my pay-day is coming, and I will pay you every farthing she has taken from you."

COURT to FRANCES CUSHION. Q. Did you point out the prisoner's room to the officer? A. Yes - that was the room he lived in; the little girl did not bring in any cloak while I was there - she took it from under the bed.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 45.
Fifth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Law.

1739.
GEORGE WILLIAMSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of September , 9 ducks, value 15s. , the goods of
John Routh
.

WILLIAM ROWLES
. I live in Union-row, Hackney. On the 2d of September, about twenty minutes before two o'clock, I saw the prisoner and another man coming from Mr. Routh's - about forty yards from the house; I stopped them coming up an avenue; the other man had nine ducks- he ran, and dropped them; I took up the ducks, but he escaped - the prisoner stopped, put his hand into his bosom and drew out something; I had desired them to stop - the prisoner said "What is the matter," and thendrew this from his bosom; I followed the other man some distance, and the prisoner went towards Hackney - I lost the other man in a nursery-ground; he dropped the ducks in a field, and I took them up - that was about one hundred yards from where the prisoner and him had, been together: I took the ducks to Mr. Routh, and then went to the watch-house, where I saw the prisoner in custody, and am certain of his person - the moon shone full in his face; he was so near to me that I could have touched him- I can speak confidently to him from his features, and the manner in which his handkerchief was tied: when I went to the house, Mr. Routh came to the window.

Prisoner. If I were as near to him as he says I was, why did not he take me? Witness. I wanted the man with the ducks; I knew my brother watchman would take him from the sound of my rattle - what he drew out appeared to be a pistol.

HENRY HILL
. I live in Homerton-row, and am a watchman. On Tuesday morning, I was on my beat, near the Paragon; I heard the rattle, and went on towards Homerton-terrace - I met the prisoner there, about one hundred yards from Mr. Routh's; I asked if he heard a rattle - he did not answer at first, but then said No; I asked where his ears could be - he seemed much agitated and wanting breath; I took hold of him and took him to the watch-house - Rowles came in and pointed out the prisoner as soon as he saw him.

JOHN ROUTH. I live at Homerton-terrace
. I had nine ducks on the evening before this transaction; they were in a hen-house, near my house - there is a hole in my stable door; I saw the ducks produced by the watchman, and knew them to be mine.

SARAH COWLAND
. I am servant to Mr. Routh. I had seen the ducks safe in the hen-house between six and seven o'clock; I went again at ten and heard the noise of the ducks - between one and two the next morning I heard they were gone; I went to the hen-house, and the whole nine were gone - I saw them again, and knew they were the same as had been in the hen-house.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going to cross into the main road; the watchman came and said to me "What have you got" - I said Nothing; he turned from me and pursued another man, whom I never had seen - I was then going down the terrace, and the other watchman stopped me.
COURT to JOHN ROWLES. Q. Did the prisoner and the other man appear to be in company. A. Yes - they were as close as they could be.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Three Months .

1740.
JOHN COLWELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of July , 3 planes, value 10s., and a rule, value 2s., the goods of
Thomas Allen
; and 8 planes, value 40s., and 1 apron, value 6d. , the goods of
George White
.

GEORGE WHITE. I am a carpenter , and live in Gilligham-street, Vauxhall-road. I was in a building in Belgrave-place, Pimlico
, on Saturday, the 19th of July - I left tools there to the value of 5l.; I saw them safe at six o'clock that evening; I returned to work on Monday morning, between six and seven o'clock, and missed then all the tools stated in the indictment, and an apron; I detected the prisoner. at a quarter-past ten o'clock that morning at a pawnbroker's in the New-cut - the tools were produced to me, and I knew them; the prisoner had offered them in pledge; I delivered him to the constable.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. It was on Saturday night you left them? A. Yes, it was an empty house - it was locked up: the prisoner said he found them; when he was taken, he had some tools at his feet, and we put them all together, but did not mix them with any other - I had never seen him about the house.
COURT. Q. What tools were on the counter at the pawnbroker's? A. These five bead planes.

THOMAS ALLEN
. I am a carpenter. I left some tools in the same building; there were chisels, planes, and a veriety of other things, worth about 50s. - I saw them again at the pawnbroker's, in a cloth, close by the prisoner's feet.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you see the tools which the last witness lost? A. Yes, there were not more than one man could carry; I did not find all mine.

JOHN JAMES
. I am a patrol of Bow-street. I met the prisoner in the New-cut, with the two witnesses; I took him, and found this rule and this apron on him, which the witnesses calimed.

SAMUEL CANNON BARNET
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in the New-cut. I saw the prisoner on the Monday morning - he offered some beading planes to me; I did not see anything else; just all that time the witnesses came in; I believe the prisoner said they were his own property.

Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner was offering them to pawn? A. Yes, I had only asked what he wanted for them; there were a great many other people in the shop; it was between ten and eleven o'clock; we open at eight.
COURT. Q. How far is Charlotte-place, New-cut, where you live, from Belgrave-place? A. It must be two or three miles.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Is there not a name on those planes? A. Yes, no attempt has been made to erase the name.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was walking down near the canal - there were some bricks there; I stepped on them, and they gave way, when I found these tools, and intended to pawn some of them to get money to advertise them.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Confined Six Months .

1741.
JAMES CANN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 7s. , the goods of
Charles Stock
.

CHARLES STOCK. I am servant to Henry and
Edward Charter
, of Mary-le-bone-street
; the prisoner lived next door, at the Union public-house. On the Monday week previous to the 21st of July, I left some things in the top room of my master's house; on the Sunday following, I missed a handkerchief, and saw the prisoner the same day with it round his neck; I spoke to his mistress, and received the handkerchief from her; when it was on the prisoner's neck I spoke to him about it, he ran away and took it off, and put on another; I fetched an officer, and took him; he was very much agitated at first, but as we were going to the watch-house, he said he got in atthe window, and took it from the bed-post; he could get in from the parapet.

GEORGE ROBINSON
. I was applied to to take the prisoner; I made no promise or threat to him; he said he had taken nothing else but this - I cannot tell the precise words he used.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY. Aged 14.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Whipped and Discharged.

1742.
CATHERINE CALLAGHAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , 1 waistcoat, value 4s. , the goods of
Joseph Cohen
.

ELIZABETH COHEN
. I am the wife of Joseph Cohen - we live in Duke-street, Grosvenor-square
. The prisoner was in our service nine or ten days previous to the charge - I did not miss anything, but I saw a waistcoat concealed behind a useless water-butt in the back kitchen; on Thursday, the 7th of August, I desired the prisoner to go on an errand, but she did not go; I then sent for a constable - the waistcoat was then gone; when the constable came, he met her at the door, and told her to come in; we asked what she had done with the waistcoat; she said she had none, but we found it under her clothes.

WILLIAM CRAGG
. I apprehended the prisoner, and found the waistcoat tied round her middle.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY. Aged 22.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury .
Confined One Month .

1743.
BENJAMIN BULLOCK
and
ALEXANDER MAYSTON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of July , 1 silver pocket communion-service, value 50s. , the goods of
Mary Gilbert
. widow .

JAMES STAPLES
. I am shopman to Mary Gilbert - she did live in Cockspur-street, Charing-cross; she is a widow- she is a goldsmith and jeweller. On the 31st of July I watched the shop window; I saw the two prisoners there: Mayston put his hand through a pane of glass, (which had been previously broken), and took hold of this case of articles; Bullock was close by him, and when he drew them out Bullock took them of him, they immediately parted- I ran and took Mayston, and my fellow-shopman took Bullock, and when he had got hold of him I saw him throw two of these articles into the road; they were taken to St. Martin's watch-house - the articles are worth 50s.

GEORGE DOGGETT
. I am porter to Mary Gilbert. - Staples gave me some information; I ran out and took Bullock; I saw these things fall from him, either at the moment I took hold of him, or just before; it was between eight and nine o'clock in the morning.

JAMES MERRETT
. I was in Cockspur-street, and saw Doggett take hold of Bullock - I saw him throw down these articles, and I took them up.(Property produced and sworn to.)

BULLOCK -
GUILTY . Aged 24.

MAYSTON -
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Seven Years .

1744.
MARY BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of August , 1 umbrella, value 4s. , the goods of
John Williams
.

JOSEPH PRICE
. I am a patrol of Bow-street. I saw the prisoner, on the 23d of August, take this umbrella from the shutter of a house next door but one to Southampton-street
; I saw Mr. Williams at the same time handing his wife from one of the stages - he then turned, and was looking for the umbrella; I followed the prisoner, and took her with it; I took it back - Mr. Williams would not at the time swear to the umbrella; but said he lost it from the spot where I saw it taken.
COURT. Q. When she took it did she move on with it? A. Yes; it was between twelve and one o'clock.

JOHN WILLIAMS
. I lost the umbrella, but cannot speak positively to it.

SUSANNAH WILLIAMS
. I am the wife of John Williams. I saw the umbrella; I know it to be mine - I did not see it taken; I was going from the coach at the time.
Prisoner's Defence. I took the umbrella, but there was no person near it; I considered some person had left it there, and it was free for any one to take.
NOT GUILTY .

1745.
WILLIAM BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of July , 1 pair of boots, value 12s., and 1 pair of stockings, value 1s. , the goods of
Thomas Sarjeants
.
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

THOMAS SARJEANTS. I am superintendent of the Sailors' Asylum . I do not recollect that I had ever seen the prisoner, but my wife shewed me a pair of stockings and a pair of boots on the 8th of July, which were mine.

MARY SARJEANTS
. I am the wife of John Sarjeants. On the 8th of July I was in my back room on the first floor, and heard a strange footstep coming down the stairs; I went to the door, and saw the prisoner - I asked what he wanted; he said he had come there for relief: he said money was meant for such as him - he was distressed, and would have it; the office is in the house, but down stairs, and he was coming down from the attic; I told him Mr. Sarjeants was not at home, and he could not have it then; I saw something bulky under his frock - I came down after him to the street door, and said, "You have robbed this house!" he said, "I have not," and he ran about five yards, to the second house, when he took out the boots, and threw them down; I took them up - Mr. Smith ran and took hold of him, and brought him back; there were some other trifling articles found on him, which I had mended up to give to a poor woman.

COURT. Q. Had he been at your house before to ask for relief? A. I cannot say I recollect him; but I believe he was relieved, in December last; the office was then up two pairs of stairs; these are the boots he dropped - they have my husband's name on them.

THOMAS HABGOOD
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner, and produce the boots; he swore most desperately, and said he would have his revenge on Mrs. Sarjeants.

GEORGE SMITH
. I came to the assistance of Mrs. Sarjeants; I saw the prisoner drop the boots from under his smock-frock, and run off; I chased and caught him - I brought him back; his hat was taken off, and these stocking were found in it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I did not know what I did; I was intoxicated - they know I was.
MRS. SARJEANTS. I believe he was perfectly sober.
GUILTY . Aged 42.
Transported for Seven Years .

1746.
MARTHA CLARE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of August , 4 shirts, value 7s. , the goods of
William Gail
.

PHILIP GAIL
. I live at No. 5, Thrawl-street, Spitalfields
. On the Friday before the 28th of August; there were three shirts of my brother's and one of mine, hanging on a string in an empty room in that house; some were worth 2s. and some 2s. 6d.; I took the prisoner on the stairs with them under her arm, and she dropped them down; I called some people, and took them up: I took the prisoner to the office; my brother lived in the house with me.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Have your shirts any marks? A. No; I did not see them lying about the stairs, but I saw her drop them; I had never seen her before; some English people lodged in the house.
WILLIAM GAIL. I lost three shirts; I saw the prisoner with three of mine and one of my brother's - I took her to the office.
Cross-examined. Q. Were you at home? A. Yes; I never knew her before.

MOSES SIMMONS
. I am a constable. I was sent for to the watch-house, and found the prisoner there; these shirts were produced to me.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I went to see a friend, and these Germans ran after me as I came down the stairs, and seized me; they dragged me back into the room.
COURT to PHILIP GAIL. Q. How many live in the room? A. Two of my sisters, three girls, and six men; they are relations of mine.
GUILTY . Aged 36.
Transported for Seven Years .

1747.
SAMUEL DREW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of July , 1 looking-glass, value 24s. , the goods of
Jacob Enticott
.

MARY ENTICOTT
. I am the wife of Jacob Enticott; we live in Long-alley
, and keep a broker's shop . On the morning of the 24th of July, about half-past eight o'clock, I was in my parlour, and saw the prisoner at my window - he leaned ever, and took this glass out of the shop; I went to the door, saw him put it on his shoulder, and walk away- I went after him, took hold of his sleeve, and asked where he was going to take the glass; he said it was no business of mine - I told him it was; I took hold of the glass with one hand, and him with the other; he tried to break it, and struck me two or three times; I called a girl to take the glass from me; I called Mr. Gardener, who took him into custody - I never lost sight of him.
Prisoner's Defence. She is mistaken in the person; it was another man.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

1748.
WILLIAM EDWARDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of August , 1 penknife, value 2s.; 1 sovereign, 2 half-crowns, 1 shilling, and 1 sixpence , the property of
Samuel Bonner
.

MARY BONNER
. I am the wife of Samuel Bonner, who is a butcher ; I have been separated from him for some time: I partly get my living by needle-work, and I receive the visits of gentlemen. On the Saturday night previous to the 17th of August, I saw the prisoner on the Pavement, near Finsbury-square - he was a stranger; he asked me where I was going, and whether I would take a glass of anything to drink; I went with him, and had a glass of gin- he then went home with me, and there he gave me 1s. for drink; he asked me if he could stay all night; I said he might if he thought proper - he asked what he must give me; I said a sovereign - he said he could not afford so much, he would give me half a sovereign; he gave me a sovereign, and I gave him half a sovereign in exchange - I put the sovereign into my pocket; I slept with him that night - we got up about seven o'clock in the morning, and walked out; he breakfasted with me - I provided the breakfast; we dined together, and after dinner I went up stairs - he came up after me; I took off my pocket, with my sovereign in it, and put it under the pillow; my brother called on me, and I went down to him - he gave me two half-crowns and two shillings; I changed one of the shillings, went up stairs, and put the remaining silver into my pocket; I laid down, and went to sleep - when I awoke the prisoner was still there; I heard a voice below, and came down, leaving him up stairs washing his hands - he came down in about two minutes; he had agreed to stay with me, and to go out walking, but he came down, and went straight to the door; I asked where he was going - he said he should be back in a few minutes, by the time I was dressed; I ran up stairs, found my pillow turned over, and the money and pocket all gone; I had a penknife in my pocket, with a white handle and two blades, and a bit of gold on one side of the handle; I looked out of the window, and saw him just turning the corner - I called my brother, and told him I had been robbed; I saw the prisoner again on the Friday following - I caught hold of him, and told him he was the man who had robbed me, but if he would give me what he took from me, I would do nothing to him; he said he would see me d - d first - I had put the money by towards my rent, which I pay monthly.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did not he say he had taken no money, and he would return you none? A. He certainly said he had not robbed me, but he offered it afterwards; I told him I only wanted my money, and he refused to give me any - no persons had come into the house while we were up stairs; there was a man and his wife in the parlour - it is not an improper house; I only go out sometimes when work is short - he went out in the morning, and came back for his handkerchief, but not after he had robbed me; no property of mine was found - I cannot tell how many young men had been there in the course of that month; I will not swear there had not been ten that week - it certainly was nothing but shortness of work that induced me to go out. He did not say that he would go before any Magistrate; there was a gentleman I knew, whom I happened to stand talking to - I do not know whether he heard the conversation; I had left him - he might be a yard from me; I spoke to the prisoner directly - the gentleman was near the gutter, and we were up against a shop; I still kept talking to the prisoner, and the gentleman accompanied me down to the Mansion-house - I suppose he might hear me talking about it as we were going along; he is nothere - he knows my friends in the country, and is very respectable; my money was not in a purse - I paid for the breakfast and dinner.
COURT. Q. What time at night did you meet him? A. About eleven o'clock; we got up in the morning about seven - he went away about four.

ALICE CHASLEY
. I live at No. 7, Waterloo-street, St. Luke's; the prisoner has been my lodger for six weeks - I saw him on the Tuesday before he was taken into custody; he was cutting a piece of leather off his shoe with a small knife that had two blades, to the best of my knowledge, and as far as I could see, a white handle - it appeared to correspond with the description I have heard from the prosecutrix.

Cross-examined. Q. Could you swear to the knife? A. No, but when the officer came I told him what I had seen - I had seen a knife in his hand on another occasion which his wife was trying to get from him, and he said"That is a knife I received from a young woman, and you shall not have it."

JOHN GILL
. I am a painter and glazier, and live at No. 97, Whitecross-street; the prosecutrix is my sister - I went to her house in the City-road on Sunday, the 17th of August; I gave her two half-crowns and two shillings - between four and five o'clock, she came down stairs to speak to a young person who was there; the prisoner came down about five minutes after, and went to the door - my sister went up stairs and complained of being robbed; I went after him, but could not see him.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you the least notion how your sister was getting her living? A. No, I had not; she has held herself out as living by her industry - she is between twenty-four and twenty-five years of age; and is married, but lives apart from her husband.

WILLIAM WORCESTER
. I am an officer. The prosecutrix brought the prisoner and gave charge of him - I searched him. and found two sovereigns, two half-crowns, eleven shillings and sixpence, but no penknife.
NOT GUILTY .
THIRD DAY. SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 13.
Fourth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Justice Gazelee.

1749.
WILLIAM VYSE
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 15th of July , 30 pieces of paper of great value, (to wit) 30l. of lawful money, each of the said pieces of paper being stamped with a stamp, value 5d. the same being the stamp directed and required by the statute, in such case made and provided on every promissory-note, for the payment to the bearer on demand, of any sum of money not exceeding 1l. 1s. of the goods and chattels of
John Whitehead
and others, lately before stolen by a certain evil-disposed person unknown, he well knowing the same to have been stolen, and the said pieces of papers being so stamped as aforesaid, and each and every of the said stamps being at the time of committing the said felonies available and of full force and effect ; against the Statute, & c.; and that at the General Session of the delivery of the Gaol (of our late King George the 3d.) of the county of Kent, holden at Maidstone in the said county, on the 5th of August, in the 52d year of the said King, he by the name of William Wyse, was in due form of law convicted of felony.
SECOND COUNT, The same, only omitting the words used in italics, and saying, "being duly stamped as directed,&c."

THIRD COUNT, for feloniously receiving on the same day, 30 valuable securities, commonly called promissorynotes, each being for the payment to the bearer on demand of the sum of 1l. and the value of 1l. of the property of the said John Whitehead and others. lately before stolen by a certain evil-disposed person unknown, he well knowing the said valuable securities to have been stolen, &c., and the said valuable securities at the time of committing the said felonies being of great value (to wit) 30l.; against the Statute, &c.; and that he was previously convicted as above.

FOURTH COUNT, for feloniously receiving on the same day, 30 other valuable securities of great value, (to wit) 30l. of the property of the said John Whitehead and others, lately before stolen by a certain evil-disposed person unknown, he well knowing, &c.; against the Statute and setting out the previous conviction.
MESSRS. BRODRICK and RYLAND conducted the prosecution.

HENRY PARTEGER
. I am clerk to Sir Richard Carr Glyn & Co. On the 21st of November 1827, they were agents to Messrs. Whitehead & Co.; they had several banks - the Stratford-on-Avon, the Shipston-on-Stour, the Chipping Norton, and the Warwick; they were in the habit of issuing 10l., 5l., and 1l. - at all these banks their 10l. and 5l. notes were payable at Messrs. Glyns; the 1l. notes were not payable there, but they were paid if presented - my business was in the country office, and to keep an account daily of all the notes of Whitehead's paid by Sir Richard Carr Glyn - they were counted separately according to each Bank; the notes are first paid in what is called the town office - I fetch them from the cashier, and take them into my office; all the notes of all the Banks are there indiscriminately put together with a ticket upon them, specifying the amount of the whole - I sort the notes of the different Banks into tens and fives, and specify the amount on the back of them, if there were ten 10l. notes, and so on- having done this, I deliver them to Holloway to copy them into the note-book - that having been done, they come into my possession again; when banking hours are over, I add up all the amounts together of one day's payment, as in this case; (producing a book) here is the amount of the 10l. notes, the 5l. notes, and the 1l. notes - they are all added up together, and then I enter them in the bill-book; the entry in the bill-book is then compared with the notebook by Holloway. On the 26th of October 1827, there were paid thirty-seven 10l. notes, thirty-nine 5l., and ten 1l. making a total of 575l.; the numbers on the back of these notes are my making - here is on the back of this"370l." that means the 10l. notes - here is 195l. that means the 5l. notes; and here is 10l., that means the 1l. notes - on the 1st of November, here is entered thirty-six 10l., thirtythree 5l. and nine 1l. notes - total 534l.; this is the prosecutors' note, (looking at it) and the figures on the back of it are mine; the figures are 360l., 165l. and 9l. - total, 534l.; on the 19th of November, there were fifty 10l. notes, twentythree 5l. notes, and nine 1l. notes - total 624l.; this is one of the prosecutors' notes, and the figures on it are mine - on the 20th of November, here is 700l., 450l. and 2l., making atotal of 1,152l. this is Wellington's writing - I have looked through all the books of Sir Richard Car Glyn, in which an account of the prosecutors' notes are entered, and there are no entries corresponding with the sums I have mentioned, except these four dates - the gross amount may correspond, but not the particulars; I believe these notes must have been passed at Messrs. Glyn's on the days I have mentioned - when I have done with them, I give them to Holloway.

Cross-examined by MR. LAW. Q. These memoranda are made by you on the backs of several of them? A. No, only on the outside note, and then I hand them to Holloway - if I receive any more notes in the day I make a fresh mark, but I do not make the total till the close of the day; the other numbers may become incorrect in the course of the day, but the total will be right; Holloway gives them to Daniels to lock up, and they would remain several days till Daniels sends them out again; the cashiers pay the notes, but none of them are here to day - I do not know whether there is any one here who can state whether either of these notes came back since the 20th of November - the principal clerk keeps one key of the place where these notes are put; there is no date put on these notes by me, only in the book.

HENRY WELLINGTON
. I am a clerk at Messrs. Glyn's. On the 20th of November there is an entry of Whitehead's notes in the book - these figures on the back of this note are mine.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. If this had not been the outside note there would have been no figures on it? A. No; we know it has not been in our hands since the 20th of November, because we have not paid any of these notes since then; before that time we should have paid 1l. notes; I did not see this note again till I was before the Grand Jury.
MR. RYLAND. Q. As a clerk of Messrs. Glyn's, do you know if any 1l. notes have been paid at your house since? A. No.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you know of any placards being issued? A. Yes; I do not know whether the numbers of any 1l. notes were given - it is so long since I saw the placards, that I do not remember whether there was any notice taken of the 1l. notes at all; I dare say there were many thousands of their 1l. notes in circulation - this is one of the first placards - (Looking at it).

CHARLES HENRY HOLLOWAY
. I am clerk to Messrs. Glyn's. I received the notes from Parteger, and made an entry of them in the note-book which I have here; on the 26th of October, 1827, here are thirty-seven 10l., thirty-nine 5l., and ten 1l. - total 575l.: on the 1st of November, thirtysix 10l., thirty-three 5l., and nine 1l. - total 534l.: on the 19th of November, fifty 10l., twenty-three 5l., and nine 1l. - total 624l.: on the 20th of November, seventy 10l., ninety 5l., and two 1l. - total 1152l.: when I receive the notes in the evening I copy them, make them up in a parcel, put a label on them, and deliver them to Daniels - that is done every night regularly; Mr. Daniels locks them up in an iron-safe till they are wanted to be sent down to the country Bank: on the 21st of November I received some parcels of notes from Mr. Daniels - I looked over the labels, and checked them with this book; the notes, from October 12th to November 20th, inclusive, were all in those parcels, and each of the parcels contained the notes paid on each of the days mentioned - those of the 26th of October, 1st of November, 19th and 20th of November, were all in this parcel: I also delivered some sovereigns.

Cross-examined by MR. LAW. Q. Then the whole of your payment for that Warwick Bank in that period was very considerable? Yes; 1900l. or more - there must have been hundreds and thousands of their notes in circulation in the country; these notes were to be returned to Mr. Greenway for the purpose of re-circulation; many notes, on the backs of which we have made marks, have got into circulation again; the public would be used to see notes with our marks on the back of them.
Mr. BRODRICK. Q. Have you, since the 20th of November, paid any notes of that Bank printed in black ink? A. No.

JOHN DENNIS DANIELS
. I am a clerk at Messrs. Glyns. It was my habit to receive Messrs. Whitehead's notes every evening, from the 12th of October to the 20th of November, inclusive, from Mr. Holloway - I deposited them in the iron-safe; on the 21st of November I delivered back to Mr. Holloway all the parcels of notes I received of him within those dates: as far as I know, no 1l. notes printed in black have been paid since then.

Cross-examined by Mr. LAW. Q. Were you aware of the placards being issued? A. I do not know whether I recollect that - but we were not to pay any of the 1l. notes printed in black after that; we paid the 5l. and 10l. notes which were not mentioned in the placards.

COURT. Q. Had all the notes numbers on them? Yes - but we only took the numbers of the 5l. and 10l. notes, and the placards only had the numbers of the 5l. and 10l. notes - the 1l. notes not being payable at our house, we did not take the numbers of them.

MR.
KELYNGE GREENWAY
. I am one of the partners of the house of John Whitehead and Co. - there is another partner beside Mr. Whitehead. On the 21st of November last I was in London, staying at Furnival's Inn Coffee-house- I received on that day a blue bag from the clerk at Messrs. Glyn's. which I took to Furnival's Inn Coffee-house - I had taken my place to go by the Warwick mail that night; I took out of the blue bag a parcel of sovereigns, and put them into another bag - the porter took my portmanteau to the mail, and in the evening the mail called for me; a little before eight o'clock; I went up stairs at Furnival's Inn Coffee-house, and took the two bags out of a drawer - I directed the porter to take them and put them into the seat of the coach; he took them and went to the coach door - I followed him close; when I got into the street there was only myself and the porter that I observed; I was going to open the coach door myself, but a person from within opened it, and I directed the porter to get in and put the bags into the seat - he appeared to me to lift the bags on the coach floor, and at that moment a person from the back part of the coach ran against me; when I recovered the shock, I observed the porter putting the heavy bag, containing the sovereigns, into the coach seat - and I observed to him that he had not put the blue bag into the seat; he appeared to search for it, and declared it was missing - there was a woman in the coach; I looked for the bag but it was gone; the next morning a person was introduced to me as the person who had run against me, it was not the prisoner; when I went from the house I saw no one butthe porter, but as soon as the bag was lost I proclaimed it immediately, and there was a great concourse of people; I went immediately to Messrs. Glyns, and also to the Mansion-house - placards were printed, and advertisements were put into the newspapers - I used all means in my power to make it known; here is one of the placards which were published, containing the numbers of the 5l. and 10l. notes, but here is no statement of the 1l. notes at all; we continued to issue 1l. notes of the Warwick Bank where I reside, but I cannot tell what the other Banks did; we did not issue any more of these others; these are of the Stratford-on-Avon, Shipston-on-Stour, and Chipping-Barnet; the houses at Stratford-on-Avon and Chipping-Stour is still open for the payment of notes only.

Cross-examined by MR. LAW. Q. At which house are you resident? A. At Warwick; the notes of the Stratford-on-Avon, Shipston-on-Stour, and Chipping-Barnet, were issued at those houses, not at Warwick; there were 12,000l. in notes in circulation, and our notes had a great circulation in the country; they have all been paid and destroyed except 572l.; there was nothing in the notes stolen to denote to a stranger that they formed part of the parcel that was lost; the placards contained no description of the 1l. notes: we lost one hundred and eight 1l. notes of those houses, and one of the Warwick; there is at this time five hundred 1l. notes properly in circulation; we got back about 19,000l. in 5l. and 10l. notes, but none of the 1l.; I do not suppose the prisoner is the man who ran against me - he was committed for stealing, but that was the act of the Magistrate; I gave the same account I have now.

MR. BRODRICK. Q. What other means did you make use of to apprize the public of your loss? A. We continued to circulate placards, and repeated cautions to the public, against taking the notes, in different papers, in February, April, and June last.

CHARLES DOBSON
. I am book-keeper at Messrs. Waterhouse's booking-office, Islington. I know the prisoner - I am in the habit of occasionally changing country notes, which are not payable in London, for the gratuity of 1s. in the pound; I had seen the prisoner three or four times, but did not know his name till I saw him at Bow-street: he came to me on Saturday, the 5th of July, and brought five 1l. notes of the Stratfordon-Avon and Shipston-on-Stour Bank, and wished to know if I would change them - I said I could say nothing to it till I had inquired about them, but if he would call on the Tuesday I would tell him; he came on the Tuesday, and I gave him 4l. 15s. for them; these are two of the notes which I cashed for him on the 7th of July, to the best of my belief (looking at them). I gave the whole of the five 1l. notes which I received from the prisoner to George Mallison, a porter, to take to Lad-lane, and in about a fortnight I received these two back again - the prisoner came again on the evening prior to his examination at Bow-street; he brought ten 1l. notes of the same Banks; he wished them to be cashed, and I told him if he called on the Thursday I should be able to give him an answer - he said, if they passed all right, he should be able to put several others in my way: on the day following I sent these ten 1l. notes by Coles to Messrs. Glyn's, which I found, by a book I had, was a house that did business for them; in consequence of the answer I got from Messrs. Glyns, I spoke to Gardner the police-officer then, and on the 15th of July I gave him the ten notes which I received from the prisoner - I am confident this (looking at it) is one of the ten notes I received from the prisoner and sent by Coles, by the name of "Wall, the 19th of November," on the back of it; I had received notes from the prisoner prior to this, which I sent to Lad-lane, where they were paid in, and I received the money of the guard on his return from Birmingham.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. What was the date of the first transaction? A. I should think a week before those which I sent to Lad-lane on the 5th of July; must have been the latter end of June or the beginning of July - I did not know the prisoner lived in Islington, but I learned it at Bow-street; I have since heard he carries on a straw business there, it is nearly a quarter of a mile from the Angel office: I suppose not more than twenty coaches start from there to go to the country - more go from the Peacock; we only book for Water-house's coaches - it is usual for persons to bring country notes to book-keepers at coach-offices, and pay 1s. in the pound to change them; I sent the first portion of notes to the country Bank of my own head, not by the direction of the prisoner - I did not pay the cash till I had received the cash for them; eight of the Stratfordon-Avon Bank have been paid, which I received from the prisoner; he lives in the same street in which the Angel stands, and on the same side of the way - I do not know that I have seen his straw hat shop; the notes were in Coles' possession from between eleven and twelve o'clock in the forenoon, till between two and three o'clock in the afternoon; I had not made any mark on them before I delivered them to him, but I had noticed the dates and indorsements - I did not make any mark on them when they were brought back to me, I merely looked them over. and gave them to Gardner; there are no marks of mine on them - I made no marks on the notes I gave to Mallison; they were out of my possession nearly a fortnight before these two were returned from Lad-lane - I gave these to Gardner.

MR. BRODRICK. Q. Had you noticed the notes? A. I observed the dates of them, and what an uncommon length of time they had been out; I had noticed the indorsement before I gave them to Cole - to the best of my recollection, the notes I received back from Cole were the same which I gave him; I am certain I gave the same notes to Gardner which I received from Cole and from Mallison.
COURT. Q. Did you pay the 4l. 15s. before these two notes were returned? A. Yes, in consequence of the book-keeper having sent the money for them.
COURT to MR. GREENWAY. Q. Are not the 1l. notes reissuable? A. Yes; there are notes of the same date out now; and some which have been twenty-three years out.

GEORGE MALLISON
. I received five country notes from Mr. Dobson to take to Lad-lane; I delivered the same notes to Mr. Felgate on Monday, the 7th of July.

THOMAS FELGATE
. I am book-keeper at Lad-lane. I received some Shipston-on-Stour and Stratford-on-AvonBank notes from Mr. Dobson by Mallison; these are my marks on them, "Mr. Dobson, July the 7th" - these are two of them; I gave them to one of the guards, and these two were brought back.
Cross-examined by CLARKSON. Q. When did you mark them? A. The moment I received them from the porter.

JOSEPH ADAMS
. I am book-keeper at the Bolt and Tun Inn, Fleet-street. The prisoner came to my office the latter end of June, (I think,) and I changed some Caermarthen notes for him; he came to me in June, I believe it was, and asked me to exchange some Stratford-on-Avon notes for him - I said I would for 1s. in the pound; after I had exchanged them I asked his address, and he told me "Mr. Williams," and I think Back-lane, Islington - I believe I gave the notes to Mr. Gray, my employer; the notes I gave him were those I received from the prisoner - they were notes of this appearance; I cannot swear that these are them.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. I think you say you changed other country notes for the prisoner? A. Yes; I gave them to Mr. Gray; I believe some of them were of this Bank, but I do not pretend to swear to the notes produced - I have no recollection of the prisoner saying his name was William Vyse; I can undertake to say, that he did not say his name was William Vyse; I wrote the name on one of the Caermarthen notes, but that note is not here - I speak from memory; I have no recollection of the name of Vyse - I will not swear he did not use that name; I am certain he said "Williams" and"Islington" - to the best of my recollection it was"Williams, Back-lane, Islington."

STEPHEN CARPENTER
. I am a porter at the Bolt and Tun Inn; I saw the prisoner there; he gave his name and address to me - I am confident he said "Williams," and "Islington," and I believe "Back-lane;" this was three months ago.
Cross-examined by MR. LAW, Q. Will you swear he did not use the name of Vyse? A. Yes; this was in the middle of the day - I wrote the address on a note; I believe a Llandoveny note.

ROBERT GRAY. I am proprietor of the Bolt-in-Tun. I received from Mr. Adams, my book-keeper, six Stratford-on-Avon notes, about June last - I cannot speak to the day, as I did not put it down; I kept them by me, as they were not payable in London - I put them into my iron chest, and after the examination at Bow-street I referred to a great many notes, and found these, which I delivered to Gardner; these are the notes; I marked them - I have no doubt these are the notes I received from Adams, because I am not in the habit of receiving notes from any one else.
Cross-examined by MR. LAW. Q. Have you any other reason for saying you received these from Adams, than because you did receive notes from Adams? A. No.

MR. BRODRICK. Q. Did you receive any Stratford-on-Avon or Shipston-on-Stour Bank notes from any other person except from Adams? A. I received three notes from another person, which I gave to a person of the name of Garnet, but they were neither of these six.

COURT. Q. Did you receive three notes from another person, which you delivered to Garnet? A. Yes, I marked them at the time I received them; I have no recollection of receiving any other notes, except from Adams.

RICHARD GARDNER. I am an officer. I received ten notes from Mr. Dobson, which I marked the next day: these are them I am sure; these are two notes which I also received from Mr. Dobson; I took the prisoner, and searched him; I found no notes, but a pocket-book and some money on him.

The certificate of the prisoner's former conviction was put in and read; it certified that, on Wednesday, the 25th of August, in the fifty-second year of his late Majesty's reign, at Maidstone. William Vyse, labourer, was convicted of being at large before the expiration of the term of seven years, for which, at Hertford, in the forty-first year of his late Majesty's reign, he had been sentenced to be transported; and received sentence of death, but his present Majesty, then Prince Regent, was pleased to pardon him, on consideration of his being transported for life.
(Signed) JOHN CLARK,
10th Sept. 1828. Deputy Clerk of the Assizes.

ROBERT SMITH
. I am commander of the Prudentia hulk, stationed at Woolwich.
