I know the prisoner; in 1812, I was first mate of one of the hulks at Sheerness; I prosecuted him at Maidstone, in that year, for returning from transportation; I had seen him on board of one of the bulks in 1802 - I am sure he is the same man; I had him in my charge after 1812, and I have seen him since on board the hulk I now have the charge of at Woolwich - he came to see another person; he said "How do you do?" and I have seen him since at Newgate.
MR. BRODRICK. Q. Are you the person who prosecuted him at Maidstone on behalf of the Crown? A. Yes.

WILLIAM BACON
. I was formerly an officer of Bow-street, I first knew the prisoner in 1801, at Hertford, where I gave evidence against him and two others; he was convicted, and sentenced for seven years' transportation; I gave evidence against him at Maidstone for returning before his time - I have no doubt he is the same man.

Cross-examined by MR. LAW. Q. Then the felony was committed twenty-seven years ago? A. Yes, he was tried the second time for no other felony, but for returning before the time; I did not know that he had the King's pardon.

WILLIAM LIMBRICK
. I am an officer. I know the prisoner; I saw him tried at Maidstone in 1812; he is the same man.

Prisoner's Defence. I declare myself totally innocent of this charge; I mean to say, that before your lordship and before God I have been imposed upon - I am not guilty of the offence; and the porter of the Angel has stated wrong; I told him if I had more local paper I would give him the preference.

COURT to
CHARLES DOBSON
. Q. When was the prisoner taken? A. On the Friday after the Tuesday he had given me the notes, he came on Thursday, and I told him to come on the Friday; he came, and was taken.
GUILTY. Aged 46.

Judgement Respited
.
Before Mr. Justice Gazelee.

1750.
JAMES COLLINS
was indicted for
stealing,on the 20th of June , 1 gelding, price 5l. , the property of
Benjamin Carter
.
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

BENJAMIN CARTER. I keep the George inn, at Silso, in Bedfordshire
. On the 19th of June. I had a bay gelding pony; at nine o'clock that evening I gave it to the boy to take to the paddock near my house; I did not see it in the paddock; I saw the boy take it, and he brought the halter back; there is a gate and a lock to the paddock; I made some inquiry for the pony, and a little boy said he could not find it; in consequence of some communication, I came to Hampstead on the following Monday, and found my pony in possession of John Hinton, who keeps ponies and gigs; I have got it since - it is not worth more than 5l. in the market.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Is the boy here? A. No, I could have had him here; the paddock may be about one hundred yards from my house.
COURT. Q. What age is your poney? A. Upwards of twenty years, but he was a great favorite with my children.

JOHN CULLEY
. I am ostler at the Holland Arms, Kensington. On Friday, the 20th of June, I saw the prisoner there a little after eleven o'clock in the morning; I was out exercising a horse, and met him going up towards my stable - he had a little bay gelding, which he put into the stable, and in a little while after a man named Wilkinson came by with some potatoes; the prisoner brought the poney out, shewed it to Wilkinson, and rode it up and down Back-lane, and then put him in again; soon afterwards, the prisoner went after Wilkinson; when I went out, about twelve o'clock, I saw him and Wilkinson together; I heard Wilkinson say "I have bought this poney of Collins for 4l. 10s.;" the prisoner made no answer; they all went away together about two o'clock.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did he go away with the poney open in the public road? A. Yes, there was no concealment of any kind.
NOT GUILTY .

1751.
JAMES COLLINS
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of June , at St. Mary Abbott's, Kensington, 1 gelding, price 20l , the property of
George George
.

GEORGE GEORGE. I live at Eden-bridge. Kent
; I lost a horse on the night of the 28th of June - I had seen it in the close that day as late as nine o'clock in the evening- I missed it the following morning between six and seven; it had been in my yard, adjoining my house; I found it again on the 15th of August, at Kensington, in possession of William Bennett, the constable - I know it to be mine - it was worth upwards of 20l.; I have got it again - I had bred him; my farm is about thirty miles from Kensington.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Have you any other Christian name? A. No - it was about six weeks before I saw it again; I keep a farm-yard, and have many servants; I retired to my house on the 28th of June - I left my servants about - I did not go out myself; I do not know who was last in the yard that night - two men and a boy were in my house; I cannot tell what time they went to bed that night - whether any of them might have left the gate open I cannot tell - my servants are in health, but are not here.

COURT. Q. What is the fastening to your farm-yard? A. A common hasp to the gate - it was fastened when I was in the yard, but I cannot say of my own knowledge whether it was open or shut when I went to bed - I was up an hour or more after I saw it, but did not go out again.

WILLIAM BENNETT
. I am a constable of Kensington. I had occasion to go to the Holland Arms public-house, on Sunday, the 29th of June, about eleven o'clock in the morning; I found the prisoner there, and took him into custody- I told him it was on suspicion of stealing a horse from Bedfordshire, and I asked if he did not sell a horse ten days back to Mr. Wilkinson; he said Yes; I then asked where he got that horse. which was then in the stable; he made no answer; I took him and the horse - the ostler told me, in the presence of the prisoner, that he had come there with this horse that morning - it was the ostler who had fetched me- I took him into the public-house, and searched him; I kept the horse in my possession till the 15th of August, when I found who it belonged to; when Mr. George appeared at the office, the horse was given up to him by the Magistrate's order.

Cross-examined. Q. When had you this conversation with the hostler? A. On the 29th of June; the hostler said, "This is the horse he sent here by a little chimneysweep boy, and he gave him a penny for it;" I knew the prisoner before, and he knew me perfectly well as a neighbour - I suppose he knew me to be an officer; I leave no doubt of it - he worked for Mr. Cobbet, in his garden.

JOHN CULLEY
. I am ostler at the Holland Arms, Kensington; I know the prisoner. On Sunday, the 29th of June, he sent this horse to our house by a little boy; I did not think it was to come to our stable - I thought the little boy had made a mistake. and I hitched the horse on the outside; in about a quarter of an hour the prisoner came into the stable - I went up with him, and unlocked the stable door, and he brought the horse into the stable - this was before he said anything to me about the horse; the boy was then gone - I asked him if it was his horse; he said Yes; the horse was then put into the stable, and I went to the public-house and fetched a pint of half-andhalf, I called Richard Toy. our watchman, out, and told him to go for the officer - the officer came, and took the prisoner: I do not know where the prisoner lives - he had been at our house before; the last time I had seen him before the 29th was on the 20th.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you been acquainted with the prisoner before? A. Yes - I had known him better than two years.
COURT. Q. What is he? A. When I first knew him he was at home with his father, and sold fruit in Covent-garden; I do not know where he has lived for the last two years.

Prisoner's Defence. When I was going up towards their house on the 20th; Culley was drinking with some men, and he asked me if I would toss with him for some beer - I said No, I did not want any such thing; I was not inclined to toss for it - he then ordered me to take the horse up into the stable: then he asked if I would give 2l. for it, and then Wilkinson came up.
COURT. You are now tried about George's horse.
Prisoner. Oh, there was a person came along the road and offered it me, and I purchased it of him.
Two witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 25.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor on account of the respectability of his family, and his good character .
Before Mr. Justice Gazelee.

1752.
JOSEPH KINGSTON
and
CHARLES STYRING
were indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Elizabeth Talitha Tooth
, on the 8th of August , at St. Leonard, Shoreditch, and stealing therefrom 1 writing desk, value 1l. 8s.; 3 books, value 2s.; 1 slate, value 4d., and one drawing-box, value 5s. , her property.

ELIZABETH TALITHA TOOTH. I live in Hoxton-square, in the parish of St. Leonard, Shoreditch
. On Friday morning, the 8th of August, between six and seven o'clock, I was alarmed by a violent ringing at the street door, and my servant came into my room, saying that thieves had been discovered escaping from the house - I got up and ran down stairs; when I got down to the hall, I saw a desk, belonging to a little girl a pupil) it was shut - I think it was in the hands of an officer; I missed a drawing-box which belonged to another pupil, which I had seen on the Thursday morning, on the sideboard, in the back parlour - the desk and drawing-box were both under my care; the desk had been in the back parlour, and was the first in a row with many others - it was shut down as it appears now; I subsequently saw that it was very dirty - it had been taken out of the house, and the drawing-box has never been recovered.

JEREMIAH O'CALLAGHAN
. I live at No. 13, Hoxton Old-town, about sixty paces from Miss Tooth's house - I belong to the Ordinance. On Friday morning, the 8th of August, between six and seven o'clock, I saw the two prisoners and another near Miss Tooth's house; they were in a suspicious manner consulting together, and in a short time I saw Kingston entering Miss Tooth's garden-gate - the other two were watching, one looking up one street, and another up another, and when a person came up one of the streets they gave an alarm to Kingston, who came out again - I saw Kingston enter into the gate repeatedly in that manner, and at length, when it was getting near seven o'clock, the three had some consultation together, and then they all entered the gate - I then had no doubt that they were had characters, and I went to a neighbour or two to assist me to apprehend them, but I could get no person; I took a stick with me and went to take them myself - I went down High-street and into Old-street-road, but before that I saw them all three coming out of the gate, and the prisoner Styring had the desk - I ran down the street towards the square, and met them coming out of the square; Styring was behind the other two, and he was carrying the desk - I said to him "Where are you going with that;" he made no reply, but turned round and threw it at my person - I turned my hand and left it in the road, and pursued him; I cried Stop thief! and several other persons ran in pursuit with me - I did not loose sight of them till they got to Shoreditch, and before they had been out of my sight a minute, I saw Kingston in custody; a gentleman took up the desk and carried it to his own house- I went to Miss Tooth's house, and so did the gentleman who had the desk; when they went in at the garden-gate it appeared to be on a latch, and Kingston lifted up the latch - I did not see them go into the house, but when I got into the house I saw the window up, and the mark of a man's shoes inside and outside of the parlour window; I had never seen either of the prisoners before to my knowledge - I saw Styring in custody near the Police-office; he was taken to a different watch-house.
Prisoner STYRING. Q. If he saw the mud on the window, why did he not state it at the office? A. It escaped my memory - I should not have thought of it now if his Lordship had not asked the question.

WILLIAM TETHERTON
. I am a Bow-street patrol. On Friday, the 8th of August, about half-past six o'clock in the morning, I was at the Toll-gate, near Hackney-road - I heard a cry of Stop thief! several times, I saw a mob of people coming, and Kingston about fifty yards before them- I took him into custody, and took him back to Miss Tooth's, No. 24, Hoxton-square; I searched him and found a silver thimble, a necklace, a bodkin and case, and a silver knife - I then took him to Shoreditch watch-house; the servant said they had entered through the window.

RICHARD TREVETT
. I am a Bow-street patrol. On the 8th of August, I was with Tetherton, near Shoreditch church, I heard a cry of Stop thief! and saw the prisoner Styring run past; I took him into custody, and on the way to the watch-house, he threw this skeleton-key from his pocket down on the ground.
Prisoner STYRING. Q. Did you see me throw it down? A. Yes - from your left-hand trousers pocket.

ELIZABETH LANGLEY
. I was servant to Miss Tooth. On Friday morning, the 8th of August, I got up at half-past five o'clock - she has five persons in the house, and twentysix or twenty-seven pupils; I went into the front parlour and opened the shutters - the windows were closed when I left them and went into the kitchen, which lics backwards, and is down one stair from the parlour; I heard a noise, but did not know what it was - I then heard the front door bell ring; in consequence of that, I went to the parlour - a young woman informed me there had been thieves in the house: I missed one of the desks, and saw the windows thrown wide open - I am not certain whether they had been fastened, or merely shut down; as I had not fastened the shutters at night, I am sure they were shut down that morning - I did not observe the seat of the window at that time, but did afterwards; the blinds were closed when I left them, but they were then thrown back - the desk was brought in by some one, and it was in the hall when I came down: it belonged to a young lady named Strong.

JOHN PEARSON
. I am a chair-stuffer, and live in Old-street-road. On the morning of the 8th of August, while I was in my shop, I heard a cry of Stop thief! and heard something falling in the road, nearly opposite my door - I went out and saw it was a portable desk lying in the road; I picked it up and took it to my own dwelling for safety - it was open; I afterwards gave it to Mr. O'Callaghan, after the prisoners were in custody - there were other persons running, but I only saw Mr. O'Callaghan.

SARAH ANNA ROGERS
. I am a pupil of Miss Tooth's - this necklace, knife, bodkin-case, and thimble are all mine; they were all in my work-box, in the back parlour, in my care.
COURT to JEREMIAH O'CALLAGHAN. Q. Is that the desk you took to Miss Tooth's? A. The desk I took from Pearson I took to Miss Tooth's, and put it down in the hall.

MISS TOOTH. This is the desk I saw in the hall; it contains two cyphering-books, a writing book, and a slate- it had been in the front parlour; and the drawing-box, on the sideboard, in the back parlour; the desk was under my care - it belonged to Miss Eliza Strong; she is under ten years of age - I consider all under my care; the little girl, herself, had the key of it.

KINGSTON'S Defence. I was taken against Shoreditch church by this officer; he asked what I had got, and I told him I had picked up the articles in Hoxton-square, and while I was being taken back, a young man came and gave him something else: he let the other man go and kept me.

STYRING'S Defence. I was standing by Shoreditch church; the officer came and took me into custody - I asked him what for, and he would not tell me till we got to the watch-house; he searched me and found nothing - O'Callaghan said there was a young man there who was one of the prisoners, and then he saw me sitting in the corner, and he said "Oh, I beg your pardon, you are the one I want."
One witness gave Styring a good character.

KINGSTON - GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 22.

STYRING - GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 21.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutrix on account of their youth .
Before Mr. Justice Gazelee.

1753.
SAMUEL JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of February , 2 coats, value 3l. 5s.; 1 pair of breeches, value 4l.; 3 shirts, value 10s.; 1 shift, value 2s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 4s., and 2 shoes, value 2s, the goods of
Isaac Steed
, in his dwelling-house .

ISAAC STEED. I live in White Horse-street, Stepney
. In February last the prisoner and
James Wickham
came to lodge there; they came on a Tuesday, and continued till the Sunday morning - they lived in a back room up stairs, and I live in a back room down stairs; the staircase comes into my room. On Sunday morning, the 10th of February, about half-past six o'clock, the prisoner and his companion went through my room, and one of them wished me good morning, which of them I do not know; about eight o'clock that morning I discovered that my box was broken open, and a black frock-coat, a brown frock-coat, a pair of patent small-clothes, a very large cord, two silk handkerchiefs (one an India one, with white spots,) three shirts, and one shift were gone, and a pair of shoes, which had stood in the room; an old pair were left in their place; the box stood in the room where they slept - there were other lodgers in the house, but none of them had left the house till after I discovered the robbery; neither the prisoner nor Wickham ever came back; I did not see the prisoner again till the 20th of July, when I saw him at the Wellington public-house, in Brooke-street, Ratcliff; I have not seen my things since - I had seen them safe on Saturday afternoon, the 9th of February; I know they were all in the box - I value them at 5l., but they were worth more than that to me; I valued the two coats at 3l. 5s. - I do not know how long I had had them, but they were little the worse for wear; they cost me 8l. - I value the small-clothes at 1l.; they cost me 1l. 10s. - I had not had them long, and worn them very little; I valued one of the handkerchiefs at 4s. - it cost me 6s.; the three shirts were worth 6s., and the shift 2s. 6d. - it was a new one; the shoes were worth 2s. 6d. The prisoner is an engineer.

JAMES YOUNG
. I am headborough of Ratcliff. I took the prisoner into custody, and told him it would be better to tell the truth.
Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing at all about it.
GUILTY. Aged 26.
Of stealing to the value of 99s. only .
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Justice Gazelee.

1754.
MICHAEL COHEN
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
William Maryatt
, on the King's highway, on the 24th of August , putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 watch, value 2l. , his goods.

WILLIAM MARYATT. I am a lighterman , and live at Rotherhithe. I was going along Ratcliff-highway
on Sunday evening, the 24th of August, about ten o'clock; I had been to Waltham abbey, and was returning home: seven or eight persons met me - one of them gave me a shove, and one of them drew my watch; I endeavoured to run after them, but several of them got before me, and stopped me; I sung out "Stop thief! he has got my watch;" in five or ten minutes the prisoner was caught, in Old Gravel-lane, but I did not see him caught - I saw him at the watch-house; there were seven or eight women and men round me - one of them pushed me towards the road, and one stood near the curb and took my watch directly; they did not take hold of me - my watch came quietly out of my pocket; it was dark: I had not opportunity of seeing the man who did it - I had not been drinking.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. You had not been drinking? A. No, I was quite sober - there were several persons at the watch-house; I believe Rainer was in custody; Rainer is the man who said he saw the prisoner throw the watch away.

THOMAS RAINER
. I live at Mr. Burford's, in Ratcliffhighway, and look after horses and chaises. I was returning from the stable after doing up my horses, a little after ten o'clock, and going down Old Gravel-lane, to our back door, I heard a cry of Stop thief! I looked round, and saw the prisoner the first person running; I stopped him, and heard a person say, "I have lost my watch;" I then saw a watch in the prisoner's hand - I caught at it, and got the chain in my hand, but he held the watch in his hand, and began to kick in a manner I could not bear, so that I was not able to hold him; he got the chain from me, there being no seals to it, I could not hold it - he ran off, and threw away the watch: I took it up, and was going to pursue him, but two young women stopped me as the watchmen came up, and accused me of the robbery; I stated how I came by the watch, and he took me to the watch-house; I got there before the prisoner, and when he was brought in I recognized him as the person who threw the watch away; he was then taken and locked up; it was a darkish night, but I knew the prisoner well - I have seen him pass my master's house scores of times.

Cross-examined. Q. What is Mr. Burford? A. A paper-stainer - he has three horses and two chaises, and a chaise-cart, and another gentleman has a horse and chaise in the same stable; I quitted Mr. Burford on Monday - I was a regular servant of his for nine months, and had 16s. a week. Mr. Burford, Jun. and myself had a few words, and I left them - they did not accuse me of anything; I never was here but once before, that was about a man getting into the stable; I never said to any one that I had a job here which I got three guineas by, and I should like to have such another; I got my expences at that time, which were above a guinea; I have seen the prisoner buying and selling fruit, and serving master with fruit - there were other persons running, but he was the first; there were others running after him - I stopped him; I did not take hold of the chain till I had hold of him; a person(who is a bricklayer) saw him throw the watch away, and saw me pick it up, but he is not here - neither of the young women saw me pick it up; I cannot tell how they came to accuse me of the robbery - perhaps they might be confederates; I knew the prisoner's name was Cohen; neither of the young women are here - if I could have found them I should have given them into custody; I did not state that the prisoner's name was Cohen.
COURT. Q. When you had hold of the watch-chain did you know the prisoner? A. Not at that time, but when I saw him at the watch-house, I knew his name was Cohen.

Cross-examined. Q. Then, when you had hold of the chain you had doubts about who he was? A. I knew his face very well indeed; I was then taken to the watch-house, and in consequence of my stating it was Cohen I was discharged, and he was kept; my master and two respectable gentlemen came to the watch-house, and stated where I had been.

COURT. Q. You say the watchman came up to you and took you? A. Yes; I pointed out the person in the mob to him - he took me to the watch-house, and in going along I saw Cohen in the custody of another watchman and a bricklayer; when I saw him I said that was the man; the watchman is not here, and I do not know his name.

JAMES JACK
. I am headborough of St. George's parish. I was at the watch-house - the witness was brought in, in about three minutes before the prisoner, and had the watch in his possession; the prisoner was then brought in, and the prosecutor came and said he had lost his watch - the witness then said he stopped the prisoner with the watch in his possession - he gave the same account he has to-day: the prisoner was given in charge for stealing the watch; there was no charge against the witness - there was a gentleman came forward to say he knew him; I do not know who it was.

Cross-examined. Q. Then when Rainer first came in he said nothing about how he came by it? A. There were no questions asked him till the prisoner was brought in - the person who brought in Cohen brought in a piece of watch-glass, which was picked up near to where he stood.
COURT. Q. Who was that? A. I forget his name; he said he would attend if we wanted him - he is not here, nor the watchman who took Rainer.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I am innocent.
GUILTY. Aged 21.

Of
stealing from the person only . -
Transported for Life .
Fifth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Law.

1755.
GEORGE HARRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August , 1 live tame fowl, price 2s. , the property of
James Wild
.

JOHN PARTINGTON
. I am servant to Mr. Rawson. On the 15th of August, about twenty minutes to ten o'clock, I was in Black Lion-lane, and saw the prisoner and another boy coming down from the front of Mr. Wild's premises, in a private road; I went up to them, and said, "Halloo! what have you got there, a fowl - will you sell it?" he said, Yes - I said, "Have you been buying it?" he said Yes, he gave 1s. for it; I said,

"Are you sure of it?" he said,"Yes - I bought it of a man in the Green-lane, with a donkey and panniers;" I took it in my hand - it had its wing broken, and was very dirty underneath; I said, "I will take you to a man who I think will own it;" I took him to Mr. Wild, and he claimed it; the prisoner did not say anything - he was about forty yards from the prosecutor's when I first saw him; this was before ten o'clock - he was then taken into custody.
Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Then he told you he had bought it? A. Yes, and he offered to take me to the man, but I did not go, because I knew it to be Mr. Wild's.

JAMES WILD. I live at Craven-place, Bayswater
. On the 15th of August the prisoner was brought to my house, with the fowl (which I knew to be mine); I had seen it, to the best of my recollection. the day before - I had seen the prisoner the day before, go past my house with two other lads, and told them it was no thoroughfare, and they turned back: the prisoner said he had taken the fowl, together with the other lad, but he had not thrown at the fowl.
Cross-examined. Q. Was Partington then present? A. He was present part of the time.

Prisoner's Defence. I went out into the fields to go bird's-nesting, and saw the fowl in Mr. Johnson's field; we tried to catch it, and then I took it; we came by the gentleman's house, looking to see if we could see any one to own it, and the gentleman took me.
GUILTY. Aged 14.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury .
Whipped and Discharged.

1756.
WILLIAM HIGGINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of July , 3 snuff-boxes, value 8s.; and 1 cigar-tube, value 2s. , the goods of
Francis Ashdown
.

MARY ASHDOWN
. I live in Well-street, Oxford-street
, and am the wife of Francis Ashdown. I saw the prisoner on the 4th of July, at the post opposite my door, about twenty minutes past nine o'clock in the evening; I did not see him do anything, but a neighbour pointed him out to me - I went up to him, and took hold of his coller, and said "You know the boys who have been taking the snuff-boxes;" I had been to my window and missed three boxes, and one cigar-tube - the prisoner said "They have run down Union-street;" he said he knew the name of one of them was Michael - he pulled away from me, and then Mr. Dunn took hold of him, and I turned away- I made my complaint at High-street, and have seen some of my boxes since.
Prisoner. Q. Was there any mark on the boxes? A. Yes; I had marked them myself - I can swear to them.

WILLIAM PRICE
. I am a watchman of Mary-le-bone. I got a box from the watch-house-keeper - the proseuctor claimed it; the prisoner was present, but I do not think he saw the watch-house-keeper produce it - at half-past two o'clock in the morning I found another box in Union-street; there was nothing found on the prisoner in my presence - the watch-house-keeper is not here.

JAMFS DUNN
. I am a shoe-maker, and live opposite the prosecutrix. I saw the prisoner standing by her shop with two snuff-boxes in his hand; I saw Mrs. Ashdown sake hold of him - he got from her, and I stopped him in Union-street, between Nos. 37 and 38; he threw down two snuff-boxes, and I took up one - Mrs. Ashdown saw it, and owned it; I gave it to the watch-house-keeper.
Prisoner. Q. You said at the office, you did not know whether I dropped it or not? A. No; I said I saw him throw down two boxes, and I took one up.
COURT to MRS. ASHDOWN. Q. Is the box now produced, one of those you lost? A. Yes; it is the one that was found by the watchman the next morning - this is not the one Mr. Dunn took up.

Prisoner's Defence. They said they found two boxes, but they have brought but one; I came out of the country on the 4th of July, to get a situation - I met my consin, and stood talking with him; the prosecutrix came up and laid hold of me, and said she was informed I had been stealing some boxes - I said I had not, but I had seen some boys near her window, and they had run down Union-street.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Three Months .

1757.
MARY KNIGHT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August , 1 petticoat, value 1s. 6d.; 1 gown. value 1s. 6d.; 1 handkerchief, value 3s.; 1 brush, value 1s., and 1 book, value 1s. , the goods of
John Garrett
.

JOHN GARRETT. I live in Carburton-street
, and am a carver and gilder . The prisoner had been my nurse ; my wife was ill - she had been with me about four weeks, and had attended Mrs. Garrett in her confinement before; I had some suspicion of her - and on the evening of the 15th of August, about 8 o'clock, she went out; I sent a man to bring her back - she came back, and had a bundle; I said I suspected she had been robbing me - she said No; Mrs. Garrett had given her part of the things, and the other part she had lent her; I found in the bundle two wine-bottles, a gown, a prayer-book, a silk handkerchief, a petticoat, a muslin collar, and other things - we then searched her pockets, and found a bag of flour, some potatoes, some salts and wafers; she said she had taken them, or words to that effect, and begged to be forgiven.

SAMUEL EVANS
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner, and searched her; I found the articles the prosecutor has stated, and a great many more - the prisoner said Mrs. Garret had given her some, and lent her others; I found a furniture-brush under her arm, and some other things - the prosecutor claimed them all; she said she hoped she should be forgiven.
The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that her misthress had given her the salts to conceal them from her master.

JOHN GARRETT
. I believe she was not paid the last three weeks wages, but I do not know; my wife is now deceased.
GUILTY. Aged 60.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury .
Confined One Month .

1758.
GEORGE WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of July , 1 hat, value 5s. , the property of
Isaac Hill
.

JOHN COLE
. I am errand-boy to Mr. Hill, a hatter , of the Strand
. At half-past seven o'clock, on the morning of the 8th of July, I was sweeping the door, a stranger came and spoke to me, and while I was talking with him I saw the prisoner coming out of my master's shop with a hat; I stopped him, and he asked me whether it was a 16s. or an 18s. hat, but before that he said, "Let me go! let me go!" I called my master, and a constable was sent for.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do you mean to say this man had ever left the shop? A. No - he was coming out of it; he was coming towards me, and I took hold of him - my master was three or four minutes coming down; I took the hat in my hand - I had shut the door, and locked it; he did not attempt to get away - he could if he had liked.
COURT. Q. How near the door was he when you stopped him? A. Near the step - I was by the curb-stone.
ISAAC HILL. I keep this shop - I was called down and sent for an officer.
Cross-examined. Q. Was there any concealment of the hat? A. No; he did not say he came to ask the price of it - there was no one else in the shop.

JOHN GALL
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner; I found nothing on him, and no money.

COURT to JOHN COLE. Q. What questions were put to you by the other man? A. He asked me the way to Southampton-street - the name of that street is written up; he was on the curb-stone - the prisoner was coming out of the shop, about one yard from us.
Cross-examined. Q. How near was the prisoner to you when you put your hand on him? A. I went to the step- he could certainly have overcome me.

Prisoner's Defence. I entered the shop with no other intention than that of becoming a purchaser of a hat; I had 4s. 6d. which was taken from me by Hill or by the constable - I meant to have left that, and paid for the hat on Saturday night.
NOT GUILTY .

1759.
WILLIAM WOODROUGH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of July , 4 brushes, value 5s. , the goods of
William Cowdry
.

JOSEPH PHILLIPS
. I am servant to William Cowdry, of George-court, Strand - he is a brush-maker . At half-past ten o'clock in the morning, of the 17th of July, the prisoner came into the shop with a basket in his hand, and asked what I would make a plate-rack for, of certain dimensions; I said I could not tell until it was made - I went and asked my master, and he could not tell; while the prisoner and I were talking a gentleman came into the shop, and said, in the hearing of the prisoner, "Have you lost anything?" I said, "I don't know;" he said,"Look into his basket" - the basket was then opened, andthe prisoner took out this package, threw it down in the shop, and ran away - I pursned, and brought him back; it contains four brushes of my masters, worth 5s.
GUILTY . Aged 56.
Confined Six Months .

1760.
RICHARD DUTTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of August , three iron locks, value 7s., and 22 squares of glass, value 30s., the goods of
Thomas Dunstan
, and fixed to a certain building of his .

JOHN WALKER
. I am agent to Mr. Thomas Dunstan - he has a house in Pleasant-row, Mile-and Old-town, Stepney
; I was at that house on Tuesday, the 26th of August - it had been lately repaired, and was unoccupied; I afterwards received information, and went there - I found the sashes broken, the glass gone, and the locks gone off three doors; I did not find any of the articles - they had been previously taken care of; the glass was worth 1s. 6d. a square.

GEORGE MASSEY
. I am a watchman of Mile-end Oldtown. I was on duty in Pleasant-row on the 28th of August; at four o'clock in the morning I went up to the prosecutor's house, and saw a piece of flannel in the keyhole - I pushed it through, and then missed the lock; I called the other watchman, and he came - I had seen the place all right at three o'clock - the other watchman came, with a lamp-lighter, who put his ladder up and opened the window; he said, "There are thieves in the back part" - I went round, and found the prisoner and another man coming over the back fence; I sprung my rattle, and sung out, Stop thief! the prisoner was taken by a man going to his labour - I followed him, and had kept him in sight, oxcept just as he turned the corner; I took him to the watch-house, and found this chisel on him.

JAMES FULLER
. I heard a watchman's rattle on the 28th of August, opened the window and looked out; I saw the prisoner running, and Massey caught hold of him - I saw the prisoner throw something from his pocket.
Prisoner. I do not suppose that witness saw me throw anything away. Witness. Yes, I did, and my brother went and picked them up - it was those two screws.

ROBERT CHRISTIAN
. On the 28th of August the prisoner was brought to the watch-house - I searched him, and found some matches and a short pipe on him; I went to the house, and found twenty-two squares of glass in the back room, and four sashes broken to pieces; I found the lock of the street door broken. and lying in the passage - it had been broken evidently by force from the outside - I received these two screws from Fuller; I compared them with the holes in the door where the lock had been taken off, and they fitted exactly.
MR. WALKER. The key of the street door lock was in my possession, and is here now.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going to my work about half-past four o'clock that morning, when I was stopped by a man, and they took me.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

1761.
THOMAS MOXEY
was indicted for
embezzlement .

JOHN MILLS
. I live in Edgware-road, and am a baker . The prisoner was in my employ for two or three months; he was to receive money - there was 14s. 10d. due to me from Mr. Wigley, of Star-street, for bread; there was 6s. 6d. due up to the 9th of August, and the difference up to the 15th; the prisoner brought 8s. 4 1/2d. to me, and stated that it was the remainder of that bill, but he had never accounted to me for the 6s. 6d. - here are two bills in the prisoner's hand-writting for Mr. Wigley, one for 6s. 6d., and the other for 8s. 4 1/2d.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Shew me those bills? A. These are them; I took up the prisoner on Saturday afternoon on the 23d of August, between four and five o'clock; he should settle every day - I have only settled with him on Saturday nights for the bread taken out on Saturday; I never to my knowledge settled any of Friday's bills with him on Saturday night; if I have, I have forgotten it; I will not swear that he has not settled the Thursday bills on the Saturday - he was the servant of my predecessor; he was about leaving me to go into the service of a person in that street - I took him because I knew no one else; I do not know that he had a considerable connexion in the neighbourhood - he was going into the service of Mr. Shaw; I owed him his week's wages, which were 15s., but he had monies standing on my books that I had lent him; I had paid him the Saturday night before - Mr. Wigley had been a customer from the time of my going there, and had been of my predecessor; I do not know that he had made a waistcoat for the prisoner.

COURT. Q. When you apprehended the prisoner on that Saturday, was he told what it was for? A. Yes - I mentioned to him in the morning that he had been keeping his accounts very bad, and before he left me I should expect him to clear up his accounts - he said they were all right; he had had a sovereign of me, and had paid me money at different times - there was 3s. 4d. then left, and I owed him 15s; he had paid me the 8s. 4d., but said nothing about the 6s. 6d.
NOT GUILTY .

1762.
HENRY BROOKS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of August , 2lbs. of cochineal, value 20s., the goods of
Henry Gray Keat
, his master .

EBENEZER KEAT
. I am in partnership with my father Henry Gray Keat; we live in Cleveland-street, Fitzroy-square
- the prisoner had been in our employ for seven years; he was employed to grind some cochineal , and in consequence of something I had observed, I called him back on the 5th of August, about seven o'clock, as he was about to leave to go home - he came into the counting-house, and I asked him if he had anything in his pockets; he said nothing - I felt them, and could find nothing - he had a piece of green baize under his arm - I opened that, and in it found upwards of 2lb. of cochineal, which I valued at 25s.; I sent for the officer and took him up - it was the same quality as that he was employed to work upon.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you have a character with him? A. No, he came as a lad to work for us at two or three shillings a week; when I called him back, he was in the yard about ten yards from the counting-house - he had quitted the factory, and had thebaize under his arm; any one could see it - we never knew that he took cochineal home to grind; he lost three fingers, and then we employed him in the dye-house.
COURT. Q. Had he his hat on at the time he was stopped? A. Yes, he had a place to grind the cochineal on our premises.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he had by mistake taken 2lbs. of cochineal to grind, and was returning it to its place when the prosecutor charged him with stealing it.
GUILTY. Aged 19.
Recommended to Mercy by Jury and Prosecutor .
Confined Six Months .

1763.
JOHN CRAGG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 24 phials, value 2s. , the goods of
Anthony Thatcher
, his master.

ANTHONY THATCHER. I live in Red Lion-yard, Old Cavendish-square
; I am a bottle and phial merchant - the prisoner has been twelve months in my employ; on the night of the 29th of July, I called him into my counting-house as he was about leaving, and told him I had heard he had been robbing me - I desired him to turn out his pockets; he burst into tears, and took out two dozen of phials, which he put on the counter - I took him as a confidential servant.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you not say to him "Deal fairly with me, tell me the truth, and you shall not be hurt? A. No, I asked him how long he had been robbing me; I cannot recollect that I told him he should not be hurt.

Q. Had not he been in the habit of selling you phials at times? A. Yes, he had occasionally; he was not a kind of salesmen - he had not sold me more than two gross; I believe he generally brought them from a Mr. Crichton, where he formerly lived servant - I never went to Mr. Crichton; I was not threatened with a prosecution for receiving goods - it is customary for persons who are ill to give phials to their servants; I do not know that Mr. Crichton was ill - I had noticed in the morning that some of the phials had white labels on them; I used to have a great many come in - I gave the prisoner 1s. a dozen for phials; he brought some phials to me which I did not like, and told him to go to Isaacs, as he would buy anything - Isaacs is a bottle merchant.

GEORGE WOODLAND
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and bring the phials.

JURY to
ANTHONY THATCHER
. Q. Did you hold out any inducement to the prisoner to state to you whose property they were? A. I cannot be positive; I was very much agitated at the time when he produced them - I did not say anything about them; I should have no objection to take him into my service again.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.
FOURTH DAY. MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 15.
Fifth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1764.
SAMUEL HAMPTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of July , 3s. , the monies of
John James Rippon
, his master.

JOHN JAMES RIPPON. I am an ironmoger , and live in Well-street, Oxford-street
- the prisoner was my errand boy . In consequence of suspicion, my clerk, in my presence, marked some half-crowns, shillings and sixpences on the 5th of July; they were put into the till the first thing in the morning - I counted them at twelve o'clock, and they were all right; I counted them again at two o'clock and four shillings were gone - we sent for an officer, and found some shillings on the prisoner, three of which were marked - the other marked shilling has not been found; I produce three which were marked in the same way.

JOHN BULLOCK
. I am in the service of Mr. Rippon - what he has stated is quite correct.

JAMES DAVIES
. I was sent for and took the prisoner; I found three marked shillings on him, but I have left them at home.

JOHN BULLOCK
. This is the mark I put on all the money; I saw the three shillings taken from the prisoner - they had the same mark on them.
Prisoner's Defence. I was sent at different times to give shillings, and cannot say whether it was marked or not.
MR. RIPPON. He was not sent between the time I saw it right at twelve o'clock, and the time it was missed - I kept a watch on it.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

1765.
HENRY LUDLOW
was indicted for
embezzlement .

RICHARD BUDDLE
. I am a cap-maker , and live in High-street, Shadwell. The prisoner was my town-traveller and shopman - he had a weekly salary and a commission on the sale of goods; I sent him on the 22d of August to Mr. Michael's, to collect a debt of 8s. 6d. - he was to have brought it to me; he did not return, and on the Wednesday night following, I found him at a public-house, in the Isle of Dogs, apparently in a state of intoxication; I asked him if he had any money about him to give me - he answered that he had not; I asked what he had done with the monies he had collected - he gave me no answer; I did not ask where he had collected it, nor why he did not return - he had been in my employ about six months.
Prisoner. I was engaged by him as town-traveller or servant - he used to charge me so much for my goods, and what I got more I was to keep. Witness. He had 5s. a week.

DAVID MICHAELS
. I am a slopseller, and live at Lime-house. I owed Mr. Baddle 8s. 6d. - this is the bill, it is dated the 21st of August; I paid it the day after to the person who applied - I cannot swear it was the prisoner; the receipt is sigued "H. Ludlow" by the person I paid it to.

RICHARD BUDDLE
. This receipt is in the prisoner's writing.
Prisoner's Defence. I had to do business at Greenwich, Woolwich and Deptford; I took some liquor which took effect on me, and I did not like to return - there is an account between us.
PROSECUTOR. He is considerably in my debt - there is no account between us.
NOT GUILTY .

1766.
MARY ANN VARLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of August , 1 1/2lbs. of sugar, value 1s., and 3 shillings , the property of
John Morgan Thomas
, her master.

JOHN MORGAN THOMAS. I am a grocer , and live in High-street, Shadwell
. The prisoner came every day to my house to char, and was paid weekly; I lost three shillings from my till - she had access to that once a week, generally on the Monday or Tuesday. when she cleaned the shop. On the 12th of August I watched my till, which contained 2l. worth of silver and some copper; I placed myself in a sngar hogshead and heard the prisoner go to the till - I heard the money move; there was another person in the hogshead with me, and he could see through a hole what was done; I then went out and accused her of taking money - she said she had not; I sent for a constable, who found on her 3s. in silver, 8d. in copper, two 1/2lbs. and three 1/2lbs. of sugar, which I believe to be mine.

DAVID THOMAS
. I was with my master and saw the prisoner go to the till, and put her hand into it; the money was afterwards found on her - the silver was marked.

THOMAS AMES
. I am a constable. I was sent for and found these three shillings on the prisoner, and this sugar.

JOHN MORGAN THOMAS
. These are the marked shillings which had been in the till, and these found on her, make up the right money which had been in the till.
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY. Aged 27.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Three Months .
Before Mr. Justice Littledale.

1767.
WILLIAM CHAPMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of August , 1 pocket-book, value 4d., 3 sovereigns, 17 shillings, and two 20l. Bank notes, the property of
Henry Towell
, in his dwelling-house .

MARY ANN TOWELL
. I am the wife of Henry Towell - we live in John's-lane, Clerkenwell
, and keep a cheesemonger's shop , which has an internal communication with the house. I have known the prisoner twenty years - he came to our shop on the 9th of August, a little after nine o'clock in the morning - he had been in the habit of coming there from time to time; on the 9th of August, I went to a drawer in the parlour at the back of our shop, and gave my husband some money out of a pocket-book - there is a door from the shop to the parlour - it is not a glass door; I do not know exactly what money there was when I went there, but I left two 20l. Bank notes, 3 sovereigns in gold, and 17s. in silver - I am certain that is what I left; there were some shillings among the 17s., and it was all in a small pocket-book; when I took the money out, the prisoner stood on the left hand side of me, and my husband on the right; I cannot exactly say how near he was to me, or that he saw what I was doing; I gave the money to my husband that I took out - he and the prisoner were to go to buy some goods for the shop- they went out together about half-past nine o'clock - he returned with my husband between ten and eleven; he soon went away then, but returned between five and six in the evening - he did not stay long then, but he came again between eight and nine in the evening, and went away a little after twelve; I do not remember his saying anything to me, but my husband was speaking to a man about making him a grate, in the yard, and the prisoner wished me to go and tell my husband not to let the man make the grate, because he could get one much cheaper, but I did not go; I saw the prisoner shut the door between the shop and parlour once or twice in the course of the evening, and he had shut it in the afternoon as well; in the course of the evening, I went to the drawer in the parlour to get change for a sovereign, that was a little after ten o'clock - the money was all right then - I saw the pocket-book there; I left the sovereign in the same drawer, but not in the pocket-book - I took the change for the sovereign out of a bit of rag in one corner of the drawer; I have a bacon-knife, which I saw the prisoner take into the parlour between eleven and twelve o'clock - he did not stay in the parlour above two minutes, if he did so long - the parlour door was then a little way shut, but not close; no one came into the shop but the customers - none of them went into the parlour; when the prisoner went away, he said nothing particular - he bid my husband good night - I do not know that he bid me good night; my husband shut the shop up between twelve and one o'clock; my husband had not been in the shop all the evening - after the shop was shut, I saw the bacon knife on a table close by the drawer in the back parlour; I went to unlock the drawer, and it was unlocked - I had left it locked; I did not observe any marks on it; I missed all this money - it was all gone; it was between twelve and one o'clock; the bit of rag with the rest of the money was safe - this was on Saturday night, we expected the prisoner the next day; he had promised to come, but did not.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You told your husband you had this money? A. He knew I had it - I told him that night that I had missed it - I will swear that; I did not tell anybody that I did not miss it till between twelve and one o'clock on the Sunday, nor till Sunday afternoon, when I went to look for a brooch in that drawer - I did say on the Saturday morning that two sovereigns was all I had in the world; because I did not wish the prisoner to know what we had got; I said so before the magistrate - that I will swear; it was my husband who was asking me for money when I said I had no more - I only said it out of a bit of fun; he knew I had more - he had as much money as he wanted of me for his business - he had 6l or 7l.; he asked for more, but I thought he was asking for too much, and I said "Don't ask me for more - I have but two sovereigns left," but he knew I had more; I did not wish the prisoner or any person to know what I had, and because I thought my husband was asking too much; I did not take any one else up on this charge; I sent for a little girl to know if she knew anything of it - I did not accuse her of stealing it - that I will swear - I persist in that; I did not accuse her of stealing it from between my pillow and bolster, nor tell her I would transport her if she did not tell me the colour of the pocketbook, nor that I would transport her father and mother if she did not; I did not send for the streetkeeper to take her, but my husband went out to fetch her, and he met Forbes, the street-keeper, who came in, he found a piece of wood broken from the drawer, and said he had no doubt the prisoner was the man; and he would assist in taking him - this was about five or six o'clock on Sunday evening; I searched the drawer accurately on the Saturday night, but did not discover that it had been broken; I did not offer the girl a sovereign to tell the colour of the pocket-book, nor anything of the kind; I did not on my oath; I did not give her sixpence to hold her tongue; I gave it her because she cried - that was when it was discovered that it had been broken open, and I knew she could not do it - she might be there an hour in conversation, but not two hours; I mentioned when she was there that I had lost notes - I did not say sovereigns and silver only; the prisoner has been exceedingly kind to my husband in his business - he assisted him in buying things, but my husband always gave him things home with him; I have been married five years, nearly - I am lawfully married; my husband did not go for the street-keeper to take the girl up - he met him by accident; he went to the girl's mother's, and brought her from there; she had left my house at half-past ten o'clock, and I had seen my money safe then, but I did not recollect that when I sent for her, my agitation was so great; she had been there on the Sunday morning, but I did not ask her then, because I expected the prisoner to come and bring the money back; I did tell him at Hatton-garden, that if he would give me my own money I did not want any one's else - I might say so in his father's presence; I did not say "Your father is a respectable man, and can easily raise the money;" upon my solemn oath, I did not tell Mrs. Griffiths that I had put the money in the drawer on Saturday morning, and did not miss it till Sunday afternoon.

HENRY TOWELL
. I live in John-lane. I was in my shop on the evening of the 9th of August - between eight and nine o'clock that morning I had asked my wife for some money, and she gave me about 6l. altogether; I think she took about two sovereigns out of the pocket-book - I saw her take it out, and the prisoner stood on the left hand of me and close to my wife; he saw my wife take the money out - he was in the shop in the evening; he went into the parlour several times during the evening, and I noticed him taking the bacon knife to cut a slice of bread for a drunken man - he cut the bread in the parlour, but he did not stay there more than a minute or two; the drunken man was outside my shop window - the prisoner left the knife on the dining table; he went away between twelve and one o'clock, and told me he would be over on Sunday morning, if he did not go to his father's; I did not know exactly how much money was in the drawer: when the prisoner was gone my wife found the money was gone - she made an alarm, and I went to the drawer and examined it - this was between twelve and one o'clock on the Sunday morning: I did not see any marks on the drawer at that time, not till the street-keeper pointed them out - I saw them then, that was on Sunday; the marks were on the upper part, where the bolt of the lock shoots in - it was a small place; the street-keeper compared the bacon knife to the place - I merely said I suspected the prisoner, and I went with two officers on the Monday morning, about eight o'clock, to apprehend him; he was at his residence, on the other side of Christchurch - he asked me if I accused him of it; I said I certainly did.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know that your wife had all this money? A. I did not rightly know how much she had, but I knew that she ought to have near this money - I gave it her; I did not ask her for any more than the 6l. that morning - I am certain I did not; but previous to her giving me the 6l. she gave two sovereigns out of the pocket-book, and said I must not ask her for any more, for that was all she had: I knew she had about 40l., but she did not like to satisfy the prisoner how much she had got - he was exceedingly kind to us; she told me that night that she had lost the money - I went and looked at the drawer then, and examined it again on the Sunday, by day-light; the prisoner was not more than two minutes in the room - I was about one minute looking at him; I did not immediately send him to cut the bread, but a man came and asked for a pennyworth of bread, and he said, "You can sell a pennyworth of bread?" and he went and cut: I had a right to suspect the girl, as I had been robbed by a girl before - my wife knew that; she did not exactly know that I went out for the girl - I brought her in; the street-keeper was there: it is possible my wife might say, in Forbes' presence, that it was all nonsense, that she had been robbed by a girl before, and she could not get the money from her till she got an officer to take her into custody, and then she got it - I did not take notice of every thing she said; I have no recollection of such an expression; I did not hear her offer the child a sovereign if she would tell her the colour of the pocket-book - she did accuse her of taking the money, certainly; she said to the girl, "if she knew anything about it to tell her the truth" - I told the streetkeeper I had been robbed, and I rather suspected the girl; I did not see my wife give her 6d. when she was going away, but she told me of it afterwards; I cannot tell what she gave it her for - she asked the girl if she had seen anything of the money about; she said she thought she had mislaid it, and put it under her pillow, and the girl had taken it from there - I will not be certain whether Forbes was present; I suppose the girl was there half an hour; it was not so long as an hour - I went to the girl's father, her mother was out; I do not recollect that I told her father I was sure his daughter had taken the money - I told him I had been robbed, and he said the girl had brought nothing there; I think I did not tell him I was sure the girl had robbed me: the prisoner came as a friend to assist me - I offered to make him a recompense, but he never took anything but a few goods; he introduced me to a few customers, and to some wholesale dealers - I know now that he was taken very ill the next day.

BENJAMIN PHILLIPS
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner on the 11th of August, at his lodging in Collingwood-street, over the water; I saw his wife, and asked for Mr. Chapman; I said I had a job for him - she said she would be there in ten minutes or a quarter of an hour if I would wait somewhere; I said I would wait, and she went into a cart-house or shed and closed the gate - I went in, and in about two minutes she came, and said it was useless my waiting, Mr. Chapman would not be there for an hour and a half or two hours; I told her I thought he was in bed; she said he did not sleep there, he slept at Kennington; but in about five minutes I saw him - I told him Towell had been robbed; he said, "He don't suspect me, does he;" I said, "Yes he does;" I told him he must come outside and speak to him, which he did; he saidnothing further but denying the charge; I found 9s. on him - this was about eight o'clock on the Monday morning; I had been sent for on the Sunday by Field, a brother officer - I went to Mr. Towel's about seven o'clock one Sunday evening; the street-keeper showed me this knife, and I compared it with the upper part of the drawer - it appeared that this knife had been forced in, and the shuttle of the lock had been forced down - the knife fitted the place.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you known the prisoner any time? - A. Yes, for years; he knew I was an officer; I did not know that he referred people to his father's house in consequence of the obscure situation he lived in; I searched his place and his wife, but found nothing.
Prisoner's Defence. I am innocent - on my oath I never saw the money; and I do not believe the prosecutor ever had it.

MARY GRIFFITHS
. I was twelve years of age last August; I remember a piece of work being made about some money which Mrs. Towell said she had lost - she accused me of taking it; she offered me a sovereign to tell her the colour of the pocket-book; I know nothing about the pocket-book; she said if I did not mention some colour for the pocket-book, my father and mother should be transported; she said she would send for the street-keeper to take me into custody - she did not at first mention about any notes at all; she said at first she had lost a pocketbook with some silver and sovereigns in it - she did not make any mention about notes to me; she kept me about an hour and a half; she afterwards gave me 6d., and told me to go home - she told me not to take any notice, not to tell my mother and father - but I did tell my mother; as I was coming down the steps she told me not to tell my father and mother anything about it; she said she had laid this money under her pillow - I do not know the prisoner.

RACHAEL GRIFFITHS
. I am the mother of Mary Griffiths. I remember Mrs. Towell accusing her of stealing this money; she told me in the conversation I had with her, that she put this money into the drawer on Saturday morning, and did not miss it till Sunday afternoon, when she went to the drawer to get out her brooch, and then missed the pocket-book; upon my oath, as an honest woman, she told me that; I did not hear her accuse the child, but I went to know what she meant by it, and to know about the pocket-book that was lost; I asked her how she came to accuse my child of it - she said she thought she had put it under her pillow as she usually did - but she admitted she had accused the child.
COURT. Q. Are you or your husband acquainted with the prisoner? A. His father kept a grocer's shop close by, but we have not spoken to him for some years.

MR. PHILLIPS to
HENRY TOWELL
. Q. Did you yourself ever tell any body, or say in the presence of any body, that your wife had missed this on the Sunday when she went to look for a brooch? A. I did not; I never said it before Forbes or any body.

JOHN FORBES
. I am street-keeper. I know Towell - I remember meeting him on the subject of this money; I asked him when the money was missed, and he said "We had no occasion to go to that drawer, but we were going out in the afternoon to meet some friends; I wanted a little more money; I did not consider I had enough in my pocket, and she was going to give me some more."

COURT. Q. When was this conversation? A. Between six and seven o'clock on the Sunday evening - what he said was, they had no occasion to go to that drawer, but they were going out in the afternoon, and he considered he had not money enough in his pocket, and he asked his wife to procure him some; it was the Sunday afternoon he spoke of - this was after I found the drawer had been broken.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Who did he say were going out in the afternoon? A. His wife and him; he said they were going out that same afternoon, and then they missed it; he said they had no occasion to go to that drawer, but he considered he had not money enough, and he was going out that afternoon to meet some friends; he did not say anything to me about a brooch.

COURT. Q. Was Mary Griffiths there? A. Yes; I went in with Mr. Towell, and the child was crying; I went directly to the parlour, and the bolt had been shot; Mrs. Towell said she was very happy to think she had not given the girl into custody: when I first met Mr. Towell, he told me he had been seriously robbed; I went with him to Griffiths's house, and from there we returned to Towell's, and the girl was crying - Mrs. Towell said she suspected the girl, that she had been robbed by a former girl, and she owned it to the officer afterwards; he said he considered he had not money enough in his pocket, and he sent his wife to get him some - that she went to put the key into it and it would not unlock; he did not say what money his wife had given him; I have known the prisoner twelve or thirteen years; I have not been particularly intimate with him - he has not been living in that neighbourhood lately.

Mr. PHILLIPS to
MARY GRIFFITHS
. Q. What time on the Sunday morning did you go to Mrs. Towell's? A. A little after seven o'clock, and stayed till about three - Mrs. Towell was there, but she did not in all that time make any charge against me; it was half-past five or six o'clock before I was sent for.

WILLIAM CHAPMAN
. I am the prisoner's father; I saw Mrs. Towell at the Police-office, I heard her say, "There is your father, let him pay me the money, and I will not hurt a hair of your head;" my son has lived in rather an obscure situation, and his letters and parcels have been directed to me.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice Littledale.

1768.
ROBERT GRAHAM
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Edward Fitzgerald
, on the King's highway, on the 23d of August , putting him in fear and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 sixpence, 1 penny, and 3 halfpence , his property.

EDWARD FITZGERALD. I did live at Rotherhithe, and on the 23d of August, I was in Church-street, or Lamb-street, Spitalfields
. I am a journeyman bricklayer , and work at the Thames-tunnel; I saw the prisoner - I had not known him before, but I am sure it was him - he came up to me and asked what I had got; I said what was that to him - what I had was my own private property; it was some bills to stick up - he told me he was a constable, and showed me a stick with a crooked head to it; he made no more to do, but struck me, (here is the scar) and repeatedhis blow several times - a gentleman then came out of a door and protected me from any more assaults; he came from a place just by where I was knocked down; I did not do anything, for I had a misfortune, and got my limbs broken, and cannot help myself - I believe I did lay hold of the prisoner by the breast while he was striking me, but I was so confused I hardly knew what I was about; I said, "You rascal you shall not part me, you may bent me as long as you like, but till death parts me I will not let go my hold" - two gentlemen then came up; they ordered me to go and get a constable from the watch-house - I enquired the way, and the constable came with me, and took the prisoner into custody; when I left home I had 10s. about me; I had paid for my bills, and gave 1s. to a man for sticking them up, and I had 8d. or 8 1/2d., remaining when the prisoner came up - it was a 6d. and 4d. or 5 1/2d. loose in my pocket; I did not feel his hands about me - I fell down on the ground in the scuffle, but I do not know how I got there, nor how long I was there, my head was so had; I had changed my 1s. about five minutes before the prisoner came up; when he got about half-way to the watch-house, he ran down a street - the constable pursued and took him to the watch-house; there was some money found in his right-hand pocket, and as soon as it was put on the table, I said, "That is like mine" - there was a sixpence and some halfpence; and some half-crowns were taken from another pocket - I then put my hand to my pocket, and missed my money and my bills; the reason why I said the money was like mine, was on account of a particular mark on the sixpence which I had taken at a public-house in Brick-lane - I cannot say what house it was; the mark was as if a person had bit it; I took notice of it when I took it - the sixpence taken from the prisoner was something similar to it, but I do not say the money on the table belonged to me at all.
NOT GUILTY .

1769.
WILLIAM NASH
was indicted for
putting off to Thomas Smee, 34 pieces of false and counterfeit milled money, counterfeited to the likeness of good sixpences, at a lower rate and value then the same did by their denomination import, and were counterfeited for ; and that he had previously been convicted of felony.
SECOND COUNT, varying the charge.
MESSRS. BOLLAND and LAW conducted the prosecution.

THOMAS SMEE
. I am a Bow-street patrol. In consequence of a communication with Avery on the 28th of July, I altered my usual dress, and went to the Black-boy public-house, Long-acre; I saw the prisoner there, and told him I had come from Susan from the House of Correction - that I was very badly off, and should be much obliged to him if he would sell me a little money; he said I have not any now, but if you will come to-morrow night I will see - I went the next night, but he had none then - there was no quantity mentioned. On the 29th he told me if I would come the next night, he would let me have what he could; I went again on the 30th to the Two-brewers, public-housein Whitecross-street, were I met him; we went to Short's-gardens, Drury-lane - he told me he had some money for me, and said "Give me your money;" I gave him 7s., and I received 40 sixpences - he said "As you came from Susan, I will let you have some more," and told me to come again on the Saturday; I put the 40 sixpences into my pocket, and went to the Adam and Eve public-house, where I gave them to Avery; I gave the prisoner for them two half-crowns, which I had received of Avery - I told him I was very poor, or I would have given him more; he then gave me six sixpences for luck - I afterwards assisted in his apprehension on the 8th of August, and have had the sixpences ever since.

JOHN AVERY
. I am patrol of Bow-street. I communicated with Smee from time to time, and on the 30th of July he brought me forty-six sixpences; these are them - I have had them ever since.

JOHN MASON
. I assisted in apprehending the prisoner; I saw him searched, and forty bad sixpences were found on him in a black bag - Smee found them under his left arm.

Prisoner. They asked if I had got any bad money about me; I let them search me, and they found nothing - they then pulled my coat off, and he put his hand to the sleeve of my coat, and said he found them there, but there were none till he put them there; my coat was off and lying on the ground - they neither of them told me what was in the bag. Witness. It was taken out when the coat was but half off; there are two parcels, a score in each.

JOHN FIELD
. I am inspector of coin at the Mint; these forty-six sixpences are all counterfeit - they are cast from a white metal, and are all from the same mould; these forty are all counterfeit, and of the same description with the others.

GEORGE BRAND
. I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction of felony.
COURT. Q. Were you present at his trial? A. No, but he was brought to the House of Correction in 1823.

Prisoner's Defence. I am totally innocent of the charge; I was going by the Tile-kilns public-house, and the officer came and asked if I would go and have something to drink - I had drank with him once before; I said I had no money, but he said "Come in," and we went and had half a pint of gin - he handed me the first glass, and said "You treated me and I will treat you now;" he said his friend was out of place - I was shaking hands with them and bade them good by - I went some distance, and they called me back, and said I will tell you where I will meet you to night at a public-house; he then said he was an officer, and he took me to a house they call the White-house, and there they searched me - I asked what they had taken from me, but I never saw what it was till I was sent down to Clerkenwell.
GUILTY . Aged 27.
But negativing the former conviction it not having been proved.
Transported for Seven Years .

1770.
ROBERT WHITE
was indicted for
putting off 3 counterfeit sovereigns to George Watts, at and for a lower value than the same were counterfeited for .
MESSRS. BOLLAND and LAW conducted the prosecution.

GEORGE WATTS
. I live at No. 6, Dock-street, Rosemary-lane, Whitechapel - I keep a lodging-house. On the 11th of July I saw
George Horne
and the prisoner; I had arranged with Fogg before - I asked the prisoner if he had got any shan to sell; he said No, but he had got some out and out couters, meaning counterfeit sovereigns, to sell,which were to be 5s. a-piece; I agreed to take three, which were to be brought to me on Saturday night, the 12th of July - he came that night, but said they were not ready, but he brought them on Sunday morning, the 13th; he brought three counterfeit sovereigns; I gave him two halfcrowns and 7s., and promised to give him 3s. on the Monday - they had paper round them, and he told me to keep them separate; in five or ten minutes after we had left the house, I saw Fogg - I shewed him what I had got - he marked them and returned them to me; the prisoner came about three o'clock in the afternoon, on Monday, the 13th, and I paid him the 3s - I know Alexander Mitchell.

Cross-examined by Mr. CLARKSON. Q. What sort of a lodging-house is your's? A. A sailor's lodging and navigator's; there are married men and women there. I believe - I do not keep a house for the reception of men and women, but if a sailor and a woman come there I am not to ask if they are married - Horne is an acquaintance of mine; I do not know that he has been in trouble lately - I never was in trouble; I never speculated in shans and couters before the 13th of July - the first information I had of this was from Horne, at Fairlop-fair; I knew what a couter meant, it is a very common word; if a sailor comes to sleep at my house it is usual for me to take care of their money - I have had a great deal of money in my hands, and in the morning I returned it to them; they do not find any couters among it, unless they gave them to me - I never saw a bad sovereign in my life before.

JAMES FOGG
. I am an officer of the Thames-police. Watts gave me information on the 12th of July, and on the 13th he shewed me three counterfeit sovereigns, which I marked and returned to him; on the 19th I was with Mitchell and Carter on Tower-hill, but I did not take the prisoner untill the 22d of August, at Kent-street, in the Borough - he was sitting at breakfast; I said, "White, I want you, I suppose you know what for" - he said, "Yes, I have heard something about it;" I told him it was for selling bad sovereigns to George Watts and George Horne - he then said he thought so of Horne when he saw him at his house the day before, and what could he do this for? - he said, "Well, I understand they can only give me two years for it," and asked if there was anything else against him; I said not that I knew of.

Cross-examined. Q. How many of you went to apprehim? A. Four - we had four brace of pistols, and powder and shot; I was more afraid of his dog than I was of him - he told me if his dog had been at home I should not have had him then; I knew Watts before - he did live over the water, but I never knew of his keeping a house until he kept the one he lives in now; he came to me first on this subject, and asked what they were to do - I said I would mention it to the Mint, and tell him; I do not think Horne was with Watts the first night - if he was, I had no conversation with him; I have known Horne five or six months - I never knew that Watts and him went about to catch people with money; I do not believe Watts keeps a house of reception for sailors and common women; I have been in his house, but I saw no woman but his wife.

ALEXANDER MITCHELL
. I received these three counterfeit sovereigns on the 14th of July from George Watts.

Cross-examined. Q. When did Fogg open this business to you first? A. About the 11th; I was not in company with him when he went to Watts - I think I have seen Watts at the office before, but it is some months ago - I do not know on what charge; I do not think it was for felony - he appeared against two men who were transported, and gave eveidence against them.
JAMES FOGG. These are the sovereigns I marked.

JOHN FIELD
. I am inspector of coin at the Mint; these sovereigns are all counterfeit, and from the same die.
MR. CLARKSON to GEORGE WATTS. Q. Are you married? A. No.

MR. CLARKSON to GEORGE HORNE. Q. Were you examined before the Magistrate? A. Yes, and I gave evidence which was taken down in writing; I was in company with Watts when Fogg went to him - I believe it was on the 10th, but I do not recollect the day; we were not coutering together - you are talking French to me; it is a matter of indifference to me, whether I was ever at the tread-mill; the "lead story and the goose story" have nothing to do with this subject - I believe you are right that I had been about, to endeavour to precure people to sell counterfeit coin; I know Fogg, but he did not know of my being engaged in other things - he never employed me till I met him with Watts, on Tower-hill.

MR. BOLLAND. Q. You have known Fogg some time as an officer? A. Yes, but he never employed me to purchase bad money before; I saw him twice, once when I made my own purchase, and once when Watts made his - when we went to Tower-hill and met Fogg, it was for Watts to tell him what had passed.
COURT. Q. When did you see him on Tower-hill? A. On the 19th of July.
JAMES FOGG re-examined. I saw Horne on Tower-hill on the 19th of July.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you know nothing of Horne before that? A. No, and never knew he had been in custody till to-day - I told him when he came into Court, not to deny it.
Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing of them, and never sold them anything of the kind.
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Transported for Seven Years .

1780.
WILLIAM THOMAS BARNES
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Elizabeth Jones
, on the 8th of September , on the Kings's highway, putting her in fear, and taking from her person, and against her will, 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d. , her property.

ELIZABETH JONES. I live in St. Ann's-street, Westminster
; I keep a house and let a ready-furnished room - one room I let to single men. On Monday night, the 8th of September, I heard a quarrel near my door; a lodger of mine was coming across the road - the prisoner and several others had been walking about the street, with pipes in their mouths, but at that time they were at the corner; some altercation took place between them and my lodger, but I was not at the door to see it: my lodger's coat and hat were thrown into my passage - he was out in the street, but I did not see him at that time; I took them up and put them on a chair and went out to see the meaning of the quarrel - I saw my lodger on the ground on his back; I went and persuaded him to come in and dress himself, and not to fight: some people brought him in, and he was washed from the blood - I bolted my door, because the mob was so great; my lodgerwas in the house half an hour or twenty minutes, and when we thought it was all quiet, he wished to have something to eat; he took some halfpence, and went out to get something, and was knocked down again; I did not see him knocked down, but I saw him on the ground - I heard the words "Now, Bill," and I saw a man kicking him on the left side - I went up and took him by the left arm, but I could not raise him; the man who had kicked him, when he saw me take hold of his arm, struck me, and knocked me down, full length on the ground - that was
Joseph Stocks
, a brickmaker: two neighbours of mine lifted me up - I turned round and said to Stocks, "I know you" the prisoner's brother then gave me a blow on the neck, and called me a very wicked name, and told me to take that; I made no reply to him at all - the prisoner himself then came up to me and struck me on the right side of the head; I always wear a handkerchief round my neck, across my breast, and tuck it into my gown or apron - the prisoner seized the handkerchief and dragged it; I just caught it with my finger and thumb, but I could not keep it - it went with a sudden jerk, and I saw no more of it - he did not strike me after he got the handkerchief.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How many people have been transported out of your house? A. Never one; I defy any one to prove it - I know Timbrell, but he is a false man if he says that ever I had a person taken out of that house, since I have been in it; I had no lead stolen from me, nor taken from me - I do not know
Fredrick Moody
