: I have six children - I had three sons, but they are not in this country; I have nothing to do with my son's transactions - I have not had a son at home for eight years; I am bound to come to tell the truth - four persons were transported out of a house which I kept; two of my sons are at Sydney, but they are gentlemen, they never did so well - I do not know the name of the person who came into my house to have the blood washed off; his name is George, that is all I know; he had been living in my house about a month - I do not know that he fought eight or ten rounds in the street; I do not think he fought at all, I saw none - I do not know any man named Harris, but the constable; I was stupified with the blows - I felt great effects from them, and I do now; I never told any body I was in a state of insensibility for ten minutes, and that anybody in the street might have taken my handkerchief; I never said so to Harris - I do not know
Charles Treble
, nor
William Wallers
; the reason I went in the street was, when I saw the coat and hat in the passage, I went to see what the event of that was: it is not in my power to say how many people were about - there were a great number; my handkerchief had a large round ring and a table in it, and one corner of it was painted with red; I do not know that I saw the prisoner searched - I was in the watch-house, but his mother was abusing me at the time, and she very likely got as good as she gave, in your opinion.

FAITHFUL BRIGHTON
. I live in the back premises. I was at the door about eight o'clock in the evening; I saw Mrs. Jones lying on the ground - I saw a person pick her up, and after that the prisoner came up, and merely took the handkerchief off her neck; I knew him before, and can positively say it was him - I did not see who knocked her down.

Cross-examined. Q. What part of the house do you live in? A. In the back premises; there are some little cottage at the back - there was a great mob; I cannot say that there were not full two hundred people about - there were fifty or sixty round Mrs. Jones when she was lying on the ground; I contrived to get sight of her, but I do not know how - when I came out I went and threw it into the mob; she had not had too much to drink, she is not such a woman - it was a red handkerchief, with flowers and a table in the middle; no one interfered to save the handkerchief - she had been lifted up by some people before she lost it; I do not know the man who was fighting with Stocks - George was not a lodger of Mrs. Jones.

GEORGE HARRIS
. I am a constable. I was sent for and took the prisoner in St. Ann's-lane - I found nothing on him; I was not present when this was going on - Mrs. Jones fetched me from near the watch-house.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you any conversation with Mrs. Jones? A. Yes, and she told me she was in a state of insensibility for ten minutes or a quarter of an hour; she said any person might have taken it, but she was pretty certain it was the prisoner - I am sure she said that to me.

ELIZA JONES
re-examined. I did not fetch Mr. Harris I am sure - my son-in-law and a man of the name of Adams fetched him, and he asked me if I could point him out the man; I went down to the Three Elms, and Adams took the prisoner and turned him over to Harris - Harris appeared at Queen-square; if I were to die in your presence this moment, my Lord, I never said to Harris that I was in a state of insensibility for ten minutes or a quarter of an hour, and any one might have taken my handkerchiof, but I believed it was the prisoner - I said I had been a wife thirty-eight years, and never had such blows in my life.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you taken your tea that night? A. Yes, at five o'clock, but I am a person who never takes liquors for months together, when I do take it, it is as a remedy for the spasms in the stomach - I did not take notice whether Harris was sober; I had some conversation with him, to tell him who it was that struck me - if I were to tell the sincere truth of my mind, I do not think he was sober; I did say I did not take notice whether he was sober, but it was because I did not wish to injure the matter - I know I was treated by the prisoner as I have stated, and that is all I have to say; I do not altogether take upon me to say whether Harris was sober or drunk - in my own opinion I do not think he was sober; if I did say I did not take notice, it was because you were bothering of me, or because I did not wish to injure the matter, which way you please to take it.
MR. PHILLIPS to GEORGE HARRIS. Q. Is there the least pretence for saying you had the slightest appearance of intoxication about you? A. Not the slightest, I was as sober as I am now.

JAMES MILLER
. I went for Harris; my mother-in-law did not go for him; I know Adams - it was he took the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. Where is Ricker? A. I do not know such a name - I never was in gaol in my life - I might have seen the inside of it; I am not obliged to tell you how long I have been in gaol; I did not swear I never was in gaol in my life - I was in for two months; I did say I never was in gaol in my life, but it was not true - such a thing as that might slip my memory - it is nearly eighteen months since, and I forgot it; Mr. Marriot sent me to gaol - this officer never took me up in his life; how long has he come out of confinement himself for a bad sovereign? - it was Cooper took me up; I saw Harris that night, and Adams - they did their duty, and appeared sober.
Prisoner's Defence. I am innocent.

CHARLES TREBLE
. I live in St. Andrew-street. I remember the night of the row - I suppose there might be a dozen people at the time Mrs. Jones came out - the prisoner and a man named Williams, who lives in the house, were fighting for some time - they fought two rounds - after she came out, I did not see any handkerchief about her neck; she was intoxicated - in liquor; she interfered in the row, and struck a by-stander of the name of Stocks, and he knocked her down in the gutter - she had a cap, but no bonnet on - she was very rash indeed, and wanted to pull Williams away; the prisoner did not strike her at all - I will be on my oath.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1762.
MELINDA HARKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of August , 1 pelisse, value 30s. the goods of
Richard Atkinson
.

CATHERINE ATKINSON
. I am the wife of Richard Atkinson, and live in Welbeck-street
. The prisoner lodged with us from the 26th of April last - I believe she is married; I had a pelisse, which I kept in a chest under the counter - she saw me put it in there about two months ago, and she said "I wonder you are not afraid of trusting your pelisse there;" I found it on the 30th of August at a public sale shop; the prisoner had not left my apartment.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You know that this young woman surendered himself up? A. Yes - I believe the Magistrate bailed her; I saw a woman named Campbell when I went for the pelisse; it was in consequence of her describing the prisoner so plainly, that I had her taken up - she said she was a tallish genteel person, with a smiling eye, and a pleasant countenance, and followed the dress making; I do not know that there was another woman who saw me put this pelisse into the chest - I never wore it; I have only men cooks and butlers, and such people in the house, except a woman and her daughter who sell milk; the daughter saw me put it into the chest about a week before I lost it, which was on the 27th of August.

GWENNY CAMPBELL
. My husband is a butler in a family, and I keep a sale shop. This pelisse was sold to me on the 27th of August, by the prisoner for 10s. - it is a crimson silk velvet; I am sure she is the person I bought it of - I had not known it before.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know her name before? A. No - I always said she was the person; I was examined before the Magistrate, and I said the first time that I was positive she was the woman - I did not say I only believed it, but could not swear positively to her - I never said so in my life; I said once I was not positive the woman, because she was in a disabille.
COURT. Q. What did you mean by saying you were not positive as to her person? A. I said to Mrs. Atkinson "I don't think she is the person;" but I knew at the same time that she was the person.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Upon your oath, were you not so little convinced that she was the person that you went to look at another? A. Yes, I did not want to go, but Mrs. Atkinson said "Would you like to go and look at another person."
NOT GUILTY .

1773.
WILLIAM STEVENSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of August , 157 lantern leaves, value 25s. , the goods of
John Burnell
.
JOHN BURNELL. I am a manufacturer of lantern leaves . The prisoner was employed by the workhouse to fetch the leaves for the paupers to polish.

WILLIAM HIGLEY
. I am master of Whitechapel work-house. I found these lantern leaves in the prisoner's box, in the workhouse - if they had been lost, I should have had to pay for them.
NOT GUILTY .

1774.
JAMES ELLIS
was indicted for
embezzlement .

CHARLES FREDERICK GREEN
. I am a butcher , and live in Great Marylebone-street. The prisoner was my servant - I had a customer named
Joseph Rankin
.

ANN HORTON
. I am servant to Mr. Joseph Rankin, of Ulster-place, Regent's-park. On the 17th of June, I paid the prisoner some money for his master; I cannot tell how much, but I paid him when he brought the meat - the last I paid him was, on the 1st of July, 1s. 1 1/2d. - he gave me this receipt, and these other receipts are his writing: here is June 16, 1s. 8 1/2d.; June the 11th, 8s.; June the 25th, 2s. 1d.; June the 27th, 7s. 2d.; and June the 26th, 2s. 9 1/2d.; the prisoner wrote the receipt to them all, and I paid him the money for his master.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did not he always give you a receipt? A. Yes - in his own name.

MR. GREEN re-examined. Q. What was the habit of the prisoner's settling with you? A. Every day at first; and then I never had any money since October last; I suffered it to run all that time - it is upwards of 34l.; he said at first the lady was ill, and then he said he wanted the abstract of the bill and I gave it him - I have asked him for the money several times; I think the first time was before Christmas - the debt began on the 12th of April, and it went on till the 1st of July, and is 34l. 17s. 10d. - I thought they had had all this; I do not know whether they have or no - the prisoner has never accounted to me for these sums of money paid in these bills; he told me they had not paid - I said several times "It is very strange Mrs. Horton don't pay her bill;" he said at one time she was out of town, and another time she was ill - I think I spoke to him about it in June: but in July he asked for the abstract te be sent, and I said I supposed she was going to-pay.

Cross-examined. Q. Up to October she used to pay daily? A. Yes. for a little time prior to the 12th of October, and from then I have received nothing: he brought orders for meat and he took it; he told me part of thetime that she was out of town, but there was part of the family there - I let it go so long because she was a respectable lady, and I did not like to ask for fear of offending her; my books are not here, but there is an entry in them of the bills, and of the money I received - I was not ordered to bring them here; I took them to Mary-le-bone Office - the books are the things that would tell what I received.
NOT GUILTY .

1775.
SARAH LAMBETH
was indicted for
embezzlement .

MARH ELTON
. I am the wife of
John Elton
; he is a varnish-maker. The prisoner lived with me to go on errands, she was to receive money for me, and to give it me as soon as she received it.

MARY BROCKLESBY
. The prosecutrix washed for me for many years; I paid the prisoner a sovereign, on the 15th of August, for her mistress.

MARY ELTON
. She never paid it to me; she went with a basket of clean linen and never returned - I went after her, and found her on the 17th, in the Pancras-road; I got an officer and her took her - she told me she had bought some clothes with the sovereign; she had been in my service three weeks - I gave her victuals, drink, and lodging, and some clothes: she had received half a sovereign from Mrs. Brocklesby which she brought me.

RICHARD COOPER
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner; she said she had the money and bought some clothes - I found her old clothes at a house in Dyot-street, where she had been: she was an unprotected girl, and this good woman took her in out of charity.
GUILTY. Aged 16.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury.

Judgment Respited
.

1776.
DAVID EVANS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of August , three 10l. bank notes , the property of
John Evans
.

JOHN EVANS. I am a cheesemonger , and live in Clothfair
; the prisoner is my eldest son of ten. On the 10th of August, I had a pocket-book, which contained three 10l. Bank notes, and a number of cheques; I missed it about ten o'clock that morning - it had been in a kind of teachest or caddy, in a closet, in my bed-room; the caddy was locked - it was taken from my bed-room up to the attic, and the nails were drawn: my son had been in my house from Whit Sunday till the 10th of August - before that he had been in the work-house; he got into the work-house and then got away - I have seen two of the notes in the possession of the constable; he sent back the pocket-book and the cheques by a porter.

ROBERT DALLON
. I am a constable. I was on my rounds on the 10th of August, and went into the Plough public-house; I received information there, and waited until the afternoon, when the prisoner came, and I took him into custody - I took two 10l. notes from him and seven sovereigns and a half; I told him what I took him for - he looked very stupid and strange, but gave up the notes very willingly; I asked him how he came to do so, he said he was very sorry - he did not deny it.

JOHN EVANS
re-examined. Q. Are these two of the notes you lost? A. Yes - they have my writing on them; I knew they are what I lost - my son has laboured under mental derangement; he was at Bethnal-green for nine months, and then at St. Luke's for a twelve month - I believe he was at this time labouring under mental derangement.

ROBERT DALLON
re-examined. Q. Did you not take up another person on suspicion? A. No - I understood he was acquainted with a girl in Denmark-court; he offered her the notes, and she refused them.

ALEXANDER CULLEN
. I am landlord of the Plough - the prisoner came there on the 10th of August, and called for a glass of porter; he then asked me to send this book to W. Smith - I got a man to take it; I had never seen the prisoner before.

FRANCIS EVANS
. I live with my father. My brother has been out of his mind for two years; I believe he is out of his mind now - he has been discharged as a lunatic.
NOT GUILTY, believing him to be insane .

1777.
CHRISTOPHER MARTIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of August , 28 lbs. of rope, value 4s. , the goods of
Thomas Blyth
.

DAVID STEVENS
. I am clerk to Mr. Thomas Blyth, who is a merchant and ship owner . On the 8th of August, between four and five o'clock, I was superintending the landing of some goods on the wharf; Driscol told me there was a boy in the warehouse taking some rope - I went there, and saw the prisoner with it; I asked what he was going to do with it; he said to take it to his master - I asked who his master was; he said William John Brown, a rigger, at Wapping; he had moved the rope five or six yards.

MICHAEL DRISCOL
. I am a labourer. I saw the prisoner take a piece of rope from the inside of the warehouse - he was bringing it out towards the gate; this is the rope- I saw him on the premises five or six days before, and I turned him off.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I thought I saw a ship, which I expected to go on board of; a man asked me to carry this to Narrow-street, Wapping, and said he would give me 6d. I took it up, and this man came and asked where I was going; I said to my employer's, a man of the name of Brown, the foreman then came, and said I should not go off the premises till he saw my employer - I was going to find him, and he called me back.
GUILTY. Aged 16.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury -
Confined 3 Months .

1778.
THOMAS McDONALD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of August , 22 pairs of braces, value 11s. , the goods of
Benjamin Pole Price
.

BENJAMIN POLE PRICE. I am a haberdasher , and live at Shadwell
. On the 18th of August, I lost some braces from my door-post, but I did not see them taken - I saw them in the possession of the officer, and knew them to be mine.

- LAWRENCE. I was at a friend's house, opposite the prosecutor's; I saw the prisoner walk backwards and forwards; he then took the braces, and went off - the watchman stopped him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

JAMES CONNOLLY
. I heard the cry of Stop thief! I proceeded to the spot, and stopped the prisoner, who was in the act of dropping these braces.
Prisoner's Defence. This gentleman came and took me; when he was at the watch-house he said he did not see me take the braces - I know nothing about them.
GUILTY . Aged 50.
Confined Three Months .

1779.
JOSEPH PERKINS
and
SAMUEL PERKINS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of July , 6 shillings, and 1 sixpence , the monies of
John Bastar
.

JOHN BASTAR. I am a mechanic ; the prisoners were in my employ: I sent Perkins and Berry on an errand to Thames-street, to purchase some sheets of copper; I gave Berry two sovereigns, out of which he was to pay for the copper; he brought me this bill, but neither of the prisoners were there at the time - I never heard from either of the prisoners what sum of money was paid.

WALTER BERRY
. I was in the employ of Mr. Bastar. I went with Perkins to buy this copper; we paid 1l. 11s. 10d. for it - I gave my master the bill.

COURT to JOHN BASTAR. Q. What was the sum you was told they paid? A. 1l. 19s. 4d., agreeable to this bill- I gave them the two sovereigns to pay for the copper, and accuse them of stealing the difference.
NOT GUILTY .

1780.
JAMES SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of July , 1 clock, value 40s., and 24 pencils, value 2s., the goods of
John Young
, and another; 1 seal, value 10s., the goods of
James Young
, and 1 silver pencil-case, value 1s. , the goods of
George Alexander Young
.

GEORGE ALEXANDER YOUNG. I live in Eagle-street, Red Lion-square
, and am a builder ; it is a counting-house and warehouse, but no one sleeps there. On the 15th of July when I went there, soon after six o'clock in the morning, I found the desks and cupboards open, and a window open in the shop, and the clock was missing; I looked about some time, and as I was coming out, about seven o'clock, one of my men called out that he had found the thief; he then turned the prisoner up from a mortar-shed; I knew him - he had been in my employ two years ago.

JOSEPH KENT
. I received information, and went to the premises; I found the gates had been unfastened from the wood; I looked about, and found the clock and seal in a hole behind the gate.

CHRISTIAN PARGES
. I am constable of the night; about twelve o'clock the property was brought in, and we went to the yard, but could not find the prisoner - here is a seal, a pencil-case, and two knives, which were found under where the prisoner was.

STEPHEN BROWN
. I work on the premises. I found the prisoner in a dark vault, about seven o'clock in the morning - he was lying down: I got him out, and found those things under where he had been.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I had been to the play, and it was over late; I walked about all night, and went down that place, and there they found me.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .

1781.
THOMAS SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of August , 13 horse-shoes, value 6s., and 1 1/2 lb. of nails, value 1s. , the goods of
Samuel Townley
.

SAMUEL TOWNLEY. I am a farrier , at Three Cups-yard, Bedford-row
. On the 27th of August, I fastened up my shop, and was called up at near one o'clock in the morning; I found the shop-window had been taken down, and some person had been in; I afterwards missed some property which I knew to be mine - it had been safe when I went to bed.

JOHN LLOYD
. I am a watchman. I was on duty, and stopped the prisoner, between twelve and one o'clock, with this property - here are some horse shoes and nails; I asked where he got them; he said, "I brought them from my master's premises, in Three Cups-yard;" I said, "I am sure you are wrong, you don't mean to do this:" he said,"I did it on purpose to leave the country." I took him to the watch-house, and then went to the premises, and found the shutter down - I called up the prosecutor.

SAMUEL TOWNLEY. He had worked for me up to that time, but he had been away for two days, as he sometimes was - he had no right to get into my premises, and take my property; when I saw him he said, "Master, it is your property; I got into the shop, and took it out."(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I had been with some friends, and gone Mondaying; I drank rather too much, and did not know what I was doing.
GUILTY. Aged 22.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor, believing it to be his first offence .
Confined Six Months .

1782.
ESTHER STUFF
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of August , 1 purse, value 1s., 1 sash, value 2s., 1 collar, value 7s., 1 piece of lace, value 1s., 1 piece of ribbon, value 6d., 1 pair of stockings, value 2s., and 1 sovereign , the property of
Samuel Harrison
.

SAMUEL HARRISON. I am a linen-draper , and live in Charlotte-street Fitzroy-square
. On the 18th of August, at half-past nine o'clock at night, I was at supper - the prisoner has been my servant for about six months; we heard a noise, and my wife said "There is some one in the shop;" I said, that could not be, as I had closed the front door - I had counted the cash in the till before I went to supper - I went into the shop and missed a sovereign; I called up the prisoner and charged her with it; she denied it - I asked if she would have any objection to let me see her box - she said she had no objection; she went up stairs and opened the box herself; I found various things belonging to me in it - this purse was in her pocket; she said this was her own, and she brought in from the country: this purse was in her pocket, this gauze sash was in her box, and this collar, this piece of lace, which my wife had had about one of her caps and had lost it, and this pair of my wife's silk stockings - they are all mine - no other person could have taken the sovereign; I gave them to the constable.
Prisoner. Q. Have you any of them marked? A. Yes; I marked them when I bought them.
Q. No, you marked them the morning after? A. No, I did not.

WILLIAM JAMES DONKIN
. I am a pawnbroker, and live at No. 15, Norfolk-street, Middlesex-hospital. The prisoner pawned some things with me, but they are not in the indictment.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence (written.) On Monday, the 16th of August, I was in bed about ten o'clock at night, when my mistress came to my bed-room door, and desired me to get up - my master followed her, and insisted on my getting up, as he had missed a sovereign; they searched my pocket, and found nothing in it but an old purse - they then searched my work bag; in it was a pair of black silk stockings that I had washed and mended, but had omitted taking them up stairs; in my box was a waist ribbon I had purchased in the shop of my master after I had been there about a month, a black handkerchief I had bought in the country, a small ganze scarf I gave 1s. 3d. for in Charles-street, Soho-square, all of which they have sworn to as their property, as well as a collar I had given to me by a friend, and was in pledge, with some other things, for 10s.; my master and mistress both said if I would say where the sovereign was they would not send for an officer, but pay me my wages, and I should return to my friends; next morning, when they searched the shop, the sovereign was found on the floor; though they had found it, they sent next morning for an officer.

SAMUEL HARRISON. I told her if she did not tell me where the sovereign was, I would send for an officer; she then came down into the shop, and took it up from a corner, as she pretended, but I think she had it in her mouth; she brought me down 10s., which she said she had picked up, but I do not think she had; I had frequently missed money out of the till.

Prisoner. I took the lamp into the shop to have oil in it- I saw the sovereign lay in the shop; I touched it with my foot, but not with my hands - I thought it did not lay in my way, and I did not meddle with it; they called me up, and took my key - my mistress unlocked my box, and searched it; I told them I saw the sovereign in the shop - my mistress took it up, and put it into my master's hand.

SAMUEL HARRISON
re-examined. Q. At what time did she produce the sovereign? A. In about half an hour; she said her mistress would not know where to find it.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Seven Years .
FIFTH DAY. TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 16.
Fourth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1783.
WILLIAM DYSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of June , 1 coat, value 3s. , the goods of
John Fish
.

JOHN FISH. I am a glazier , and live in Bishopsgate. On the 27th of June I left my coat in a house at Hackneygrove
, where I was at work; I went out at twelve o'clock, to dinner, and when I returned it was gone - I saw it again in a few days, when the prisoner was in custody; he had been working on the premises as a labouring gardener.

ROBERT FISH
. I am the prosecutor's brother, and was working in the house. On Saturday, the 28th of June, I saw the prisoner in Sun-street, Bishopsgate, with my brother's coat on; I spoke to him for some minutes, and a person came by - I collared him, and asked that person to assist me; the prisoner said it was all nonsense - we had a scuffle, and he ran away; I pursued, and cried Stop thief! he was taken by Sapwell.

CATHERINE DOGGET
. I was servant at No. 7, Hackney-grove, next door to the house the coat was stolen from. I saw the prisoner on the 27th of June, come out of that house with a flag basket and a bundle; he hung the basket on the pales, and then got over and took it away; I believe the workmen were gone to dinner - it was between twelve and one o'clock.

THOMAS SAPWELL
. On Saturday, the 28th of June, I was at tea, between four and five o'clock; I went out, and saw the prisoner running down Lamb-alley - I pursued, and took him; Robert Fish came up, and said he had got his brother's coat on; I said, "How do you know it is your brother's?" he said, "If you look on the right shoulder you will see it is sewed, which it is; the prisoner said he bought it in Petticoat-lane.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was returning from the Londondocks, and went to Petticoat-lane; I bought this coat, and exchanged my own old one; I then went up Sun-street, and stopped Robert Fish; I talked to him a little while, when he said I had got his brother's coat on; I said it was all nonsense, and walked away - he called Stop thief! and I ran, not wishing to be locked up all day on Sunday.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Three Months .

1784.
THOMAS CARTWRIGHT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. , the goods of
George Witt
.

GEORGE WITT. I am in the service of the East India Company . On the 25th of July I was on the Paddington stage, opposite Regent-crescent
; I felt a jerk at my pocket, looked round, and saw a boy getting down from behind the coach; I felt my pocket, and my handkerchief was gone; I saw the same boy stopped - I lost sight of him in getting down from the coach; I then saw him running, and several persons pursuing him; I think I should know him again; the handkerchief was found in the crescent, which he had passed; a girl who was drawing some children in a chaise threw it to me.

SAMUEL WITT
. I was with my brother on the coach on the 25th of July; he clapped his hand to his pocket, and called out Stop thief! I turned round, and saw the prisoner running away - he threw the handkerchief over the pales; I lost sight of him while I got off the coach, but I observed him enough to be certain that the prisoner is the boy.

RICHARD HARTLY WALL
. I am an officer. I produce the handkerchief, which Mr. Witt gave me; I found 1s. 6d., a knife, and a tin box on him.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going home to my dinner, and running to make haste, I heard the cry of Stop thief! one gentleman was trying to get over the rails, and a girl threw the handkerchief over the rails; I know nothing of it.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1785.
GEORGE STAMP
and
JOHN WILLIAM WHITLEY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of August , 7 lbs. of cheese, value 6s. , the goods of
Richard Morriss
and
John Holland
.

CHARLES PRIDDLE
. I am shopman to Richard Morriss and John Holland, of Skinner-street, Somer's-town
. On the 30th of August I was outside the window and saw the two prisoners for about an hour; I presently heard acrushing in the shop; I went in, and the prisoners were brought in with this cheese, which I know to be my employers'; I had seen it about an hour before, near the doorpost, where there was a lot on a tub.

WILLIAM BEESON
. I am a green-grocer, and live in Skinner-street. On the 30th of August I was walking from one of my shops to the other: I saw Whitley shew the cheese to Stamp, who took it down, and gave it to Whitley - he put it under his coat, and ran away; I caught hold of Stamp, but he got between my legs, and another person took him; I then caught Whitley - the cheese fell on the ground; a gentleman behind me took it up, and brought in Stamp with it.

JAMES PEARSON
. I am a watchman. The prisoners were both put into my custody between ten and eleven o'clock on Saturday night.(Property produced and sworn to.)
STAMPS' Defence. There were numbers of boys standing round, and I never touched the cheese.
WHITLEY'S Defence. I was standing near the rails, and they took hold of me - I had never seen the cheese.

STAMP -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Whipped and Discharged.

WHITLEY -
GUILTY . Aged 12.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1786.
JAMES WILLIAMS
&
THOMAS WILLIAMS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of July , 2 brushes, value 1s., and 2 towels, value 6d. , the goods of
James Possilwhite
.

JAMES POSSILWHITE. I am an engraver . On the 5th of July I lost two brushes and two towels from my wash-house - I had seen them the day before; James Williams was employed there, painting, and had access to the wash-house.

JOHN BOWLER
. I took up the two prisoners together, on the 5th of July, at a quarter-past four o'clock in the morning; I met them, and asked what they had got in the butter-flats - they said rabbits; I took them to the watch-house, and these brushes and towels were found on Thomas Williams - he said he had bought them for a pot of beer, of a person on Finchley common; the towels were in his hat, and the brushes in his pocket.
NOT GUILTY .

1787.
JAMES WILLIAMS
&
THOMAS WILLIAMS
were again indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of July , 21 rabbits, price 2l. , the property of
Thomas Transfield
.

DANIEL WARREN
. On the 5th of July the prisoners were brought into the watch-house, with these twenty-one rabbits in these two flats.

JOHN BOWLER
. I met the two prisoner at a quarterpast four o'clock in the morning, coming from Highburygrove, with these two flats - each of them had one; I asked what they were - they said rabbits, which they had bought at Finchley; they said they lived at home with their father - he did not like the rabbits, and they were going to take them to Newgate-market to sell, as they were a nuisance in the house; I took them to the watch-house, and in going to the office in the morning one of them said, "Master, I am sorry we did not tell you the truth - we did not breed the rabbits, we bought them, and we live in Long-lane, Smithfield; we could not make up 10s., and the man let us have them for what we had got;" I said I should ask them nothing, and they said no more.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did James claim them as his property? A. It was James who first spoke to me; Thomas never spoke to me: I have heard that they are not related to each other; I believe the proper name of James is Hitchman, but they said they were son's of the same father, and gave their names as James and Thomas Williams.

WILLIAM TRANSFIELD
. I live at Highgate
, and lost these rabbits on the night in question. I am waiter at Mr. Pledger's, and go home to Highgate once a week; on the 29th of June I saw them safe, and never saw them again till the Monday week.

TIMOTHY HODGSON
. I live in the prosecutor's house, and attend to the rabbits. At eleven o'clock at night on the 4th of July, I fastened them up in a stable, and next morning I heard a noise a little before four o'clock, and the rabbits were gone - these are them.

EDWARD NICHOLLS
. I sold these rabbits to the prosecutor - I know them very well.

J. WILLIAMS -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

T. WILLIAMS -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Baron Vaughan.

1788.
MARTIN MELLETT
&
JAMES FARTHING
were indicted for
b-gg-y .

MELLETT -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 19.

FARTHING -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 19.
Fifth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1789.
WILLIAM ARCHER
was indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of the Rev.
David Thomas Powell
, on the 5th of September , and stealing 4 tureen covers, value 2l.; 2 candlesticks, value 1s., and 2 extinguishers, value 2s. , his property.

THE REV. DAVID THOMAS POWELL. I reside at Tottenham
. On the 5th of September I was informed my house had been entered, but I was not there myself; I went to see how it had been entered - it was about two o'clock in the afternoon; I did not find any breach in the door or window, but the drawing-room window was open, and the dining-room door had been locked, but the key was in the door - I suppose they had opened that door; I missed four tureen covers, and two or three candlesticks and extinguishers - I had seen them safe the evening before; I believe these to be mine, from having had them a number of years, and my father's crest being on them.

JAMES REYNOLDS
. I am a saddler, and live at Tottenham. On the 5th of September I was in my shop- about one o'clock I saw a young man named Layox pass my door, whom I had taken up two years before; I went to the door, and saw the prisoner join him just opposite the public-house - they passed my house once or twice, and went into a cook's shop and bought something to eat; they then watched about, and went round to the back of the prosecutor's premises; I put on my coat and hat, and followed them - when they got to the bottom of the prosecutor's grounds they parted company; I went into a neighbour's, being certain that they intended something wrong - I should have stated, that when they firstjoined company the prisoner put two or three pieces of sponge into the other's hand, that he might appear to be selling sponge; the prisoner himself had been offering some at my shop; when I got to my neighbours, I asked them to assist me, and we went up and saw the prisoner near the hedge - I went up to him, and saw his hat looked rather remarkable; I said, "What have you got here?" I took off his hat, and found this large nail in it - I said,"Where is your sponge?" he said, "I have got no sponge;" I said, "You have, here it is" - it was lying under the hedge; I then said, "Where is your companion?" he said, "I have no companion;" I said."Don't you know Layox?" - he said No; I said, "I will tell you how it is, he is at Mr. Powell's premises" - I gave him in charge, and went to the back of Mr. Powell's, and saw Layox come out; as soon as he saw me he put down this plate, and made his escape, as I was two fields off him - the prisoner, I suppose, was about two hundred yards from the premises; the prisoner was then taken and searched - I pursued Layox some distance, but I was not very well; I then went to Mr. Powell's and gave the alarm, and asked if they knew they had been robbed - I went up to the sideboard, and found these three pieces of sponge near it, which convinced me that they had belonged to the prisoner, because one of the pieces I had particularly noticed; I went to the watch-house and saw the prisoner searched, and these two keys were concealed at the bottom of his trousers.

JOSEPH FOSTER
. I am a constable of Tottenham. A man named Newsom brought the prisoner to me - I took him to the watch-house, and found these two latch-keys concealed at the bottom of his trousers: I asked what he did at the bottom of the field - he said he was picking up caterpillars, and his father was a bird-fancier.

- STUKELY. Mr. Reynolds came to me, and we went and searched the premises; when I got near the green-house, I found this plate lying down under some scarlet-runners - I did not see the prisoner until he was at the watch-house; the way the person must have got in was - there was a chain and a rope on the gate at the bottom of the garden, the rope was cut and the chain forced, and then they must have come up the green, and got into the drawing-room window; I found this other large nail close by that place.(Property produced and sworn to.)
NOT GUILTY .

1790.
WILLIAM BRACKLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of August , 1 mat, value 2s.; 1 bag, value 2s.: 1 rasp, value 6d.; 3 nail-bags, value 1s. 6d.; 1 screw-driver, value 3d., and 1 file, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Henry Grainge
and another, his masters.

WILLIAM GRANT
. I am apprentice to Henry and
Daniel Grange
, who are ironmongers
. The prisoner was in their employ on the 25th of August; I know this mat to be their property - they had received it with some things a few days before; I had not quite unsewn it, and when it was returned it was exactly in the same state - I cannot speak to the other things, but one of them has the name on; they are all such articles as they sell.

ROBERT BARNES
. I am shopman to Messrs. Granges. On Monday, the 25th of August, I was desired to follow the prisoner, which I did to his own house; I then asked him how he came to take the mat, which was then under his arm - he said he thought it was of little or no value; it was charged to us about 2s. or 2s. 3d. - these tools were found in the prisoner's house by the constable, in my presence; I believe them to be my employers'.

JOHN FERNE
. I am a constable. I went to the prisoner's, and found these articles.
Prisoner. Mr. Barnes came to me, and said I had got a mat that did not belong to me; I said I would take it back - he said it did not matter about my taking it back.

ROBERT BARNES
. He did say so; I said I would not advise him to do anything.

WILLIAM GRANT
re-examined. Q. What was the right thing to do with that mat? A. To take it to an out-house, where we keep such things - we use them in packing, but not very often; the prisoner had been three or four years in our employ, and had a good character.
NOT GUILTY .

1791.
MARY ROLLS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of July , 1 sovereign, the money of
James Dancer
, from his person .
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1792.
JAMES TREVILLION
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of July , 1 tea-kettle, value 3s. , the goods of
John Bullock
.

JOHN BULLOCK. I am an ironmonger , and live in Featherstone-street, City-road. On the 26th of July, I was out; I had seen this kettle before nine o'clock that morning, and I saw it again at the office - it has my privatemark in it.

HENRY WILLIAM TREVIS
. I am apprentice to a ropemaker in Featherstone-street. On the 26th of July, I was looking out at a window up stairs, and saw the prisoner looking into the prosecutor's window - he then took the kettle, and walked up the street with it; there was another person with him - I told a man who worked in the room with me; I went down and pursued him, and took him in the City-road with the kettle - I lost sight of him for about five minutes, but I am sure he is the same person.

GEORGE WOODGATE
. I am an officer. I received the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was going to my dinner, and saw a lad turn the corner of Featherstone-street, and put down the kettle at a door - I took it up.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .

1793.
VICTORIA THOMPSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of July , 1 pair of sugar tongs, value 4s.; 4 stockings, value 1s.; 2 cups, value 6d.; 1 cap, value 6d., and 1 napkin, value 6d. , the goods of
William Orton
,

SARAH ORTON
. I am the wife of William Orton, we live in Luke's-yard, Shadwell
. I missed the articles stated, from the kitchen dresser, between the 20th and the 25th of July; the prisoner had been in my house about two months before - I know I had these things in use on the 10th of July.

BOYD SILVESTER. I am an officer. I got a warrant to search the prisoner's house at Deptford - I found two cups, a cap, and napkin; I then asked her for the sugartongs, or for the duplicate - she denied having them; I said I should search her, and then she gave me the duplicate.

RICHARD PARRY
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a pair of sugar-tongs pawned on the 11th of July, for 3s., I believe by the prisoner; I gave her this duplicate.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating, that she intended to replace the things when the prosecutrix paid her 9s. which sum she was indebted to her.
SARAH ORTON. I owed her nothing; she owed me 9s. - I had her to work it out.
GUILTY. Aged 25.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor .
Confined Fourteen Days .

1794.
THOMAS BAKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of August , 1 window-sash, value 12s. , the goods of
John Doyle
, and another.

GEORGE JONES
. I am in the employ of Messrs. Doyle's of Princess-street, Queen-street, fan-light makers . On the 16th of August, about eight o'clock in the morning, I went down stairs, and while there, I heard some person push the door gently open, and go up stairs - I listened, and saw the prisoner coming down with a sash in his hand; I said "What are you going to do with that sash?" he said "Charles Christmas sent me for it;" I detained him - I had seen him before.

Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. Was there a young man named Christmas in your master's employ? A. Yes, he is now in custody; the prisoner said Christmas was in Holborn - I did not go there for him; he was taken, I believe, about two hours after; the prisoner had never been in my master's employ.
NOT GUILTY .

1795.
THOMAS BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of August , 1 saw, value 7s.; 5 planes, value 16s.; 1 hand-vice, value 14s., and 1 trowel, value 1s. , the goods of
Robert Boyd
.

ROBERT BOYD. I am a carpenter . On the 16th of August I was working at an unfinished house in St. Pancras
- I left all my tools there at night; there were a saw, planes, trowels, and other things - my son went on the Sunday to see if they were all safe, and they were gone - I saw them again on the 19th.(Property produced and sworn to.)

WILLIAM KIRBY
. I took the prisoner on Saffron-hill, on the Sunday, with these tools on his shoulder - he said they were his own, and he had brought them from Hornsey.
Prisoner's Defence. On the Sunday morning I met a young man, who asked me if I knew any body who wanted to purchase these things - he said he would sell them for 10s., and I bought them.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

1796.
WILLIAM COOK
and
JOHN BOWDEN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 1 pair of trousers, value 5s. , the goods of
William Mote
and another.

WILLIAM MOTE. I am in partnership with Mr. Appleby, we are pawnbrokers , and live in Little Warner-street, Clerkenwell
. On the 20th of August, about seven o'clock, Mr. Lyne came and told me there was a pair of trousers taken; I looked, and missed them - I went out, and in about ten minutes I saw the two prisoners come down Coppicerow with two others; Bowden had these trousers, which are ours.

ROBERT LYNE
. I live opposite. My wife gave me information; I went out, and saw Cook going up Bath-street with the trousers - he was alone; I told the prosecutor, and we went out and found Bowden with them about two or three hundred yards off; I had not seen the prisoners join together.

JOHN SUTTON
. I superintend the watch. The prisoners were brought to me - I took Bowden to the watch-house, and found nothing on him but a knife; I heard Cook say, he took them and gave them to another person.(Property produced and sworn to.)
BOWDEN'S Defence. I was going along Bowling-green-lane, and a young man put these trousers on my arm - the gentleman then came up and took them.

COOK -
GUILTY . Aged 15.

BOWDEN -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Whipped and Discharged.

1797.
MARY HAGAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of July , 3 half-crowns, 6 sixpences, and 240 farthings , the monies of
Charlotte Dunn
, widow ,

CHARLOTTE DUNN. I am a widow, I carry on the business of a rope-maker . On the 8th of July there were two hundred and fifty farthings, six sixpences, and three half-crowns, all in one drawer in a box in my room; I had seen them all right on the Sunday evening; I have seen sixty-two of the farthings since that - the prisoner said,"Don't hang me, and I will give you half a crown;" she says she is very sorry for it; she was recommended to me to nurse some children.

BENONI MARKS
. On the Monday night the prisoner came to my master's shop in Somer's-town, and asked me to give her three halfpence for six farthings; I did so - and asked if she had any more; she said Yes, and then she brought one shilling's worth; she then came again, and asked me to give her one shilling for tenpence in halfpence and eight farthings; I did not ask how she came by them, but the next day I heard that Mrs. Dunn had lost them.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1798.
JOHN JONES
was indicted for
stealing, 2 saws, value 7s. , the goods of
William Hannaford
.

WILLIAM HANNAFORD. I am a carpenter . On the 12th of July I left two saws at a house in Mulberry-terrace
, at six o'clock, and on Monday the 14th I missed them - these are them.(Property produced and sworn to.)

MICHAEL HANLEY
. I am a private watchman. I saw the prisoner coming out of the building on the 12th of July, between nine and ten o'clock with the saws - he dropped them about one hundred yards from the building.

JAMES SELLS
. On the 12th of July, between nine andten o'clock I heard a cry of Stop thief! I ran up the street, and saw the prisoner coming down - I stopped him; the watchman came up with the saws.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I saw some people, and ran to see what was the matter.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1799.
WILLIAM LEDGER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of July , 2 silver spoons, value 2l. , the goods of the
Earl of Limerick
.

DANIEL DUTCH
. I am an officer of Mary-le-bone. On the 28th of July I saw the prisoner come to Mr. Squires', the Devonshire Arms public-house, between seven and eight o'clock in the morning - I was in the house searching it because there had been a robbery; while I was in the cellar I saw a cupboard locked; I opened it, and found these two spoons in it; I asked Austin where he got them, he gave me some account, and I took the prisoner.

JOHN AUSTIN
. I had the care of the cupboard at the Devonshire Arms - I keep my cords and provisions there; I put those two spoons in on the Thursday before; I got them from the prisoner; I had lent him some money before - he wanted some more, and I said I would not lend him any more till he gave me some security; he then brought these spoons - I knew he was in the Earl of Limerick's service; I did not open the spoons to see if there was any coronet on them.

BENJAMIN SCHOFIELD
. I am a constable. I went to Lord Limerick's, in Mansfield-street, and the butler wished the prisoner to stop with me while he looked over the plate; I asked the prisoner what he had done; he said, nothing that he knew of - but in a few minutes he said he had given Austin two tea-spoons, as a security; the butler then returned, and was very very angry with him, but would not give him in charge; the prisoner, however, went with me to the office.

WILLIAM SNOOKS
. I was butler to the Earl of Limerick - the prisoner has been two years in his service, and had twenty-four guineas a year; I heard there were two spoons at the office, and I went, and knew them - I went back, and spoke to the prisoner about them; they have a crest on them - the prisoner had property in his care to the amount of 500l.; I always found him honest.
NOT GUILTY .

1800.
JOSEPH LEE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of August , 1 hammer, value 1s. 2d., and 3 iron tips, value 1d. , the goods of
Edward Dodd
.

EDWARD DODD. I am an ironmonger , and live in Moor-street, Soho. The constable came on the 6th of August, and gave me information; I suppose this hammer might be mine, but there are many alike - I do not really think it is mine; I do not think these tips are mine - they are odd ones. The prisoner was in my shop on the 6th of August, and asked to look at a hammer and some bristles; I showed him some hammers pretty near like this, but the iron of this hammer is more straighter than mine - he paid me 1d. for the bristles, and then came in and asked if I had lost anything - I had shown him seven or eight hammers.

DANIEL HONE
. I am an officer. On the 6th of August I was facing the prosecutor's window about nine o'clock in the evening, and saw a lad looking in the window - I crossed over, and he ran away: I saw the prisoner in the shop, looking at some hammers - Mr. Dodd turned round, and the prisoner put this hammer into his pocket; Mr. Dodd then came to the window - the prisoner put his hand into a bag, and put some tips into his pocket; he stood talking a minute or two, and was then coming out - I stopped him; and went in and asked Mr. Dodd if he had bought anything - he said only the bristles; I took the hammer out of his pocket, and showed it to Mr. Dodd.
The prisoner put in a written Defence soliciting mercy, and received a good character.

EDWARD DODD
re-examined. All the articles in the shop are mine.
GUILTY. Aged 17.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1801.
CHARLES CHRISTMAS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of August , 2 window sashes, value 24s., the goods of
John Doyle
, and others, his masters .

WILLIAM DOYLE
. I am partner with my father, John Doyle, he is a fan-light maker . We missed some sashes on the 16th of August - the prisoner was our apprentice - these sashes which are here, correspond with those in our stock; I measured them, and I know we had sashes like those; we missed sixteen of them; the circumstance of one sash being found with Baker, led us to look, and then we missed them. (see Page 838)
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you see the prisoner take any sashes? A. No.

HENRY HERRING
. I am a labourer. On the 16th of August, about nine o'clock in the morning, the prisoner came to our house at Somers'-town with these two sashes, and asked him to let him leave them for a short time; I let him leave them, as I thought he might have a job in the town; I afterwards gave them to the constable.

SAMUEL SHUTTLEWORTH
. I received these two sashes from Herring - Green took up the prisoner; Herring had been to Mrs. Baker's once or twice to know what was to be done with them, and Mrs. Baker went to Herring's, and said "For God's sake! break the glass and burn the frames.

MR. PHILLIPS to HENRY HERRING. Q. We have heard that you went once or twice to Mrs. Baker's? A. Yes, I am sure it was not Baker who left them, but I went to know who Christmas' master was; I went there again, because she said her son could tell me.
Prisoner's Defence. I do not know the young man at all.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Six Months .

1802.
CATHERINE STEEL
and
JOHANNA BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of August , 1 reticule, value 1s.; 1 scent-bottle, value 6d.; 1 thimble, value 6d.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; 1 sovereign, and 10 shillings, the property of
Wright Welby
, from the person of Jane his wife .

JANE WELBY
. I am the wife of Wright Welby. On the 8th of August, I lost a reticule, containing a sovereign, a half-sovereign, 10s. in silver, a smelling bottle, a silver thimble a card case, a handkerchief, and a Frenchshilling; I had missed my way, and came down Phoenix-street, which comes into George-street, at the top of Holborn
- I met the two prisoners and another girl - they each asked me for a penny a piece; I then asked them the way to Tottenham-court-road, and one of them said"Go and show the lady the way Bet" - Brown went to shew me the way; I said "Never mind, I can find the way," but she came up close to me, and snatched my reticule, and said "That is the way," and ran off - Steel was close to me at the time, and when I called Stop thief! she struck me; I fell against the wall, and she fell down.

WILLIAM DRAKE
. I am a shoemaker. I saw the prosecutrix about eight o'clock, in George-street, St. Giles' - she and Brown passed by my door, and when they had gone past four or five yards - Brown stepped up to her, and snatched her reticnle from her left arm, and an umbrella from her right - the prosecutirx cried Stop thief! and Steel struck her on the back: I moved from my own door, and asked the prosecutrix if she were frightened; I did not see the property after that, nor see the prisoners taken.

MORRIS NICHOLSON
. I took Steel into custody the next day - I told her it was for stealing a reticule the evening before; she said it was Brown, and she got blamed for it; as we were going along, she said if I would go into a house she would tell me where it was planted, and she begged to have half a pint of beer - I said she might have the beer, but she did not tell me where it was.
STEEL'S Defence. As for Brown, I know nothing of her - I was in liquor, and what I said to the constable I know not.
BROWN'S Defence. As for Steel, I know nothing of her nor the prosecutrix.

STEEL -
GUILTY . Aged 19.

BROWN -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1803.
ANN WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , 1 seal, value 38s., 1 key, value 18s., and 1 ring, value 4s., the goods of
George Vince
, from his person.

GEORGE VINCE. I was in the Commercial-road
on the 31st of August, about half-past eleven o'clock at night - the prisoner followed me from Whitechapel down as far as the terrace, which is, I suppose, a mile; she wanted me to go home with her - I said I would not; she did not ask me for anything till she took my seals - I mean, she first robbed me, and then begged of me; she took hold of my seals, and broke the chain off - she kept them, but said she had thrown them away.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What are you? A. A journeyman carpenter - I did not meet her long before half-past eleven o'clock; I had not promised her any money that night - I had not known her before; I walked with her about half an hour - I did not turn into any lonely lane or alley with her, that I will swear: I live at No. 92, Fore-street, Limehouse - I did not say I was captain of a ship, nor that I lived in the East India-road: I could not shake her off, she would follow me - there were watchmen in the street; she asked me for money after she had taken my property - upon my oath I had not given them to her for certain services; no intercouse had taken place between us - she broke the chain by force; she put her hand through my arm, and took the chain and twisted and broke it, and then said she had thrown it away - this was in the Commercial-road; there was no one passing: I did not call out directly I came up to the watchman - I did not tell him I had given her these things: I was sober - I had spent the day with a friend in the City; I had drunk about half a bottle of port, but no liquor, nor beer - I then spent the evening with Mr. Dunn, of Skinner-street, Snow-hill; I never was in his company before, but I went there with a friend - I swear that I had no intercouse with the prisoner, for which I gave her the seal and chain, and promised her 5s., or half a sovereign, when I could get it; I never admitted that I had any intercourse with her, to Brown, or in his presence, or any one else.

GEORGE BARLOW
. I am a watchman. The prosecutor and prisoner came to my box after twelve o'clock; the prosecutor said, in the prisoner's presence, that he had been robbed of his seals and key, and a part of his chain, and he gave her in charge for it - these seals, key and chain were in her hand; the prosecutor did not appear in liquor - when the prisoner came to my box she asked me for change for a sovereign; I said I had not got it - she said afterwards that these things had been given her as a present.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you ask her whether it was her own sovereign or this man's? A. No; but she told me she wanted chauge, that he might pay her the 5s. for which she held these things - she said that he had intercourse with her.

COURT. Q. But at first did she say so? A. No; she said in about five minutes that she had had it given her as a pledge for 5s. - that was when we were at the watch-house; when he was charged with having intercourse with her he denied it - she did not enter into any particulars.(Property produced and sworn to.)
MR. PHILLIPS called

- BROWN. I am watch-house-keeper. Vince came to the watch-house with the prisoner; I came in about five minutes after, and said to Vince, "How came she to take them from you" - he said, "They were in a private place near Arbour-terrace;" I said, "If you were standing up, she could get them" - "No (says he) I put her down, but we were walking afterwards;" upon my oath he confessed that he had intercourse with her - so help me God.

COURT. Q. If he confessed that to you, how came you to let the charge go to a Magistrate? A. I had no question asked me; I did not state what he told me - I have no business to speak if I am not spoken to; I was before Mr. Burnell, the Magistrate.
NOT GUILTY .
SIXTH DAY. WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 17.
Fifth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1804.
WILLIAM CANNADINE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of March , 1 watch, value 6l.; 2 seals, value 3l; 1 key, value 14s.; 1 shirt, value 4s.; 1 cravat,value 3s., and I pair of stockings, value 1s., the goods of
John Mashfield
, in the dwelling-house of
Charles Marriot
.

ROBERT WARD
. I am a watchman of St. Mary-le-bone. The prisoner came to lodge in the same house with me in Jubilee-court, Chelsea, at the latter and of March; he said he had spent a great deal of money, and was very much distressed - he offered to sell me a duplicate of a watch, two seals and a key, for 2l.; I bought it of him, and told him if he would come to me in two or three months and give me my money, he might have it again - I went to redeem the watch with my pension money, and the pawnbroker would not give it me.
Prisoner. you were to keep it for me. A. No; I bought it but I said you might have it again.

JOSEPH HARRIS
. I am a pawnbroker. A watch, two seals, and a key, were pawned with me for 2l. on the 24th of March, by a man in the name of John Smith - I do not know the person, but I gave this duplicate; Ward applied to me, but I had heard something.

JOHN MASHFIELD. I am in the employ of Mr. Cubit; I lived in Francis-street
: Mr. Charles Marriott kept the house. On the 17th of March the prisoner came there for employ; he was recommended by a clergyman, and I put him to work - I provided him with tools and clothes, and let him have some money - On the Friday following he came and said he had seen his brother and he should decline working any more, as one Mr. Scott, a banker in the City was dead, and he was entitled to 1200l. - he said he was to be buried at Norwood, and he shewed me some clothes for mourning, which he got from a tailor: I lent him 23s. to pay his expences; he went on Sunday morning, and he promised to return on the Sunday afternoon about four o'clock, but he did not: I lent him the watch in question expecting him to return- I got some information, and found it at Mr. Harris's; I did not find the prisoner till the 25th of August, when I took him in a field where he was at work.
Q. Where did you lend him this watch? A. I did not lend it him; he took it himself, and said, "You may as well let me have this to appear respectable; I will return it in the afternoon.

RICHARD CANNADINE
. I am a brother of the prisoner; he married a relation of Mr. Scott.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. They were lent to me.
GUILTY. Aged 29.

Of
stealing only -
Confined One Year .

1805.
DANIEL SULLIVAN
was indicted for
feloniously assulting
Thomas Warner
, on the King's highway, on the 23d of May , putting him in fear and taking from his person, and against his will, 5 sovereigns, and 6 shillings, his monies .

THOMAS WARNER
. I am a book-binder . Between eleven and twelve o'clock, on the night of the 23d of May I was coming from Duke-street across Smithfield to the East-side; I met two females near the Bear and Raggedstaff - they caught hold of each arm, and said "We have got you now, we will not let you go without you give us some gin;" I tried to get away, but could not - I then gave them a glass of gin each - I did not have any myself; we remained but a very short time in the house - they then turned into Smithfield - I remained a minute or two at the door, and said, "Now for Clerkenwell;" the prisoner and another man were there - the prisoner said to me, "You live in Clerkenwell;" I said, yes - he said, "You are not far from it;" I said, I know it - I looked at him, thinking he was a neighbour, and we went on together towards Bath-street, where I live - we crossed the way towards Cow-cross, and I turned up Peter's-lane
- the prisoner was at my right-hand, and I had no sooner got to the top where the posts are fixed, than I received a blow on my left ear which knocked my hat off - I turned round and said, "That is what you mean is it?" I seized my money out of my pocket into my hand - there were six sovereigns and twelve shillings; I tried to save myself, but could not- I was thrown down, and the prisoner seized my hand, and said, "You b-g-r let go;" I was obliged to let go, and he received the money into his left hand - he turned back my hand, and took it; I saw it as plain as I see you now - I never saw my hat afterwards; the prisoner went off to my right-hand: I called Watch! and at length one came from St. John's-lane - I told him I had been robbed - I did not go back the same way, as I thought it might be worse for me; we went up St. John's-lane - I am certain the prisoner is the person: my eyes were fixed on him several times in walking along, when we came to a gaslight.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How many gaslights did you pass? A. I do not know; the young ladies turned into Smithfield - I had not seen them before; I did not take any of the gin myself; I had been drinking two or three pints of beer, but no spirits; I was not considered tipsy when the watchman came up, nor I should think the worse for liquor; the prisoner was not taken up till the 1st of September; I gave information on the 31st of August - I did say that I had been treating two women, and I might be a little tipsy; Phillips asked me if I knew the person that robbed me, and I said I did not - he is not a particular friend of mine; I borrowed a hat of him, and called on him a fortnight afterwards and paid him for it - he asked me if I had had this person apprehended; I told him No, but I could have him apprehended at any time; the reason I did not have him apprehended was, he was a character so well known - he was out of the way; I was taken ill, and could not go through such a fatigue: I mean I had not got his name and place of abode. On Saturday, the 6th of September, I called again on Phillips; I told him I had been to Hatton-garden Office, and had parties apprehended for this robbery; I think he asked if they were the parties I had been speaking about before, but I did not say "No, it was a neighbour of mine" - I am quite sure I did not tell him they were not the same parties I was speaking about before; I said the watchman knew the prisones, and he gave me the first intimation, knowing the prisoner and one of the women passing his beat repeatedly, but he did not know the prisoner's name; I will not positively say whether I said it was upon the watchman's information that I took this man up.

WILLIAM GLOVER
. I am a watchman. On the night in question I saw the prosecutor in Smithfield, between ten and eleven o'clock, just below the Bull's Head public-hose - the prisoner was with him; I passed them from my beat - the prosecutor was very much in liquor; I askedwhere he was going - he said to Clerkenwell; I said, "This is the way," and I passed him off my beat; the prisoner said they were going to Clerkenwell; I did not take any more notice of them that night, but the next night the prosecutor came and told me he had been robbed.
COURT. Q. Did you know the prisoner before? A. I do not know that I had seen him before; I had no knowledge of him.
Q. Do you mean to swear that? A. Yes: I never saw him in company before.
Q. Company or not, had you not seen him? A. Not till after the robbery; I saw him after the robbery a few days; it may be a week or two.
Q. You have seen him several times since? A. Yes; he did not say he was the person who had robbed him.
Q. Did not he tell you he was the man who had been with him? A. Yes; he mentioned that.
Q. Then you knew he stated that the prisoner was the man who robbed him - did you tell him you had seen the prisoner repeatedly? A. Yes, I did.
Q. Why did not you take him up? A. He gave me no order to take him up.
Q. Did you not know the prisoner before? A. I had seen him once or twice before.
NOT GUILTY .

1806.
WILLIAM BUTLER
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Francis Welch
, on the King's highway, on the 3d of August , at St. Pancras, putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, five half-crowns, 17 shillings, and 11 sixpences , his monies.

FRANCIS WELCH. I live in Fitzroy-market. On the morning of the 3d of August, I was in Tottenham-court-road
, about one o'clock; I met the prisoner and two more young lads, at the corner of an archway - the prisoner came up, put out his leg, and threw me down; I am sure he is the person - the others came to his assistance, while he put his hand into my pocket; while I was down I caught hold of his collar and called for the watchman; we had a tussle - he handed the money out of my pocket to one of the lads, who ran away with it, but I detained the prisoner till the watchman came; I saw him in the watch-house the next day, and I told him if he handed the money over to me I would do no more to him - he said he had not got the money, but if I went to his father, he would see what he could do for me.

Prisoner. He said I had robbed him of a sovereign, and he was in liquor: I told him I had no money, and when at the office he said I took one sovereign and 15s. Witness. No - I said 1l. 15s.; it was five half-crowns, seventeen shillings, and eleven sixpences.

WILLIAM EMERY
. I am a watchman of St. Pancras. On the morning of the 3d of August, I was in Tottenham-court-road, about one o'clock; I saw the prosecutor and the prisoner entangled together - there were two persons standing not far off, who made off; I took the prisoner and prosecutor both to the watch-house, and the prosecutor charged him with robbing him of 1l. 15s. - he did not say it was a sovereign; he had been drinking, but he seemed sensible enough to know what he was about.
One witness gave the prisoner a good character.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 16.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury on account of his youth .

1807.
JEREMIAH LEARY
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Jacob Woolf
, on the King's-highway, on the 3d of July , at St. George, putting him in fear, taking from his person. and against his will, 1 pocket-book, value 2s., and 1 hat, value 15s , his goods.

JACOB WOOLF. On the 3d of July, between six and seven o'clock in the afternoon, this man went past my shop, No. 33, Ratcliff-highway
; he broke a pane of glass - my housekeeper called to me "Mr. Woolf, the man has broken a glass" - I went out and said he must pay for it; he said "Don't be frightened, I will pay for the glass - I have got no money, go with me home;" I am a foreigner - I asked my neighbours, "Shall I go home with him or not" and they said Yes; I asked where be lived - he said"Old Gravel-lane;" he took me to a very narrow street, and said "Here, I will pay for the glass" I was astonished - he knocked me on the ground; I cried Murder! he put his hand to my mouth and took my pocket-book - he took my hat up and ran away; there were three or four hundred people there, all Irishmen - I was glad to save my life and get away; the prisoner went away; I am quite sure he is the man - he was taken up in eight or nine weeks - I did not see him from the 3d of July till he was taken.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were there not any Englishmen? A. No, all Irishmen; there came two Englishmen, and took me away; it was not another man who said he would pay me for the glass - the prisoner told me he would pay for it; I went out - the prisoner was there alone; there was no other person; I mean to say it was the prisoner who struck me - no one saw him strike me; there were three or four hundred people there.

REBECCA COHEN
. I am housekeeper to Jacob Woolf. On the 3d of July I was outside the window, and the prisoner was just by the window, a man on the other side was talking to him; the prisoner broke the glass, and I told Mr. Woolf of it; I called him - he came out; I shewed him that was the man - he went away with him; when he came back his face was all bloody and scratched - he came back in an hour's time; I heard the prisoner say, "Come with me, I have not got the money in my pocket" - I am certain he is the man.
Cross-examined. Q. Was it this man who broke the glass? A. Yes - it was not a friend of his who said he would pay for the glass, it was this man himself.
Prisoner's Defence. There are plenty of witnesses to prove that I had no more to do with his pocket-book than a child unborn.

JOHN BRIAN
. I am a coal-whipper. I was going along the highway, and saw a crowd round the window: the prosecutor had hold of the prisoner by the collar, and said he broke the window - the prisoner did not say Yes, nor No; I spoke to Woolf, and said, "You had better go with the man to his house, and perhaps you will get paid"- I followed them, and they went on; I went into my own house and came out again, and saw the prisoner and prosecutor on the ground; Woolf was on the prisoner, and had hold of his handkerchief, and a crowd of women were about them - a number of them separated them, and the minute Woolf got up he pointed to a man to whose shoulder the prisoner does not reach, and ran into houses and houses after him; the prisoner went away without his hat; he did not run - he was not able to run.

- BRIAN. I am mother of the last witness. My son came in and told me Leary had broken a window; I went into the street, which was King-street, Old Gravel-lane - I saw Leary and the prosecutor down - the prosecutor was uppermost and had no hat on; there was a crowd of women round - the prosecutor got up, and looked after a tall young man, named Timothy McCartlty; he ran through four or five houses, and the prosecutor after him; Leary did not run - he was not able to run; he was helped away by the women to his own house, which was not five yards from the place; the prisoner did not attempt to run, but the prosecutor ran after the other man to different yards.

COURT. Q. Did you see any pocket-book? A. Yes, in the hand of the prosecutor - he had it open, and I thought he was an officer until my son came and told me a window was broken - I saw it at the place where I saw them on the ground.

ELLEN CRANE
. I was at my own door as the prosecutor and prisoner came down the street; they turned down an archway, and there was a great mob - I went towards the part; I saw the prisoner under the prosecutor, and his fist was fastened in the prisoner's handkerchief - I went and loosened his hand from his handkerchief, and said."Don't choke the man, he will pay you;" he said, "I will have him," and he expressed words not fit to be mentioned - Woolf then got up, and there was a tall man, with a working dress on, stood at the corner, and he said, "You are the man that did me damage" - he ran off, and the prosecutor after him; the prisoner would not reach his shoulder - there were two other men helping Woolf to follow him.

JACOB WOOLF re-examined. Q. Have you heard and understood what these witnesses have said? A. No, not all - they were laughing at me; I had not my pocketbook in my hand - two men were helping me to pursue the person who had ill-used me: they offered to go to the Police-office, but I could not go, I was so much murdered - the prisoner ran away, and two Englishmen went after him; I was afraid to go into any house - Brian went into one: Brian was in company with the prisoner by the house - they were by the side of each other; I went after Brian - I thought they were partners; I wanted him to tell me where the prisoner lived.

JURY to
REBECCA COHEN
. Q. In what manner was the window broken? A. With his arm - I do not know whether he did it on purpose; I said, "Master, you have broken the glass" - he was standing still, and a man and a woman talking to him; there were some fashionable fur caps in the window - they looked very handsome.
Prisoner. I was shoved against the window.
Six witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 31.

1808.
JOHN WOODASON
was indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of Jane Woodason, on the 4th of August , and stealing 1 hat, value 4s.; 1 waistcoat, value 3s.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; 5 sovereigns and 1 half-sovereign , the property of
Frederick Woodason
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1809.
JOSEPH HARRISON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of August , 3 lbs. weight of copper, value 2s. 9d. , the goods of
John Braithwaite
, his master.

CRARLES LEA
. I am foreman to John Braithwaite, who is an engineer . On the 19th of August the prisoner was leaving work - I called him back; the constable was sent for, and this copper found on him; he is a smith in our employ, and had copper of this king entrusted to him- three of these pieces had been found in a particular place, and they were marked to see who would take them.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Where were they concealed? A. Under the ashes of the forge; if copper had been dropped there, it might have been covered with ashes, but that was not a place for it - it is not common for smiths to work at home; he was employed from six o'clock in the morning till six at night for my master, the other time he had for himself - I do not know that the prisoner had worked at home; when the constable came he acknowledged he had the property, and begged to be forgiven.

GEORGE FERGUSON
. I am an officer. I was sent for, and took the prisoner - I heard him state what the witness has just repeated; these ten pieces were found on him - three are marked.

Prisoner. On the Monday I took this copper to the shop for the purpose of cutting it; I have a small modelmachine making - I have some tools at home, but I have not a hammer, except a very small one; I came from Nottingham - I began making the machine there, and am going on with it; they went to my house, and found a small bench and some tools - I was going to the West London Theatre on Monday - as Mr. Lea's son was to perform: on the Tuesday, I went to work again; I was called out between three and four o'clock, to do a job, which I was not in the habit of doing (unloading some castiron) - I said "This is pretty work to set a tradesman to do labourer's work;" when I went in again, I was told some copper had been marked - I said whether it was or not, I should take it up; I took it from under my bench, and was putting into in my pocket, when a man ran and told Mr. Lea.
LEA re-examined. Q. Did he say anything of this at the time? Q. No; he owned he had it, and begged Mr. Braithwaite to forgive him - he appeared very much confused.

Prisoner. He came to the counting-house door, and said "Have you some property of Mr. Braithwaite's?" he put his hand to my pocket, and said "Yes, here it is," and then he said "How many times have you taken copper of your master?" I said "Never before, and I hope you will forgive me."

JURY to
CHARLES LEA
. Q. Did you know it to be Mr. Braithwaite's property before he marked it? A. Yes; from its being the same sort as he uses for bolts and other things.

Cross-examined. Q. If such copper was laid before you, could you swear it was Mr. Braithwaite's? A. No, we have them in long rods ten or twelve feet long; it is not usual to cut them into small pieces.
Prisoner. Q. When did you mark that copper? A. While you were taking in the iron; I only marked three pieces - the man did not tell me it had lain there from the Monday morning. GUILTY. Aged 24.

Recommended to Mercy -
Confined Two Months .

1810.
JOSEPH TAYLOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of August, at St. Ann, Westminster, 9 lampirons, value 10s., fixed in certain street and places there situate, and dedicated to public use ; against the Statute,&c.

SECOND COUNT, stating it to be 396 lbs. weight of iron, value 10s., the goods of, and belonging to
Daniel Niven
and others, and then being fixed to certain buildings.
TWO OTHER COUNTS varying the manner of stating the charge.
MR. BARRY conducted the prosecution.

GEORGE CLUBB
. I am a smith, and live in Mitcham-street, Paddington. I have known the prisoner twenty years: he came to my shop on the 7th of August, to ask if I would go and give him a hand in the morning to do a job - he said he could pay me four or five shillings. and I could be back to my work by ten o'clock; I called him at three the next morning, and went with him to great Chapel-street
