- he raised the ladder against the wall, and said he had to take those lamp-irons down; he pulled a paper out of his pocket. and said he had so many to take down in that street, and some in King-court; Orange-street, St. Ann-court, and Carlisle-street - I believe Dean-street was mentioned; we went to work to pull them down - they were fixed up with nails and staples; we were about three hours, and pulled down eighteen in the whole - we put them down in two loads, and he said"We will take a load a-piece to where they are to go;" I took one load, and went with him to Newman-passage, to a man's house, named Burrows; I believe I carried four loads, and he took one, and the second load he was stopped with - I carried two loads after he was stopped; I afterwards saw him with Lucas, near a builder's yard, in Great Chapel-street; there was another gentleman with Mr. Lucas - the prisoner went into the yard; I said to him "Joe, what are you carrying them here for?" he said "Go and mind the other load, as there is a screw loose;" I did not know what it meant, but I thought it did not sound very well - I stood and watched him some time; I then went and worked at the heap, and took the second load - afterwards two men came up, and asked where I was going; I told them - they said I must go with them - they took me to Mr. Heron's, the builder's yard; I was taken to the watch-house, and from that to Mr. Burrows - I pointed out the lamp-irons, and was then taken to Marlborough-street, and there was admitted as a witness.

Prisoner. Q. What money have you received from the gentleman since my commitment? A. Sometimes I received 1s., and sometimes 2s. 6d.; I do not know how much in all - I called on you in prison, and you asked me to bring you a bit of tobacco; I never told you then what I had received - nor said that I was to go for more on Saturday; I certainly called on you on the 5th of September, but I was not drunk - I said I had received 2s. 6d. - you asked me why I had not gone away, and I said I could not; you said you would have gone on glass bottles to have got away - I did not, to the best of my recollection, want half a sovereign of you; I have been two or three times to you, but not to get money - you had been in the first regiment with me; I did not shew you my coat sleeve, and say I could not go into the country without a coat.
MR. BARRY. Q. Have you been out of work? A. Yes; and I got some money of the parish.

WILLIAM WHITEHOUSE
. I am a labourer in the employ of Mr. Heron, of Carlisle-street. The prisoner was brought to our yard about seven o'clock, on the 8th of August, by Lucas, who is the inspector of nuisances; the prisoner had some lamp-irons on his shoulder - he said he had been taking lamp-irons down, and he brought him to know if he was authorized to take them down; the irons were left with me - the prisoner went away with Lucas, and said the Company had employed him.

WILLIAM CRAG
. I am an officer of Marlborough-street. On the 8th of August, I executed a search-warrant with Lucas, at Burrow's house, in Newman's passage; I saw some lamp-irons there, which appeared to have been fixed - I went the second time with Clubb, and took them away.

FRANCIS MACE
. I am inspector of the parish of St. Ann's, Westminster. In the month of August I went with Clubb to Great Chapel-street, St. Ann's-court, Carlisle-street, and that neighbourhood - he pointed out places where lamp-irons had been taken from by him, and the prisoner; I had seen the irons there before, and I saw irons at Burrow's, which appeared to me to be the same.

The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that a man named Houghton of No. 6, Great Chesterfield-street, who represented himself as foreman of the gas works, had employed him to take down the irons and dispose of them.
GUILTY . Aged 39.
Confined Three Months .

1811.
JOHN BARCLAY
was indicted for
bigamy .
MR. BOLLAND conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM WILLIAMS
. I am parish-clerk of St. Mary, Newington, Surrey. I find by this register, that on the 16th of December, 1824, John Barclay, bachelor, and
Elizabeth Cornelius
, spinster , were marriedin that church, by bans, in the presence of
Charles Brand
, and
Elizabeth Gilliard
.
ELIZABETH BRAND. My name was formerly Gilliard. I saw the prisoner married to Elizabeth Cornelius, in December, 1824; she is still living - I have not a doubt but the prisoner is the man.

ITHIEL PRICE
. I am parish-clerk of St. Dunstan, Stepney
. On the 25th of June, 1827 , there was a marriage in that church of John Barclay, bachelor, and
Mary Phillips
, spinster - I am quite certain the prisoner is the man who was married on that occasion.
Prisoner. Q. Did the Minister ask if we were of age? A. No. If he considers it a clandestine marriage, he does, but you brought two witnesses with you, and it appeared a proper marriage.
MR. BOLLAND. Q. Should you remember the woman if you saw her? A. Yes; she is in Court.
MARY PHILLIPS. I lived with the prisoner as his wife, after our marriage, for twelve months; he made away with my clothes, and the tickets of my property.
Prisoner. Q. What age were you? A. Twenty.

Prisoner's Defence. I was deceived by my first wife; we lived together some time, when she absconded to livewith a man named Lacey; I was afterwards given to understand where they lived - I went and saw her, and proposed her return, but she rejected it; I then became acquainted with Mary Phillips, and she became my wife, and we lived comfortable for twelve months; I was then out of employ, which caused her to apply to the parish, and they made inquiries - it has been stated that I pawned her clothes, but they did not exceed 2l. in value; I was under age when I married my first wife, and my last wife was under age when I married her. I hope you will be as lenient as possible, as both the acts were committed without due consideration.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Confined Six Months .

1812.
ISAAC BEVEN
and
WILLIAM ADAMS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of August , 50 lbs. weight of lead, belonging to
Thompson Hankey
, and fixed to a certain building, against the Statute .

ANN BUMSTEAD. I am a widow, and live in Graham-place, Dalston. I was in my upper room on the 18th of August, and saw the two prisoners; Adams was assisting Beven in getting on the roof of Mr. Hankey's coach-house - it was only Beven got on the roof, and he stripped the lead from the roof; I sent my servant to give an alarm: I saw Adams go to the other side of the road, and return with a bag, which appeared to be empty - I did not see them more than ten minutes.

WILLIAM PREST
. I live near Mr. Hankey's coach-house at Dalston
. On the 18th of August I saw the two prisoners near the coach-house gate, and a parcel of lead lay on the ground by them; I heard one of them say to the other, "D - n the fellow, why does not he come with a ladder?" I then walked across the road, and had a more full view of them; while I was there Bumstead sent her servant to ask if I thought they were Mr. Hankey's workmen - I said I thought not; I still watched them, and saw Adams pick up some slates; he marched off towards Hackney, and the other began to take up the lead; I walked up to him, and said, "What are you going to do with that lead?" he said, "What am I going to do? I am going after the slater to do a job in Hackney-road;" I said, "What are you going to take Mr. Hankey's lead? No, you shall not step a foot further;" he then threw the lead down, while I had hold of his collar; Mr. Hankey's servant then came out; Adams afterwards told me he lived in Bryan's-buildings, Kingsland-road - we have inquired since, and the address is correct.

HENRY TROTT
. I am gardener to Mr. Thomson Hankey. On the 18th of August I went out, and saw the lead - I compared it with the top of the coach-house; it fitted it in every part and every nail hole.

JOHN KEEN
. I am in Mr. Hankey's service. I saw the lead fitted - it matched exactly.

BARNARD JEFFREY
. I took up Adams on the 20th of August - he said he had done nothing that he knew of; he was near his own house, in Kingsland-road.
ADAM'S Defence. I was going to my work - I never touched any lead; I had a load of slates on my shoulder, and that gentleman came and detained me, and looked at my property; I told him where I lived.

MRS. BUMSTEAD re-examined. Q. Are you sure you saw this man help the other? A. I could not swear to his person, but Prest got sight of them before I came down - I saw him get up to them before I lost sight of them; Adams went across the road and got the bag, and then Prest went up to them.
Beven received a good character.

BEVEN -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Six Months .

ADAMS -
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Confined One Year .

1813.
JOHN FOTHERINGHAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of July , 1 quadrant, value 20s; 2 shirts, value 4s.: 2 pairs of trousers, value 6s.; 1 frock, value 1s., and 1 pair of drawers, value 1s. , the goods of
Bartholomew Crannell Longmuir
.

RUTH SARAH ESTALL
. I keep a lodging-house for seamen at Bell's-wharf, Shadwell
. The prisoner lodged at my house - he left me on the 29th of July, between six and seven o'clock in the evening, and did not return; I missed this property, which belonged to Bartholomew Crannell Longmuir - I had seen them safe the day before in his chest, in the back kitchen; he was at work on board a ship - this is one of his shirts; I had given it out to be washed several times.

CATHERINE PORTER
. I live in Dean-street, Shadwell. On Tuesday evening, the 29th of July, I saw the prisoner at near eight o'clock - he passed by and spoke to me, and I saw a quadrant in his bosom; I pulled his waistcoat aside, and saw it; I asked what he was going to do with it - he said he was going to take it to the young man it belonged to; he called him James.

JOSEPH HAWES
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Ratcliffe-highway. On Tuesday, the 29th of July, the prisoner pawned a quadrant with me, about half-past eight o'clock in the evening; my house is about five minutes walk from Mrs. Estall's.

EMANUEL SOLOMONS
. I am a salesman at Rosemary-lane. I bought two duplicates of the prisoner - one was for a quadrant, and the other a shirt; I got the quadrant from Mr. Hawes, and sold it to Mr. Harris; I got the shirt - this is it.

HENRY HARRIS
. I bought the quadrant of Solomons - this is it.

JAMES WHITE
. I took up the prisoner - he said he took the quadrant, but not the clothes: but when he was before the Magistrate he said he took the quadrant and the shirt.
GUILTY. Aged 25.

Recommended to mercy . -
Confined Six Months .

1814.
HENRY THOMPSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of July , 1 pair of trousers, value 4s. , the goods of
Barnett Moss
.
BARNETT MOSS. I am a slop-seller . On the 17th of July, at nine o'clock at night, I lost a pair of trousers, which I had seen about half an hour before.

JAMES NOBLE
. I am a constable of Shadwell, and live next door to Mr. Moss. On the night of the 17th of July I went to my door, and saw the prisoner standing near his window - I crossed the way, and when I turned round he was gone; I thought he had stolen something - I followed,and saw him with a pair of trousers in his coat; I took hold of him, and he dropped them.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY. Aged 39.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1815.
DANIEL McLANE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of August , 1 hat, value 5s. , the goods of
David Hyams
.

DAVID HYAMS. I am a clothes-dealer , and live in Wardour-street
. I was at my door on the 8th of August - I saw somebody put a hand in, and take a hat from my door; I did not see who it was, but I went out and saw the prisoner running - I called Stop thief! and my neighbour brought him back; the prisoner ran about thirty houses - I saw him stopped; I have not recovered the hat - there was another boy whom I saw.

WILLIAM RUFFLE
. I live with my father near the prosecutor's. On the 8th of August I saw the prisoner take the hat out and give it to his companion, who ran off; I did not see which way he ran, but I saw the prisoner run - I am sure he did not walk; I was looking out of window - I came running down to the door; I am sure the prisoner is the boy who took it.
Prisoner's Defence. I was walking up the street, and saw people running - I ran, and a man stopped me.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years .

1816.
THOMAS PEGG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of August , seven 5l. Bank notes , the property of
Duncan Thompson
.

SECOND COUNT, stating them to be the property of
Jane Thompson
.
MR. SHARPE conducted the prosecution.

MR.
JOSEPH WINNY GULL
. I did live in Upper Seymour-street
. but I removed from there, and left Jane Thompson, who had been my servant , in care of the house. I did not know the prisoner was there - I never gave him permission to reside there; I paid Jane Thompson 15l. in the middle of July, and at the beginning of August 20l., taking then a receipt for 35l. - they were in 5l. notes, some of which came from Messrs. Barclay and Co., and some from Mr. Lanson; I did not take the numbers.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you given this young woman permission to let any man sleep in the house? A. No - I knew a man of the name of McKenzie, but he is dead; I have known the prisoner since the beginning of 1826 - he was my servant for ten or eleven months in 1826, and I gave him a good character, and since then have taken him into my service.

MR. SHARPE. Q. Was not McKenzie a servant of yours? A. He was - I made no stipulation for either the prisoner or McKenzie to stay in the house; I thought it better that Thompson should have some female to stay - McKenzie was not then in my service; I remember now that there was an accusation against the prisoner - a female servant in my house accused him of having stolen two guineas, or 2l.; I investigated the matter, and found no proof - I thought it extremely improbable, and dismissed it from my mind.

JANE THOMPSON
. I lived with Mr. Gull as housekeeper; I received 35l. from him; my husband was a captain in the West India service, and sailed in a vessel which has never been heard of - McKenzie had been in Mr. Gull's service, and he was at that time up from Scotland to get a situation; Mr. Gull gave him leave to be in the house, and the prisoner came to the house - I told him to stop and have a cup of tea with me after the family were gone; he said Mr. Gull sent him there to see McKenzie, who was there at tea - he said he did not know where to get a lodging, and I said he might stay in the house; the last time I saw my money was at one o'clock, on the 4th of August, when the landlord and his wife were at the house with four ladies - McKenzie came and knocked at the door, and asked if the prisoner was ready to go out; my money was at that time in a trunk in my room; I took it away at night, and put it there in the morning - the prisoner took a shirt to go up stairs; I went up to the room, and saw him sitting on the bed cutting his toe-nails - I retired from the room, and went up stairs with the ladies and the landlady to look at the house; the prisoner went into the room a second time - McKenzie said to him, "Are you not ready yet;" they then went out: about six o'clock I missed my money - no other person had been in the room but the prisoner; I found my two trunks tumbled about - the prisoner had seen me put my money in the trunk the day I received it; when he left the house he said he should not be long, but he never returned.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you permission from Mr. Gull to let any man sleep in the house? A. No, but I told him they were going to sleep there, and he never said they were or they were not - he said he would send a woman to sleep there; I will swear I told Mr. Gull that I was going to let the prisoner and McKenzie sleep in the house - he made no answer, or if he did, he made such an answer as no one could understand; I told Mrs. Gull I was going to pay a bill with the notes, but I paid it with some other money - I told her I was going to pay 20l. to a person in Regent-street, but I did not pay it out of the notes; there was no other person in the house, but the prisoner and McKenzie, the landlady, four ladies, and a little girl; a man came to the door for some linen. but he did not come in - the washer-woman was not in the house that day; I never said so, that I recollect - if I did say so before the Magistrate, it was a mistake; a man came after the furniture, but he came no further than the hall - I gave no warning when I went into the room, where the prisoner was cutting his toe nails; he was preparing to dress himself - his trousers were on; he came down into the kitchen, a minute or two afterwards; before that day he had dressed in the butler's pantry - he had slept in the room till he took the money, and then he never came again: his boxes were left in the house with his clothes and all his things - they were searched, but nothing was found; Mc Kenzie was taken up - he was acquitted and died in three days afterwards; I always said he was innocent.

MR. SHARPE. Q. On the morning of the robbery, the prisoner was in the house? A. Yes, at half-past eleven o'clock, in the room where the trunk and money were; no other person was in the room that day - he did not go out dressed - he left his shirt in the room.

COURT. Q. Did he see you put the money into the trunk? A. He saw me with the book in my hand that day; heknew the money was in one of the trunks - he saw me put it in on the 1st of August, in that same room; he had no further opportunity of knowing the money was in the trunk that morning, but seeing the pocket-book in my hand - when I was putting the trunks to rights, my keys were on a little table in the kitchen, and when he was gone, my trunks were still locked.

GEORGE CALLENDAR
. I am landlord of the house. I went there on the 4th of August, a little after twelve o'clock and stopped till near two; I was in the upper part of the house, looking over the furniture, a party came there who have since taken it, Mr. and Mrs. Macquin, my wife and Mrs. Thompson shewed them the house - Mrs. Thompson was on the parlour floor, and went up as high as the drawing-room; I went into the back parlour that day, but not at that time - I was there in the afternoon, between six and seven o'clock. and at Mrs. Thompson's request, I went into the room and saw the trunks - they were not in a particularly confused state.

MRS. CALLENDAR. I was at that house on the 4th of August, from nine o'clock in the morning till four o'clock in the afternoon; my laundress man came with the cart - he was the only person who called on my account.

HENRY BUCKEREDGE
. I am an officer. The prisoner was brought to the office; he said he lived in York-street. which I found to be the case: I went into the room in York-street, he said he had been to the Leith and Berwick wharf - that he had been on board the Sir William Wallace packet to see if a letter had been brought up for McKenzie, and he had seen the steward and the cook - I was then sent out, and returned about two o'clock; the prisoner then stated that he had eleven shillings or twelve shillings in his pocket - he said he had got nineteen shillings for a Scotch not which he had exchanged near the Haymarket, and bought a bottle of whiskey, paid some money to a green grocer, and a score to a man who lived in the Edgware-road; I calculated the whole together, and it was twentyfour or twenty-five shillings.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You say he told you where he slept? A. Yes; the robbery was committed on the Monday; he was on the wharf on the Tuesday - I searched his trunk, but found nothing belonging to the prosecutrix.

GEORGE MOSS
. I am clerk to the Leith and Berwick Smack Company. On the 5th of August, the prisoner came with another man to enquire if they could get Scotch notes for gold - I said the clerk who had the Scotch notes were not in the way, but just then Mr. Thompson came in, and I referred to him; the prisoner's companion went to him - the prisoner said nothing.
Cross-examined. Q. It was not asking gold for notes? A. No; Scotch notes for gold.
COURT. Q. You saw neither gold nor notes? A. No, I recommended them where they could get notes.

MR. PHILLIPS to MR. GULL. Q. Do you remember that woman telling you she was about to allow the prisoner and McKenzie to sleep in the house? A. She proposed to me that they should come to the house, and I said"That is a thing I by no means approve of;" I did not mumble that, she perfectly understood it, because the answer came immediately, "Very well, Sir," and on the same afternoon my house-maid went to ask whether the female servant whom I wanted to sleep with Jane Thompson, could not come - I expressed my disapprobation in a tone that she could not have avoided understanding, and she said, "Very well, Sir."
NOT GUILTY .

1817.
WILLIAM BENNETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
Joseph Bailey
, from his person .

JOSEPH BAILEY. I am a warehouseman , and live in Lad-lane. On the 30th of July, about four o'clock, I was in Goswell-street
; I felt a pull at my pocket - turned round, and saw the prisoner with my handkerchief in his coat - I had used it about two minutes before; I took hold of him, and he dropped it down; I took it up - I know it to be mine - it has my mark on it - I have made enquiry respecting his friends, and find they are very respectable.

JAMES CLIFFORD
. I am an officer. I was sent for and took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. There was a caravan at the corner of Sutton-street; the horse would not go on - there was a mob; I stopped where this gentleman turned round and accused me of taking his handkerchief, which I never had.
One witness gave the prisoner a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 14.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury -
Judgment Respited
.

1818.
HENRY BARNES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of September , 1 handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of
Henry Henman
, from his person .

HENRY HENMAN. I was sitting at the back of the Stratford coach, on the 6th of September, coming to town, when the officer called to me that I had lost my handkerchief - I felt my pocket, and it was gone; I did not see the prisoner till he was secured, in three or four minutes.(Property produced and sworn to.)

FRANCIS KEYS
. I am an officer. I saw the prosecutor riding on the coach - the prisoner got up behind, and I saw him put his left hand into his pocket, and take out the handkerchief; my brother officer went and stopped the coach - I took the prisoner to the watch-house with the handkerchief.
The prisoner handed in a petition, soliciting the clemency of the Court, and regretting the consequences of evil associates.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Whipped and Discharged.

1819.
WILLIAM RICKWOOD
and
JOSEPH HOPKINS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of August , 9 lbs. of mutton, value 5s. the goods of
Amelia Calder Stewart
.

CHARLES CROGGETT
. I am a watchman of Lissongrove. On the morning of the 3d of August, I was on duty, and saw the two prisoners about half-past five o'clock, standing together, opposite No. 13. Dorset-street - I watched them. and saw something pass into Rickwood's hands over the area rails, and they turned into a stable-yard which leads to Crawford-street; I pursued, and saw Rickwood throw down a piece of meat; I cried Stop thief! - they were stopped at the top of the mews by two men; I brought them back, and took up the meat, which was a leg of mutton and a small piece - I went to the area, and the person who had been there had made his escape - there was a ladder down the area.

JAMES HUNT
. I am housekeeper to Amelia Calder Stewart, of No. 13. Dorset-street
. I heard the cry of Stop thief! and looked out at the window - I saw the witness and the two prisoners come up to the house - I saw the ladder in the area, and missed a leg and a piece of mutton from the area.

ALFRED CRITCHER
. I am a coachman - I live exactly opposite the mews. I heard a cry of Stop thief! While I was washing a carriage, and saw the two prisoners coming along together - Rickwood was a little first, and Hopkins near him.

THOMAS CHINA
. I am a labourer. I heard a cry of Stop thief! - I stopped Rickwood, but did not see him have anything; he said "Let me go, it is not me that has done it, it is the other chap."
HOPKINS' Defence. They did not see me take anything - I ran after the other, and when there was a cry of Stop thief! I stopped to be taken.
RICKWOOD'S Defence. I heard the cry of Stop thief! and ran to see what was the matter.

RICKWOOD -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

HOPKINS -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Fourteen Days .
Fourth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1820.
HENRY CLAYTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , 1 watch, value 4l., 1 seal, value 6d., and 1 key, value 1d., the good of
William Gray
, from his person .

WILLIAM GRAY. I am a ship-carpenter . On the 1st of August I was standing at the end of Field-alley, Shadwell-market
, speaking to a ship-mate; I found the prisoner before me, who said some words which were unintelligible - he then made a grasp and took my watch; I seized him, but he got away - we pursued, and about fifteen yards before we came up with him, I heard something fall on the ground; we did not stop, but pursued and took him - we brought him back to where I heard something fall, and it was my watch.

JOHN SKUES
. I am a watchman. On the morning of the 1st of August I took the prisoner from Gray; he took me to the place, and there was this watch, I saw it picked up.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was coming up Cox's-lane, and heard a cry of Stop thief! this person caught hold of me.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1821.
THOMAS JOY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of August , 1 pocket-book, value 6d., 3 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the property of
Ann Davis
, from her person .

ANN DAVIS. I am a widow . On the 26th of August, I came to a public-house in Hornsey-road
with the prisoner and another person; we drank together at one table, and in the course of an hour I came away - the prisoner followed me out, and said he was coming my way; we walked a little way together, and he thought to take liberties in an improper way with me - I refused two or three times; he then threw me down on the ground, and took my pocket-book out of my pocket, with 3s. 6d. - there was a washing-bill in the pocket-book, and a bad shilling; he thrust his hand into my pocket, took them and got away - I pursued him to the public-house again, and he was sitting looking at some silver in his hand; I asked him for the money and pocket-book, he denied it several times, and out he rushed in a moment - I charged the watchman with him.

JAMES DENNIS
. On the 26th of August I was on duty in the Hornsey-road. I was called, and saw the watchman search the prisoner - he found 4 1/2d. in one of his pockets; I followed them to the watch-house, and saw the prisoner put his left hand behind him, take out this pocket-book, and throw into the road - I took it up, and asked the prisoner what he threw it there for - he said"He knew he threw it away; and not to ask him that foolish question;" I asked the prosecutrix if that was her's, and she said it was, and one of the strings she had sewn on it - I then asked the prisoner what he had done with the money; he said 1s. 6d. he had spent in the public-house - he did not appear tipsy.

FREDERICK SMITH
. I saw the prisoner throw something away, James Dennis picked it up, and the prosecutrix owned it: they were both sober.(Pocket-book produced sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 33.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1822.
THOMAS JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of August , 1 watch, value 6l.; 1 seal, value 18s.; 1 key, value 8s.; 1 ring, value 5s.; 1 slide, value 3s.; and 1 ribbon, value 6d., the goods of
John Dargie
, from his person .

JOHN DARGIE. I am a carpenter of the ship St. George; she was in the West India-dock. On the 27th of August I was in a street near Glass-house-fields
; I was not drunk, but I fell down - a man came and took hold of my arm, with a pretence to assist me; I told him I did not want any help - we walked about three paces, and he took his right hand from my left side, whipped the watch out of my pocket, and ran away immediately; I ran after him a little way, but soon lost sight of him, and soon after I saw the prisoner in custody - he is the man that was detained, and he is the size of the man that took my watch - I could swear to the colour of his coat; I cannot tell how long it was before I saw him in custody.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were you not quite drunk? A. I was as sensible as I am now; I felt the watch go out of my pocket - it was half-past ten o'clock: I had been at a public-house at Limehouse - I went there about four o'clock, but I did not stay there all the time; I was not exactly drinking from four till ten - I was not in any house of ill-fame, as far as I know; I was only in two houses - I cannot say what I drank or what I paid.
NOT GUILTY .

1823.
THOMAS WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of August , 1 brass cock, value 1s.; 1 saucepan. value 9d., and 1 pewter pot, value 1s., the goods of
Mary Aves
; 1 brass cock, value 1s., the goods of
John Neasmith
; 1 pewter pot, value 1s., the goods of
William
Cash
; and 1 bundle of rope-yarn, value 4s. , the goods of
Robert Elam
.

MARY AVES
. I live in Bateman's-row
, When I went to bed on the 1st of August, the water-cock, and saucepan, and other things were all safe in the yard; next morning they were all gone.(Property produced and sworn to.)

ELIZABETH NEASMITH
. I am the wife of John Neasmith. On the morning of the 2d of August we missed the water-cock from our premises, at No. 23, Bateman's-row.

WILLIAM CASH
. I am a publican. I sent this pint pot to Mr. Elam's house on the night of the 1st of August; I know it by my name on it.

ROBERT ELAM
. On the evening of the 1st of August I had this pint pot from Mr. Cash; it was in our ropeground under a shed, and in the morning it was gone, and a bundle of rope, which was about a yard from it.

JOHN PEACOCK
. I am a watchman. On Saturday morning, the 2d of August, between three and four o'clock, I stopped the prisoner with these articles in a bag; I have compared them to the places, they fit exactly.

JAMES HILL
. On the morning of the 2d of August, the prisoner was brought to the watch-house, with a bag, containing all these things; he gave no account of them - I have compared these cocks with the branch-pipe; they fit exactly.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going down Shoreditch, a young man was going along with these things; he said he felt very ill, and asked me to carry them for him - the watchman came and took me; he ran away.

JOHN PEACOCK
. There were two together, the prisoner and another, with this bag; I asked what it was - they said, "soot;" I felt it, and it was not - they then said it was soot and cinders, and if I would go home with them I should see it sifted; as we were going along the other ran away, and I seized the prisoner with the sack.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

1824.
JOHN WILSON
and
WILLIAM WILMORE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of July , 1 jacket, value 17s. , the goods of
John Nicholas
and
Simon Latter
.

The property belonging Sarah Nicholas and Simon Latter, the prisoners were
ACQUITTED .

1825.
JAMES TOONE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of August , 1 pair of boots, value 2s. , the goods of
Peter Thwaites
.

PETER THWAITES. I am a bootmaker , and live in Aylesbury-street, Clerkenwell
; the prisoner was my apprentice . On the 17th of August, about two o'clock, he was leaving my shop with some dirty linen; I searched his bundle, and found a pair of child's double soled boots; I asked him how he came to put them there - he said he had an order for them on the Sunday before, from a neighbour, I think he said, next door to him.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had he not before that sold two pairs of boots and shoes to a gentleman? A. He never took but one pair from me, by coming and saying he wanted a pair for a gentleman. I did not want to get his indentures cancelled - it was not because he was an apprentice from a school, and the consent of the Trustees was wanting, that I did not have it done; I do not know Mr. Hudson; the prisoner said he had a pair of boots ordered from him, and he was taking them to him.

HARRIET THWAITES
. I am the prosecutor's wife. I missed the boots from the stock.

JOHN ROBINSON
. I am a constable, and took up the prisoner. I asked him how he came to take them, and what he meant to do with the money - he said to spend it.
Cross-examined. Q. Was any one present at this conversation? A. Yes; it was in Mr. Thwaites' shop - he did not say he had got an order for them while I was there - I swore this before the Magistrate.

PETER THWAITES
. When I opened the bundle he gave me the account I stated, and then I went for an officer - the officer came in the mean time.

HARRIET THWAITES
. He said he had got an order for them, and was going to take the money and spend it.

Cross-examined. Q. Why did you not state that in your first examination? A. I was not called in at Hatton-garden; the officer has not been speaking to me since I went down - he was speaking, but not to me; I heard some one tell him to hold his tongue.
NOT GUILTY .

1826.
WILLIAM SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of August , 1 skittle-ball, value 4s. , the goods of
David Skivens
.

THOMAS OSBORNE. I am a shoemaker, and lodge at the sign of the Victory, near Hackney-road. On the evening of the 13th of August I saw the prisoner go out of the skittle-ground into the field; I spoke to Massingham, and he went after him; I saw him take a ball from him, and he said he was very sorry.

JAMES MASSINGHAM
. I am servant to Mr. Skiven, who keeps the Victory public-house, in Cambridge-street, Hackney-road
. Osborne gave me information - I came out, and saw the prisoner with this ball under his arm; I took it from him; he said, "Pray let me go - pray forgive me - this is the first thing I have done."

DAVID SKIVENS
. I am owner of the skittle-ground - this is my ball.

JOHN COOK
. I am an officer. I was sent for: the prisoner said he was very sorry.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he had a paralytic stoke, and which had partly deprived him of the use of his intellects.

JURY to MR. BARRETT (clerk of the papers). Q. Is there any truth in this statement? A. He has been much afflicted, and has been in the workhouse; I have not seen any change in him with respect to his faculties; but he has stated that he was better.
GUILTY. Aged 45.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1827.
JOHN RYAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of August , 1 pair of boots, value 1l. , the goods of
Edmund Matthews
and others.

GEORGE HENRY HUTCHINGS
. I am in the employ of Mr. Edmund Matthews and his partner. On the 23d of August I was standing in the shop, about ten minutes pastten o'clock in the evening; I saw the prisoner come and take a pair of boots off the door-post - I pursued, and never lost sight of him till I secured him; he threw the boots away in Middle-row, which is very light, and we have our eyes dazzled - Sullivan took up one of them.

DENNIS SULLIVAN
. I am porter to Messrs. Nicholls and Walters, ironmongers. I was standing talking to a fellow-servant about ten o'clock, and heard the cry of Stop thief! I saw the prisoner running, and went to seize him - he threw down this boot.

THOMAS McGRATH
. I took the prisoner into custody.(Boot produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was walking down Holborn, on the opposite side of the road; the prosecutor came and charged me with stealing the boots; I said he was mistaken in the person, and he acknowledged it at the office.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Confined Two Months .

1828.
ELIZA ROBERTS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of December , 2 sheets, value 9s.; 1 counterpane, value 3s.; 1 bolster, value 7s.; 1 pillow-case, value 1s.; 2 blankets, value 7s., and 2 candlesticks, value 2s. , the goods of
James Hale
.

MARY HALE
. I am the wife of James Hale. The prisoner lodged in my house on the 27th of December - she came in intoxicated, I helped her up stairs, and unlocked her door; I was going to put her to bed; I let down the bedstead, and missed the articles stated, which I had let to her with the room - I charged her with taking them; she said if I would he merciful to her I should lose nothing, but I have not seen the duplicates, nor got the things.

Prisoner. I left the room in November; my father-inlaw went to pay the rent, and was rather intoxicated; she said he had better stop there, and he did - he lived in the room, and lives there now. Witness. They came at two o'clock in the morning, very tipsy, and I missed the things.

GEORGE JUDGE
. I took up the prisoner, and told her she was charged with stealing these things; she said she had made away with them - that she sent them by another woman, and had made away with the tickets.
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Confined One Month .

1829.
JAMES PRESNALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 4 boots, value 26s. , the goods of
John Burt
.

JOHN BURT. I am a boot-maker . On the 20th of August, I was at the back part of my shop, and heard a noise at my door; I went out and saw my apprentice contending with the prisoner for a boot - he was knocked down by some other person, and the prisoner got away; I lost sight of him, for a short time, in turning a corner, but I am sure he is the man - my boots were picked up by different people.

RICHARD PINK
. I am apprentice to the prosecutor. I saw the prisoner running, with the boots in his hand, from the top step of our door; I ran to him, and struggled with him.

ALEXANDER RICHARDSON
. I saw the prisoner go and take the boots from off the door-post; he threw three away and kept one in his hand.

JOHN CUTHBERT
. I was coming down the Commercial-road, and assisted in taking the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going down the road and saw some persons; I went to see what was the matter, and they took me down to the watch-house, and brought two men to look at me, who said it was a stouter person - the night-officer said he must dismiss the case, and then there came in a man, who keeps an oil-shop, and he said he could fetch a person to swear to me; he fetched this little boy, who came and said he saw another person with them - he then fetched the apprentice, who said he caught me with the four boots under my arm, and when he took hold of me some person knocked him down - he then said he did not see me for a long time, not till I was taken to the watch-house.

RICHARD PINK
. No - I got up again directly; I was knocked down, and pursued him to Sydney-street - I am quite sure of him.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Confined Four Months .

1830.
THOMAS YALE NICHOLSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of July , 1 jacket, value 6s. , the goods of
Samuel Lumbus
.

SAMUEL LUMBUS. I am postilion to
William Lock
Esq. On the 26th of July, I was with the carriage, at the Opera; my jacket was under the seat, inside the carriage - my fellow-servant came and sung out that there was somebody at the carriage; I turned round on the saddle and saw the prisoner take something from the carriage - I got down, and my fellow-servant pursued him; he turned and I saw him throw down my jacket.

ROBERT ELLIOTT
. I was waiting with the carriage, at the Opera; I saw the prisoner with the jacket in his hand - I called out to my fellow-servant, who got off his horse; I pursued the prisoner, who threw it down.

HENRY HOWLEY
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and bring the jacket.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was charged with stealing a coat and some stockings, and when I was at Marlborough-street they brought this jacket, and swore to that which I am innocent of.
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Confined One Month .

1831.
ROBERT ALEXANDER MORTIMER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 1 truck, value 3l. , the goods of
Jacob Spurgen
.

JACOB SPURGEN. I am a wheelwright , and live in Bullyard, Gray's Inn-lane
. On Wednesday, the 20th of August, the prisoner came to hire my truck; I refused it to him, and some time after I missed it - I saw him on the Friday; I asked him when the truck was coming home; he said that night, but it did not come - on the Saturday I saw him; he said he had taken it home, but I took him - it had not been returned; when I asked him for it, he d-d, and said I might get it as I could.
Prisoner. I had hired the truck before. Witness. No- he never hired it in his life; I believe he had worked for me part of a day - I do not know when.

THOMAS McGRATH
. I am a watchman. I took charge of the prisoner on the 23d of August.

GEORGE FERGUSON
. I saw the prisoner that Wednesday night, in a house, in Bunhill-row; he said he had a truck for sale, and asked where he could sell it - I declined to do anything with it; and next morning I saw him going down Holborn with a truck; he spoke to me - I returned in an hour and a half, and he then took the truck and went away.
Prisoner. Q. What time were you in the Borough with me? A. I went to the Borough with him I think four weeks ago last Wednesday; he said it was on business for his master.

JOHN LEADBITTER
. I live near the prosecutor's shop. I saw the prisoner there on the 20th of August; he looked at the shop, went in and came out; went in again, and took the board of the truck into the shop - he then went and took the truck out of the yard.

Prisoner. Q. Have you not seen me before? A. Yes - I have seen you in Gray's Inn-lane; I never saw you in the house, nor the shop - I have seen him in the yard, and in the Bull public-house: I have to mind the shop while the men go to dinner - it was at dinner time I saw him.
Prisoner's Defence. In the deposition it was stated that I had hired the truck and was to pay 6s., and I did not return it; I had worked for him and hired the truck.
COURT to the PROSECUTOR. Q. Have you seen the truck. A. No, and when I asked the prisoner for it, he d-d me, and said I might get it as I could.

COURT to
THOMAS McGRATH
. Q. Did the prisoner say anything about the truck? A. No - Mr. Spurgen said if he would bring it home he would forgive him the hire of it.
GUILTY . Aged 48.
Confined Three Months .

1832.
MARY MOULD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of July , 6 lbs. weight of bacon, value 3s. , the goods of
Thomas Porter
.

CHARLOTTE PORTER
. I am the wife of Thomas Porter, he is a chandler , and lives in Baldwin's-gardens . On the 14th of July I lost a hock of bacon, it was found in the bed-room in the workhouse.

MARY ANN LEWIS
. I live with my father in the prosecutor's house - I was standing at the door when the prisoner went out with a piece of bacon under her arm; I did not know but that she had bought it.

CHARLES CARTER
. I am porter of the gate at St. Andrew's work-house - the prisoner was nurse of one of the wards; she went out on the 14th of July; I let her in, and in a few minutes the prosecutor came and asked to speak to her; I sent for her and the master - they asked about taking the bacon, she strongly denied it; the master sent me to search the ward, and I found it in the bed-room under the bed - the prosecutor swore to it.

WILLIAM KIRBY
. I am a constable. I received the bacon and the prisoner at the work-house; I kept it as long as I could, and then gave it up.

CHARLOTTE PORTER
. It was my property.
Prisoner's Defence. The gentlewoman is very wrong; she swore it had never been cut - I had half a peck of beans in Leather-lane, and a man offered me the bacon for half a crown.

COURT to
WILLIAM KIRBY
. Q. Did she say so at the office? A. No; she said she must be tipsy.
GUILTY . Aged 57.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1833.
PETER MACGENNIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of July , 1 pair of trousers, value 9s. , the goods of
Thomas Jones
.

THOMAS JONES. I am a tailor , and live in St. John-street-road
. On the 26th of July, about ten o'clock at night, the prisoner came in to purchase a waistcoat - I was measuring another person at the time, to alter a pair of trousers for him, they then lay on the counter; I sold the prisoner the waistcoat at a low price - and when he was gone, my wife told me he had something in his hat; I jumped over the counter, took hold of him, and asked what was in his hat; he said an old waistcoat; I took his hat off, and under an old waistcoat was my trousers; he dropped on his knees, and offered me five shillings to let him go.

SARAH JONES
. I am the wife of Thomas Jones. I saw the prisoner take the trousers from the counter and drop them at his feet; he then put them into his hat and something over them.

WILLIAM CHAPMAN
. I was coming past the house on the 26th of July, and saw the prosecutor with the prisoner by the collar - I took him to the watch-house, and found ten shillings on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I went and bought the waistcoat; I know nothing about the trousers: I took my coat and waistcoat off; and laid them on the ground to try the waistcoat on.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Confined Three Months .

1834.
HENRY KEMP
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of August , 1 ham, value 8s. , the goods of
Isaiah Cox
.

WILLIAM GREVILLE
. I am shopman to Mr. Isaiah Cox. On the 4th of August I was standing in his shop, which is a cheesemonger's; and saw a ham move, I was at that time at our third window - some persons told me there was a ham taken from the door; I went out, and saw the prisoner in the middle of the street with a bundle - I went up to him and he dropped the ham; I took it up and pursued - a person attempted to stop him, he fell down, and I collared him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

WILLIAM TRANTER
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner and produce the ham; this is the handkerchief which was round it.
Prisoner's Defence. It is the first time.

COURT to
WILLIAM GEEVILLE
. Q. Was the ham in the handkerchief? A. Not when he dropped it; I am sure he is the person I saw with the ham, but I do not think he stole it - he seemed as if he was urged by some person to make his exit; I saw him drop it in three or four minutes after; I saw it move in the shop.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined One Month .

1835.
EDWARD JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of August , 24 yards of cloth, value 24s. , the goods of
Robert Watt
.

ELIZABETH WATT
. I am the wife of Robert Watt, linen-draper , of Crawford-street, Marylebone
. On the 22d of August a little girl came and told me something was taken from the door - our young woman ran after the prisoner and cried Stop thief! he was brought back with the cloth; I then missed it from the door - I had seen it about half an hour before.

SARAH CANNON
. I saw the man take it from the door; he told me not to tell; they ran away with it; I did not see the prisoner stopped; I saw him when he was taken, in about a quarter of an hour.
COURT. Q. What did the prisoner do? A. The other man gave him this cloth - it was the other told me not to tell.

JAMES SPARKS
. I took this cloth and the prisoner in York-street, about two hundred yards from Mr. Watt's shop - he was running with it.
Prisoner. Q. Did you take me with the cloth? A. No; he threw it down just before I took him; the young woman took it up, and gave it me in the shop.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. A man asked me to carry a bundle, and he gave it into my hands - we turned up Crawford-street; I heard the cry, and thought there was something wrong - I threw down the bundle and ran; I said a man gave it to me to carry.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Seven Years .

1836.
HANNAH JORDAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of July , 5 yards of printed cotton, value 5s.; 1 bed-gown, value 1s., and 1 towel, value 6d. , the goods of
James Sullivan
.

MARGARET SULLIVAN
. I am the wife of James Sullivan, I am in service. On the 21st of July I travelled with the prisoner from Reading to London, and had these articles with me - the prisoner recommended me to her daughter in Crown-court, Soho
- I found her a very nice woman; I laid down on the bed, and when I awoke I found the prisoner and the things gone.

JAMES WALLIS
. I am a pawnbroker. I produce this print and towel pawned by the prisoner on the 21st of July for five shillings.

FRANCIS MACE
. I took the prisoner; this gown was found somewhere on her by the watch-house-keeper's wife.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. She was passed to Maidenhead, and had a bundle - she took out what she wanted; my husband was with us; she brought her bundle and my husband's bundle to my son-in-law's house; I then asked her for the things and I pawned them, and gave her 1s. 6d.; she had her breakfast, dinner, and tea out of it; she lent me the night-gown to put on in the waggon as it was cold.

MARGARET SULLIVAN
. I had lent her some money, and she returned me 1s. 6d. out of it.
GUILTY . Aged 36.
Confined Three Months .

1837.
JAMES HEWETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of August , 1 coat, value 12s.; 1 waistcoat, value 3s.; 2 shirts, value 9s.; 1 box, value 2d.; 1 sovereign, and 4 half-crowns , the property of
George White
.

GEORGE WHITE. I sell vegetables . On the 23d of August, I went out at twenty-minutes after six o'clock in the morning for some potatoes - I locked my door, and shut my shutters; I left my key inside my door, which goes with a spring lock; when I came home, in three quarters of an hour, I found the door and shutters as I left them; I found my box broken open, and this property gone; I had seen all safe that morning in my box; the prisoner is a lodger of mine - I have never seen my property since, my wife was out of town.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. It was a spring lock, and you left the key inside; how did you expect to get in? A. I had one key in my pocket; I cannot tell why I left the other key in the door - there was a pane of glass broken; I had no other lodger - I did not leave the key near the broken pane, for him to put his hand in and take it; I met him in the street about half an hour afterwards, and gave charge of him.
STOTHARD. I am an officer. I took up the prisoner, but found nothing on him.
NOT GUILTY .

1838.
SARAH HATCH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of July , 1 shawl, value 17s. , the goods of
John Elliott
.

JOHN ELLIOTT. I am a pawnbroker . I lost a shawl on the 5th of July, the prisoner came to the shop - I took her duplicate up stairs to get the articles she wanted, and at the same time I looked for a shawl in the name of Dixon; I came down, and found my apprentice looking for a shawl which he had lost from the counter - I asked who he had served, and he said Mrs. Hatch - I went after her, and found a wrapper which had been round the shawl, but the shawl is lost.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. How long have you known the prisoner? A. Five years, as a customer - I have always had a very good opinion of her; my apprentice is not here - he served her while I was up stairs; I had gone for another shawl - she took away four or five parcels; I was not there when she went out, and do not know that she took them in her bag; I had sent to her house before - I sent there to ask if she had not by mistake got something that did not belong to her; I thought it was a mistake; the person I sent met her, and saw her before I did - it is generally the case, that when a person receives anything they wrap it in a wrapper.

SOPHIA DIXON
. I went to the shop for a shawl - it was held up by the boy; the prisoner was in the box before me, and she said "Stop till I have got my things, and you shall have my place;" I went up, and my shawl was not to be found.

Cross-examined. Q. You saw the shawl held up? A. Yes - the prisoner had a bag, and took five parcels - I went to her house with the witness, after the man had been sent with the message - she had time to have put anything away; I asked if she had not taken a shawl in mistake - she brought down her pledges, and shewed them to me, and there was the wrapper of my shawl.
NOT GUILTY .

1785.
JOHN MANN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of July , 4 lbs. weight of brass, value 3s., belonging to
Kensington Lewis
, and fixed to a certain building; against the Statute .

CHARLES CAMANI
. I am a porter in the employ of Mr. Kensington Lewis, of St. James'-street, Piccadilly, inthe parish of St. James'
. On the night of the 31st of July, when I went to shut up the shop, this brass was on the railing, and in the morning I missed it; I saw it again at Marlborough-street; I fitted it to the place - it fitted-exactly.

JOHN CAIN
. I was on duty about half-past three o'clock in the morning in question - I saw the prisoner removing this brass - I went up to him, and he went away; I waited - he came again, and began again to take it up; I sprung my rattle, and he ran off, but we pursued and took him at the corner of Bury-street.

WILLIAM THOMPSON
. I assisted in taking the prisoner; I compared the brass - it fitted exactly.

THOMAS GOOK
. I received charge of the prisoner, and fitted the brass to the rails.
Prisoner. It was extreme poverty that drove me to it- I had no food for two days before.
GUILTY . Aged 60.
Transported for Seven Years .

1839.
JAMES SLAUGHTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of July , 4 metal cocks, value 5s , the goods of
William Atkinson
, his master.

WILLIAM ATKINSON. I am a tinman and brazier ; the prisoner was in my employ. On the 7th of July, about half-past seven o'clock in the evening, I had three cocks on the shelf, and the next morning they were gone; I saw them again on the Saturday following.

MARGARET BARBER
. I bought these cocks on the Monday evening of a young man - I do not know who.

MAURICE NICHOLAS
. I took up the prisoner on the 12th of July; I received these three cocks of Mr. Atkinson - the prisoner said he had stolen these three cocks, and sold them to Barber, and another he had sold to Burley.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Six Months .

1840.
GEORGE CAMPBELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of July , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Charles Bott
, from his person .

CHARLES BOTT. I lost a handkerchief on the 1st of July, which I had in my pocket in the early part of the day; I did not miss it till the officer told me I had been robbed - this was about half-past nine o'clock, in Berkeley-square
- the prisoner was taken about twenty yards from me.

JOHN LACY
. I am an officer. I was on duty in Piccadilly; I saw the prisoner and another follow the prosecutor and a lady: they went on, and sat down on a step- I walked down Hay-hill, and saw them again following the prosecutor; and near a gas-light, I saw the prisoner draw a handkerchief from the prosecutor, and put it under his coat; I ran over to cut him off from Lansdownpassage; he then turned round, and went round the inside of the square, near the rails - I ran and took him; the handkerchief had dropped a little before he came to the dark part of the square; I then went back to the place where I saw the handkerchief fall, but it was gone, and has not been seen since; I am quite sure the prisoner took it from the pocket.

Prisoner's Defence. I went to get a drop of water from the pump; he came and said I had got the handkerchief.
NOT GUILTY .

1841.
CHARLES KEYS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of July , 1 necklace, value 6s., the goods of
John Crook
, from the person of
Ellen Crook
, spinster
.

ELIZABETH OSBORNE
. On the 16th of July, I was in the service of Mr. John Crook, of Brunswick-place, City-road; his daughter Ellen is three years old; I was out with her - I went in a crowd to show her some music; she had a necklace on: the officer told me it was taken off her neck by Keys.

PHILIP PARISH
. I saw the prisoner take the necklace off the child's neck; I laid hold of him, and took it out of his hand.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was going up to Old-street-road
, and saw these beads on the ground; I stopped a quarter of an hour to hear a fiddler, and the officer took them from my hand.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Confined Three Months .

1842.
JOHN THOMPSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of August , 4 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
John Marsden
, from his person .

JOHN MARSDEN. I lost my money on the 25th of August, about half-past twelve o'clock at noon, from my trousers pocket; I had been at work close by, and went to a field to get my dinner - I laid down on the grass, and fell asleep- I did not see it taken.

JANE HAYES
. My husband and I went to look out at our window, and saw the prisoner lying down on the right side of the prosecutor - he passed his hand several times across his body, took something from his right hand trousers pocket, and put it into his own waistcoat pocket; my husband went down, and took the prisoner just as he was rising from him - I saw 2s. 6d. taken from his pocket.

ANN SMITH
. I heard Mr. Hayes go down; I went out, and saw the prisoner taking something from the prosecutor- I saw him taken, and he threw something away; I went to the place, and picked up two shillings.

THOMAS BOLTON
. I was at work close by. and saw the prisoner and another loitering about the field nearly three hours - I did not see him take anything, but I heard the cry of Stop thief! I ran and took the prisoner just as the prosecutor got up - the prisoner took 2s. 6d. from his pocket into his hand; we had hard work to get his hand open - officer was forced to hit his knuckles.

GEORGE ADAMS
. I am an officer. I saw the prisoner and the witnesses - I came up to them; I took him to Worship-street, and searched him, but found nothing; I saw his hand was clenched when we took him - he would not open his hand, and I threw him down, and threw myself upon him; I beat his hand with my staff till he did open it- there were two shillings and one sixpence in it; the prosecutor swore to the sixpence.

JOHN MARSDEN
. There is a punch on the reverse side of this sixpence, by which I know it - it was all in my pocket when I went to sleep.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Six Months .

1843.
JOHN BROTHERTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of August , 3 brass locks, value 1s.; 8 brass knobs, value 8d., and 7 brass plates, value 4d. , the goods of
Samuel Ames
.

SAMUEL AMES. I am a furniture broker , and live at Islington
. On the 2d of August I lost the property stated, which I had seen safe about two o'clock that afternoon - they were taken from a place in my warehouse; the prisoner was in my service as porter for a fortnight - these are my articles; here are locks, knobs and plates - they had been in my tool box.

JANE GORDON
. I am servant to the prosecutor: he told me to watch the prisoner; I saw him take these things from a place where they were concealed, and put them into his trousers pocket.

THOMAS COOPER
. I am an officer. I was sent for, and took the prisoner; I found these articles in his trousers pocket.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 31.
Transported for Seven Years .
SEVENTH DAY. THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 18.
First Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1841.
ROBERT JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of July
, 1 watch, value 10l; 3 rings, value 12s.; 1 bag, value 8s.; 1 pair of boots, value 8s.; 3 books, value 6s.; 3 rows of beads, value 4s.; 1 scent-box, value 3s.; 1 pin, value 1s.; 1 umbrella, value 5s., and 1 thimble, value 6d. , the goods of
George Cooper
; and
GEORGIANA BAXTER
was indicted for
receiving, on the same day, the same goods, knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute .

GEORGE COOPER. I am a builder , and live in Gloucester-place, Portman-square. I carry on business as a pawnbroker in Suffolk-street
, in the Borough - Jones was in my service at the pawn-shop; he absconded about three o'clock on the 27th of July - he did not say he was going; I only heard of it from the boy - I did not see him again till he was taken up; the day after he was gone, I missed a gold watch, chain, key, and some other things - I knew nothing of Baxter, but I went to where she was living, on Sunday, the 27th of July; I told her I had come about the watch - that she was very well aware of the business - that she knew as much about it as I did, or perhaps rather more, and I wished her to give me some information about the watch; she said if I went home and made myself easy, it should be returned the next morning by nine o'clock - I asked where it had been pawned; she said at Baxter's: after a good deal of conversation, I said I could not fancy, or believe it would be returned on the Monday; as I thought if there was a disposition to return it, it would have been returned on the Sunday morning; she said she had got a watch herself in pawn, for thirty guineas, and she went to get the duplicate - while she was gone, I sent Probert (who was with me) for an officer; when she returned, she said "Mr. Cooper, take care what you are about, I am a married woman, I shall have no intruders here;" I went to her lodgings - she went by the name of Baxter, but we had understood her name to be Thornton; she was denied as Mrs. Thornton, but while Probert was at the door, she came down stairs - I then went up, and she desired us to walk up stairs; when we got half-way up, she desired us to wait - she went into a drawing-room and shut the door; in a few minutes she opened it and admitted us - this is the watch, chain and seal; I know this ring to be my property - it was at another pawnbroker's; I sent for an officer, and we told Baxter she had better give up Jones; she said she knew nothing of him - the officer said "We must look into this room;" she said "There is nothing there, nor no one there" she denied us admittance for three or four minutes; she then opened the door and went in, and said"Robert, Robert, come forth, and shew yourself like a man;" the door was opened, but the bird was flown: Jones was not there, but we saw his clothes lying about the floor - he had escaped out of the window, the lead flat - I knew the clothes to be what he had worn in my service; we searched the house - he was at last found by an officer, and brought in while I was waiting for him; when he came in, he took some money out of his pocket and gave it to Baxter, saying "This money is yours" - I said to him "This carpet-bag is mine;" he said "It is yours, Sir"- they were then taken to the office, and the next morning were brought up for examination - while they were waiting, Baxter said to the officer "Can't we settle this thing?"

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What relation are you to Jones? A. His mother is my first cousin - I known him from his infancy; he managed the business of that shop; but since March last I have declined taking in pledges - Mr. Goddard was my partner, but he died in January, 1827; his executors have no claim on the proceeds of the trade - I have a claim on them - the accounts are still open - I do not know of my own knowledge when this watch was pawned, but this is the duplicate of it - it was written by my foreman, who is not here - I have not made any exertion to get him here; the watch might have been pawned when Mr. Goddard was in partnership with me - I cannot of my own knowledge tell how long this ring has been in my shop, that might have been when Mr. Goddard was my partner - I told the prisoner he might use this carpet bag to put his clothes in; here are three books I charge him with stealing; they were pledges, but I did not take them in; they might have been there in Goddard's time - Jones had not pawned them himself, for they were there before he came into my service; I had seen them with other books, and I had taken these books down to look at; I attend at the shop sometimes - I had looked at these books in 1827 - it is Kenilworth; I do not know whether there is another edition of it in my shop - these were pawned for 5s. - I have not the duplicate here, it is only from recollection I speak - the copy I saw may have been redeemed.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. You went to Baxter's lodging and found her at home? A Yes. I believe Jones was there, by seeing his clothes - the books were on the piano-forte. Mr. Cameron's shopman brought the watch; Jones lived in the house which these things were taken from - I was only there occasionally, but he slept there - he never gave orders; I directed an elderly woman who was there to provide for the house - I did not know till afterwards that Baxter used to come and dine there - it was not with my knowledge or consent - she told me that the watch should come home next day.

THOMAS PROBERT
. I was journeyman to Mr. Cooper, in Suffolk-street; I know this watch - I have seen it at Mr. Cooper's several times - the last time was in September,1827 - I left Mr. Cooper's before Jones came; I did not return because Mr. Cooper left off taking in pledges, and did not want me - I believe this umbrella to be Mr. Cooper's - it was in pawn - I know it by the head - I went with Mr. Cooper to Baxter's, on the 27th of July; she passed by the name of Thornton at the place where she had lived - I have seen her once or twice at Mr. Cooper's when I have called there - the place we went to was No. 17, Craven-buildings, Drury-lane - I know this comeo ring; Jones told me it was his, that he had bought it, and I pawned it for him with some other things - I do not remember the day; he asked me the favour, as he had not time to go and pawn it himself.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you ever seen it in the shop before? A. Yes, he used to wear it; I saw him wear it about a month, and any one might see it - I should not have pawned it if I had not thought it had been his own - I have taken out this umbrella on a wet day - I lived at Mr. Cooper's nine months - he did not know much of the business - there was one man and a lad there; the foreman and I have had goods on trust, and entered them in the day-book, but not without Mr. Cooper's knowledge - I have bought articles of wearing apparel, or anything I wanted; I have seen this ring several times in the shop before Jones wore it - I have taken it in myself.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. You say you have seen this woman, and called her Thornton? A. I have heard Jones call her so; he told me her name was Thornton - that was not when she was pawning anything: she was in the parlour; Jones and the servant were there, but Mr. Cooper was not - I never saw her have any coffee or dinner - she had no acquaintance with Mr. Cooper; I did attend at Bow-street - the Magistrate said, at the first examination, that he thought the case could not he made out, without admitting Baxter as a witness; I do not know that I ever called her Thornton myself.

HENRY POWELL
. I am assistant to Mr. Cameron, pawnbroker, of the Strand - I took in the watch of Baxter, on the 18th of July, in the name of Baxter, No. 6, Friar-street; I remember her perfectly well.

WILLIAM BAZANT
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in the Borough, in the employ of Mr. Kirkham. On the 16th of July this ring was pawned at our shop; but the young man who took it in has left.

THOMAS PROBERT
. It was there I pawned the ring. I

JANE BRAIN
. I am a widow, and live in Holborn. This gold watch, chain, and seal are mine - I sent my daughter, whose name is Steele, to pawn them at Mr. Cooper's; my daughter is not here: I sent it twelve months ago, in February last - I saw it at Mr. Cooper's shop last February, when I renewed it.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You have not seen it since, and the person you sent is not here? A. No.

HENRY SMITH
. I am apprentice to Mr. Cooper. I have seen Baxter at the shop; she used to pawn in the name of Thornton, but at home she went by the name of Baxter.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Is anything more common than for persons who come to pawn things, to give a name that does not belong to them? A. No - I knew her name was Baxter, and knew where she lived; she came to see Jones there - Jones used to be master in the shop; when Baxter came there she used to have tea sometimes, by his invitation, and sometimes by the servant's- we did not call Jones master; I have carried letters to her from him; if he trusted her with a gold watch, she could not know but that it was his own.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did not Mr. Cooper occasionally lend him articles to were? A. No - he did wear them, but not by Mr. Cooper's knowledge.

MR. COOPER. After Jones had left, there were some duplicates found in a pocket-book in his box; I saw them found - they do not relate to any of these articles, but when people come to redeem an article, they bring a duplicate, and the two duplicates are pinned together; that shows me that a certain sum of money has been received, and these show me that he has not accounted for the money - I found this letter on the back counter, in his hand-writing - it is addressed to me, and signed by himself.

Honoured Sir, - My conscience will not allow me to look my benefactor in the face, since I have behaved so villainous to one who has been a father to me; the reason for my absconding is, that I have worn a gold watch in the name of Steel, and I have had it stolen from me by a woman whom I have loved. Adien, dear Sir, I remain your unhappy and wretched slave R. Jones.
N. B. By the time you receive this I shall be numbered with the dead; I have borrowed 2l. from the till, which my brother will pay for me.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Then you got from this document the knowledge that he had borrowed a watch? A. Yes; I never lent him that or anything else to wear; I never saw him wear a watch or anything that was in pawn in the shop; he had a watch of his own, I believe - he said it was his; I did not see him with one when he came into my service - he might have one: I cannot tell how long it was before I saw him wear one; when he came into my service he was in humble circumstances - I think it was a common metal watch, a dirty yellow colour - I think I have seen it.

Q. Have you any doubt of it, when you have just sworn to the colour of it? A. I think I have seen it; I was not sure, but he might have had a watch of his brother's - he may have had a watch; I think I recollect his brother lending him a watch - I did not swear he told me the watch was his own; here is one gold watch-hook - it is one of a pair: I received it from his brother.

JAMES MATTHEWS
. I am a patrol of Bow-street. I went to No. 17, Craven-buildings, Drury-lane - I found Baxter in the drawing-room with Mr. Cooper who said he had sent for the officer on a charge of felony - he stated that a gold watch had been taken away from his premises, and he supposed Jones was there, and had got it; Baxter denied having anything to do with the watch, but, after a little conversation, she produced the duplicate- I told her I must search the bed-room; she refused me at first; I then heard the window go up - she then opened the door herself, but did not say anything at that time; that had been before I went, I suppose - she only said he was not on the premises; I searched, and found the bed-room window open - I looked out on the leads, but there was no person there; I went round Wych-street to stop the person from coming out, as he must have gone without a coat and hat, but I could not find him - Mr. Cooper thensent my brother officer to some other places, and he went on the adjoiniug houses, and at length found Jones in a cellar.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. How was he dressed? A. He had no coat or hat on - I have no doubt of his having been in bed there. Baxter at first denied it, but she gave us the duplicate soon after - in searching the premises the second time I found a pocket-book of Baxter's, and part of a gold watch-hook in it; I did not know whose book it was, but she asked me if I had found a pocket-book; I said Yes, and she said there was a watch-hook in it belonging to Mr. Cooper.
MR. COOPER. I found the duplicate of a watch-hook in the drawer.

WILLIAM JONES
. I am an officer. I went with Matthews, on the 27th of July, to these premises; I saw Baxter - she denied having any knowledge of the watch, but afterwards gave up the ticket; we went in to the room, and found the window open, but Jones was gone - these two rings I found in a red box, in a chest of drawers in the front room, and this ring was in another part of the room - this carpet bag was in the back room and these boots; I found Jones in a cellar - I think he had shoes on; I found these rows of beads in the drawers - a scentbox and a thimble in different parts of Baxter's room; she said they were her own - I found this umbrella in the back room, against the fire-place.
MR. COOPER. I cannot swear to these things.

THOMAS PROBERT
. I can swear to these beads by the private-mark on them, but not to these rings; I know this scent-box, it was in the window for sale.
Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. What may be the value of these beads? A. About 4s. - I never saw such a scent-box as this before; I have been some years at a pawnbroker's.

HENRY SMITH
re-examined. Q. Do you know these boots? A. Yes, Jones brought them from the shop - they were in pawn for 4s, and he had them repaired.

JONES' Defence. My cousin having allowed me the privilege of drawing things from the warehouse, I took the liberty of wearing this watch; and I took the liberty of drawing money, provided I accounted for it; the cameo ring, I can assure you, I purchased of the person who used to pawn it, and I gave 12s. for it - Sarah Gibbs was in the shop at the time, and Smith came in soon afterwards; Mr. Gray can swear to seeing it on my finger - I told him what I gave for it; he doubted whether I had not given more, and he inquired of the housekeeper, who said I gave 12s. for it - the umbrella I have not paid for, but I was in the habit of having things, and entering them in the day-book; and, provided I accounted for them, Mr. Cooper never denied me anything; the boots are what Smith said just now, they were never Mr. Cooper's - I bought them in the shop; the watch I had worn I suppose five months- Mr. Cooper must have seen it, as he frequently asked me what it was o'clock, and I have taken it out.
BAXTER'S Defence. I was in the habit of going to the place - I thought it was his own property; I ate and drank there - I pawned the watch.

WILLIAM GRAY
. I am independent - I know Jones; I recollect his shewing me this ring - I afterwards asked Gibbs about it, and she said she saw him give 12s. for it; I have frequently seen him wear it when in Mr. Cooper's employ - there did not appear any concealment about it; he was in the habit of wearing a gold watch - there was no concealment about that; this is not the watch - it was a gold repeating watch; it was nothing like a dirty yellow; Mr. Cooper could have seen it.

MR. ADOLPHLS. Q. Did he not go about like a gentleman? A. He used to go very genteel - I called in one night, and he asked me to sing; Baxter was there; and the housekeeper objected to there being any singing, as Mr. Cooper would not like it.

BENJAMIN HONEYSIDE
. I am a smith, and live in Friar-street. I have known Jones three or four months - I have known Baxter two years and a half; she lodged in my house as a married woman, with a young man, not Jones, and she left me on the 19th of July - I have seen her wear this watch in public company.

JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

BAXTER -
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1845.
WILLIAM FRYER
and
ROBERT FINCH
were indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of August , 2coats, value 4l. the goods of
Edward Driver
.

DAVID BAILEY
. I am servant to Mr. Edward Driver, of Richmond-terrace. On the night of the 4th of August, I was in Grafton-street
with my master's carriage - I fell asleep, and on my awaking I missed two coats from the box.(Property produced and sworn to.)

WILLIAM CRAIG
. I am a Bow-street patrol. I got these coats from the Collisium-tap, from the place they call the Shades: I saw Fryer sitting there, and the coats near him: I asked how he got them; he said he knew nothing about them.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How long before had you been in the tap-room? A. About three minutes- there were six or seven people there; I did not see Fryer were either of the coats, nor touch them; and he said he knew nothing about them.

JAMES RICE
. I keep the Collisium-tap. On the night of the 4th of August, I saw the two prisoners there - they were not together, but Finch had a sort of surtout coat on, with red about it; I was busy at the time - there were a good many people there.

JOHN GILBERT
. I am in the employ of Mr. Rice. I saw the prisoner come at different times in at the door; Fryer had a plain close bodied coat on as he has now; I did not notice the other man; I did not see any great coat.
NOT GUILTY .

1846.
JAMES PITHER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of July , 1 ass, price 30s. , the property of
Joseph Henry Bedford
.

JOSEPH HENRY BEDFORD. I lost an ass about the 29th of July, from Longford, near Colnbrook
; it had been in the field - I cannot exactly say the day I missed it; I found it in the possession of a man on the 19th of August- I am sure it was mine.

THOMAS BROWN
. I shewed the ass to the prosecutor - I was going to Windsor for a load of bones; I passed his place and he claimed it - I bought it of Harris about a month before.

JAMES HARRIS. I sold the ass to Brown one Saturday but I cannot tell what month - it was when beans and peas were in; I bought it of the prisoner and another young man on a Friday, as I was coming to Smithfield; I cannot tell which took the money.

JAMES SMITH
. I took Harris into custody - he told me where Pither was, but I do not know where the other is.

JOHN MILLS
. I saw the bargain between Harris and Brown - it was one Saturday in July; I cannot tell what day of the moth.
NOT GUILTY .

1847.
ELIZABETH KLEAVER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , 1 looking-glass, value 2s.; 1 bolster, value 8s., and 1 blanket, value 2s. , the goods of
John Moorecraft
.

SARAH MOORECRAFT
. I am the wife of John Moorecraft, a carpenter - we live at Somer's-town
; these articles were part of the furniture of a room let to the prisoner on the 15th of July - on the 23d of August I missed them, and charged her with it; she said, she would replace them, - I said, if she would in five days, I would forgive her; but before that time, she was taken for another offence.

WILLIAM CRUSH
. I am a pawnbroker of Somer's-town; I produce these articles which were all pawned by the prisoner at different times - she has had a good character for the last twelve months.

RICHARD COOPER
. I am a constable. I took up the prisoner for another charge, and found the duplicates on her.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded distress, and received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 48.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1848.
ELEANOR MURPHY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of July , 1 watch, value 20s.; 2 seals, value 7s.; 1 watch key, value 1s.; 2 rings, value 10s., and 2 sovereigns, the property of
Robert Wildman
, from his person .

ROBERT WILDMAN. I am a rope-maker . On the evening of the 15th of July, I went with the prisoner to a house in Bluegate-fields
