; we went to bed, and I laid till morning - she was gone when I awoke, and I missed my watch and money; I am sure I had them when I went to bed - I put my watch in my hat, and put it into the cupboard; there was a ring on my finger which was taken off - my money was in my trowsers pocket, which I put into the cupboard; this is my watch.
Prisoner. He gave me the watch in my possession, knowing me for many years; we were brought up children together. Witness. I did not give it her to keep.

HENRY HINKIN
. I am a cordwainer. The prisoner bought a pair of boots of me on the 16th of July - she gave me a sovereign, and I gave her change.

WILLIAM JEFFERY
. I received this property from my father, who is dead.
NOT GUILTY .

1849.
RICHARD CLINKAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of August , 1 watch, value 30s.; 1 seal, value 15s., and 1 key, value 10s. , the goods of
Frederick Miller
.

MARY MILLER
. I am the wife of Frederick Miller, and live at Somer's-town. On the afternoon of the 16th of August, I went out to get some flour; the prisoner came into the shop where I was, and from there he crossed and went into mine - I saw him goacross my shop, and into the parlour where I had left my watch; I did not see him take it, but crossed directly - I missed it, and detained him; I accused him of having been into my room - he denied it, but I found the watch in his bosom.

WILLIAM BATTAN
. I am an officer; I was called in to take the prisoner in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 10.
Whipped and Discharged.

1850.
JAMES BARKER
&
WILLIAN JOHNSON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of July , 1 coat, value 2l.; 1 waistcoat, value 15s.; 1 handkerchief, value 2s.; 1 pair of spectacles and case, value 15s.; 1 prayer-book, value 6s.; 1 knife, value 6s., 1 comb, value 2s., and 1 ink bottle, value 4d. , the goods of
Joseph Webb
.

JOSEPH WEBB. I am a cooper , and live in Clerkenwell
. In consequence of information I received, I looked and missed my coat, waistcoat, silk handkerchief, spectacles, and some other little things which had been in my waistcoat pocket - I had seen them all safe in the afternoon before, and before eight o'clock that morning, Dismore told me they were gone - the coat and waistcoat are lost; these spectacles and these little articles are mine - this pocket-book I can swear to; it was in my waistcoat pocket.

THOMAS DISMOME
. I live with my father in Clerkenwell; he is a jeweller. On the 29th of July, I saw a person get out of Mr. Webb's parlour window; he ran off - he appeared to have a black coat and a handkerchief under his arm - I told Mr. Webb; I saw the prisoners at Hatton-garden the same day - Barker had a similar dress on to the person I saw; but I could not see his face.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. It was not Johnson then? A. No. I never saw him till he was at Hatton-garden.

ELIZABETH WARD
. I saw the prisoners between seven and eight o'clock on the morning of the 29th of July, lurking about Mr. Webb's premises, which are only two doors from ours; I did not see them run away.

THOMAS GROVES
. I am a watchman. I heard of the robbery - I went on the 31st of July, and saw the two prisoners together about fifty yards from me; they saw me - Barker ran away, but Johnson did not - I took Johnson; I found these spectacles, pocket-book, knife, and comb, upon him.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did Johnson know you were an officer? A. I do not know; but Barker did.

JAMES ROBINSON
. I was with Groves; we went up Aylesbury-street, and saw the prisoners - when we came near them, Barker ran, I pursued him up John-street, and took him; I found 2s. and an old handkerchief on him.

BARKER'S Defence. I was not up that way at all that morning; I had been for some tea and sugar - as I was coming back these gentlemen met me; one of them put his fist up and was going to hit me - I ran to the top of Aylesbury-street; they called Stop thief! and I stopped directly.
JAMES ROBINSON. He did not stop till he was knocked into a public-house by a man, and then I took him.
The prisoners received a good character.

BARKER -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

JOHNSON -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined Three Months .

1851.
JANE GIBBONS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of September , 1 purse, value 6d.; 3 half-crowns; 2 shillings, and 4 half pence , the property of
Elizabeth Collins
.

ELIZABETH COLLINS. I live in Crown-court, Strand
. On the 7th of September, this money was all in a purse, on the table, in the lower room, when I went upstairs; a little after eleven o'clock at night; I sent my servant down before me, and she came up and said the purse was gone, and the prisoner likewise; she had been sitting in the same room with me.

MARY THOMAS
. I went up stairs with the prosecutrix; she sent me down for her gloves and purse; the purse, gloves, handkerchief, and the prisoner were all gone - the prisoner had been in the parlour with the prosecutrix: it is an hotel - there had been no other person there till the money was missed; there were no gentlemen in the parlour.

SAMUEL GILES
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner into custody, about twelve o'clock, on the night of the 7th of September; I asked what money she had got - she said only a few coppers in change for a sixpence; I searched her, and found a glove, with two half-crowns, two shillings, and five half pence in it - I took her in the same house; I asked her where she got this money, and she said at a house, next door to the Lyceum - I went there and saw two servants, but they said she had not been there: the prosecutrix told me that one of her half-crowns was a new one, and one of these is new.
Prisoner. When I left the house I had only change for a sixpence, but I did not say when I came back that I had no more.

SAMUEL GILES
. I asked what money she had, and she said only a few coppers in change for a sixpence; and when I found the money, she said she had got it next door to the Lyceum.
The prisoner put in a written defence, denying having had tne purse, and stating that she heard she she was accused, and immediately went to the house.
NOT GUILTY .

1852.
JOHN GILBERT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of August , 1 coat, value 10s. , the goods of
Alexander Bateman
.

ALEXANDER BATEMAN. On the 5th of August, my coat was on the top of a load of pots and pans, which I was driving; I had got to Tottenhom-court-road
, about half-past six o'clock in the morning - a man came and asked if we had any horse-cloths; I said "No, we have got some great-coats" - I then got up, and my coat was gone; he said "Come along with me," I went and saw the prisoner running with something under his arm - we followed him, calling Stop thief! he was stopped - I did not see my coat in his possession; he dropped it - I saw it again in about five minutes: Heaves picked it up and gave it to the watchman.

WILLIAM HOOPER
. I heard the cry of Stop thief! and saw the prisoner running before several people; he had nothing then, but they said he had stolen a coat - I stopped him.

THOMAS HEAVES
. On the morning in question, I was going down Tottenham-court-road; I saw the prisoner and another person standing against the shafts of this waggon- they crossed over, and I saw something under the prisoner's arm, which I thought was a horse-cloth; I asked the prosecutor if he had any horse-cloths - he said no, but he had some great-coats; he looked up and said there was one missing - we then followed the prisoner and his companion, who were going on towards the corner of Gower-street: the coat dropped from one of them, but I cannot say which - the prisoner's companion had something under his arm: I did not see them taken anything from the waggon - I picked the coat up; this is it.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you ever known this boy before? A. No - I had lost sight of them.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Confined Three Months .

1853.
JOHN HEDGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , 1 hammer, value 6d., and 1 trowel, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
James Coker
.

JAMES COKER. I lost a trowel and hammer, on the 29th of August, from a house in Brunswick-street, Hackney-road
; while I was at work, I saw the prisoner come, between six and seven o'clock in the morning, and take them off the bench - he ran off towards Hackney-road; some of my friends stopped him - my tools were found on him: I was in the next house, and saw him through a hole in the wall, and pursued.

Prisoner's Defence. I work for Mr. Pledge - I was walking up the street and saw a mob; I ran towards them, and a man came and asked if I were the thief - I said "I don't know what you mean," and as we were going along, a carpenter said "That is not the lad who dropped the tools, but I must take him back to Mr. Coker," who knows me very well, and has a spite against me.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Whipped and Discharged.

1854.
THOMAS DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of July , 12lbs. weight of ham, value 16s. , the goods of
Richard George Spice
.

RICHARD GEORGE SPICE. I am a ham dealer . On the 21st of July I saw the prisoner take part of a ham from my shop - I gave an alarm, and he dropped it on the step of the door; he went out at one door and I at another and took him; he had run along the window, which is about a yard and a half.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not swear you could not positively say it was me? A. No I did not.

JOHN CONDER
. I was sent for, and took the prisoner in charge - and in going along he feigned intoxication, and said it was a lark.
Prisoner. I said I thought they were having a lark - I came from my work and it began to rain; I was them going past the shop, the gentleman came out and took me.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined One Month .

1855.
MARY FITZGERALD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of August , 1 sovereign , the money of
Benjamin Mattin
.

CECILIA MATTIN
. I am the wife of Benjamin Mattin, and live in Montague-square; he is a butler there, and I live in the same family. On the 16th of August I saw the prisoner in Crawford-street
with some fruit - I asked the price, and made a bargain with her for two pottles of raspberries for one shilling; I gave her a sovereign, and she went over to a public-house for change - I saw her come out; she went down Crawford-street and I lost sight of her; she left her basket of fruit, and a little boy to take care of it; she did not return, but I found her afterwards intoxicated; I asked her for my sovereign, she said she had not got it; I gave her in charge, and ten shillings was found on her.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do not you know she was met by her husband, and beaten most severely by him? A. No, I do not; her husband had met her and knocked her down; she left her fruit for me and the little boy to mind; there was about nineteen pottles of raspberries in one basket, and the other was full of currants.
NOT GUILTY .

1856.
JOHN JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of August , 1 handkerchief, value 3s. , the goods of
Arthur Ashton
.

ARTHUR ASHTON. I lost a handkerchief on the 18th of August while I was in the Court of Chancery
; I did not feel it go - it was taken from my left-hand coat pocket; I missed it when I left for it; I saw it again in the robingroom.
Prisoner. Q. How long had you used it before? A. Perhaps about half an hour.

JAMES BAKER
. I am a Bow-street officer. I saw the prisoner attempting a gentleman's pocket - I took him and searched him, and this handkerchief was found secreted in his breeches.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I picked it up on the floor, as any one might have done; I stook there for half an hour, and then the officer called and took me.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Transported for Seven Years .

1857.
MARY NICHOLSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of August , 1 sheet, value 3s.; 1 looking-glass, value 1s.; 3 window-curtains, value 1s.; 1 hammer, value 1s. 3d.; 1 flat-iron, value 8d., and 1 candlestick, value 6d. , the goods of
George Osborne
.

GEORGE OSBORNE. The prisoner lodged at my house for about six months - her husband went away a few days before her, and then she went and took the key; she gave me no notice; I broke open the door and missed these articles; the prisoner came on the Saturday, and brought back one sheet and one blanket; I told the officer, and he took her.

JAMES COOK
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner on the 4th of August, and found this candlestick at a marinestore shop; the prisoner told me she left it there and borrowed 6d. on it; she said it was her landlord's property; I questioned her repecting the other things - she said some she had pawned and some she had sold; she said first at one place and then another(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner put in a written Defence pleading distress, and stating her in tention to redeem the goods.
GUILTY . Aged 47.
Confined Three Weeks .

1858.
MARY DAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of July , 1 cap, value 3s , the goods of
John Lewis
.

JOHN LEWIS. I am a haberdasher and live in Oxford-street. On the 9th of July, about seven o'clock in the evening, I was sitting in my parlour, and saw the prisoner standing against my counter, and putting something under her shawl - I went to her and asked what she wanted: she said a child's cap - I called my wife to serve her; I missed a cap which I had seen just before I went; I looked under her shawl, and asked what she had there - I took hold of her and found this cap.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Did she not deal with your wife for something? A. Yes - and she had paid for it; I understood afterwards that her sister was standing outside with her child; she did not say she intended to buy this cap - she said she took it off the ground; the street-keeper took her.

ANGELIUS BETRAUN
. I took the prisoner - she begged for mercy.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you know her before? A. Yes; she kept a fruit-stall under the Pantheon.
Prisoner's Defence. My husband has been a servant; my left hand was lame, and has been dressed in the hospital in this prison; I was going to buy the cap.
GUILTY. Aged 27.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury .
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1550.
ROBERT NIXON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of August , 1 hat, value 20s., and 1 handkerchief, value 1s. , the goods of
Robert Bushnell
.

ROBERT BUSHNELL. I am a millwright . I was in Whitechapel
on the evening of the 11th of August; I went to sleep, and lost my hat from my head, and a handkerchief in it; I saw them at the watch-house.

CHARLES LATHAM
. I am a watchman. I took the prisoner - he was running towards me in Whitechapel-road, opposite the hospital; I had not seen the prosecutor then; but I came up to him and he was asleep; the prisoner said he was running to make haste home, and that he had got this hat and handkerchief for a debt over the water - he had a hat on his head.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was not running; it was two o'clock in the morning; I picked them up on the pavement; they were not on his head.
GUILTY. Aged 19.

Judgment Respited
.

1860.
THOMAS NORTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August , 7 glass tumblers, value 5s. , the goods of
John Baldwin
.

JOHN BALDWIN. I keep an eating-house in Maiden-lane, Covent-garden
. I was informed by a person, that the prisoner had taken some tumblers on the 15th of August; I went after him, and accused him of it - he gave me three; I brought him back, and four more werefound on him, which are mine - I had not noticed him at my place.

WILLIAM DODD
. I took up the prisoner, and found a razor and a knife on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY . Aged 38.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1861.
ISAAC PECK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 4 shoes, value 23s. , the goods of
James Franklin
.

JAMES FRANKLIN. I was servant to Mr. Flower, of Bedford-place, on the 24th of June. The prisoner lodged there on the 24th of June; when I went out I locked my apartment, and when I returned my window was broken, and the shoes gone - I put up a board with a gimblet, and on the 30th, when I came home, the board was removed, and the four shoes were gone; the prisoner did not return that night - he came the next morning, but I did not see him again till the 8th of August, when I saw him in Oxford-street; I challenged him with it - he denied it; I met him again with his wife a short time afterwards, and said I intended to take him up on suspicion, and said, I was the last person he should have thought of doing such a thing to, as I had been a friend to him; he was then taken up, and confessed that he took those on the 24th of June, and pawned them on the 26th, and those on the 30th he sold to a Jew.

THOMAS HENRY THOMPSON
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner; he said he took the four shoes, and sold them to a Jew in the street.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not steal them, and never said I did.
GUILTY . Aged 42.
Confined Three Months .

1862.
ANN TAYLOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of July , 1 pair of stockings, value 2s. , the goods of
Christiana Dallimore
.

CHRISTIANA DALLIMORE. I live with my sister, Mrs. Smith, who keeps the Admiral Kepple public-house, Shoreditch
. The Prisoner had been four or five months in her service; I missed a pair of stockings from the wash for about two months; I made repeated inquiries of the prisoner - she always denied any knowledge of them. On the 21st of July, in consequence of missing some other things, I went into her room, and I found my stockings in her box, which was unlocked; I called my sister - we both saw them, and knew them; they were marked and numbered - we came down, rang the bell, and called the prisoner, and asked how she came by my stockings in her box; she denied any knowledge of them - I said, "I will convince you they are there;" I took her up, but the box was then locked, and when she opened it the stockings were gone - in a few days they were found in a cistern.

ELLEN SMITH
. My sister called me up to look into the box; I saw the stockings, and knew them.

JAMES BROWN
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner on the 21st of July.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. We were on very intimate terms. and I made use of two stockings, but I did not throw them into the cistern.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1863.
JOSEPH WESTMORELAND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 2 books, value 9s. , the goods of
James M'Clary
.

The property belonging to
Henry James M'Clary
, the prisoner was.
ACQUITTED .

1864.
JOSEPH WEST
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of August , 1 saw, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Baker
.

THOMAS BAKER. I am a carpenter . On the 26th of August I was in the back of a building in Tower-street, St. Giles's
; my saw was on the bench in the front part; I saw the prisner come and take it - I went after him and took him; he dropped the saw - this is it.

JOSEPH COLE
. I am an officer, and took the prisoner.(Property produced and swor to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was in great distress.
GUILTY . Aged 61.
Confined One Month .

1865.
SAMUEL WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 2 loaves of bread, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Charles Baxter
and another.

JOHN WYLLIE
. I am a constable of St. Martin's. On the 30th of July, about eleven o'clock, I saw the prisoner and another person pass me; the prisoner had two loaves of bread - I stopped him, and asked where he got them; he said, "Close by" - I said, "Show me where;" he took me to shop in Oxford-market, but he had not been there - I then went to the Bakers'-arms, but as I was going in he said, "It is no use telling you lies, I took them out of that basket;" I went to Pocock, who claimed them as his employers, and having been taken form his basket - his masters are Charles Baxter and another, and live in Charlton-street; the prisoner seemed in great distress.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1866.
AUGUSTA ROMAIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , 1 counterpane, value 2s.; 1 blanket, value 10s.; 1 sheet, value 2s.; 1 pillow value 5s., and 1 pillow-case, value 3d. , the goods of
Hannah Hunt
.

HANNAH HUNT. I am a widow , and live in Green Dragon-yard, Worship-street
. On the 26th of August, the prisoner came to lodge at my house - she was there but ten days; I wanted to wash the sheets, but she refused them - I then went and missed these articles.

RICHARD MANNING
. I am an officer. I was sent for, and found the duplicates on the prisoner.

SAMUEL STEVENS
. I am a pawnbroker. I took in these articles, but an not certain of the person.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was in daily expectation of money from my husband to support me and my child; I did not mean to keep them.
GUILTY. Aged 42.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1867.
JOHN SAUNDERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of August , 1 pair of trousers, value 5s. , the goods of
James Drew
.

HENRY CHURCHILL
. I am shopman to Mr. James Drew, a pawnbroker , of Clark's-place, Islington. On the 22d of August, about four o'clock, a person told me some things had been taken; I went out, and saw the prisoner about forty yards off, tying up the trousers - he saw me, turned into another street, and threw down the trousers; I pursued, took him, and took up the trousers - I have seen his master, who will employ him still.

JAMES DAVIS
. I was standing at the top of White Conduit-street, and saw the prisoner running with a number of persons after him; he threw down these trousers, ran about twenty yards further, and was taken by Whitmore.

WILLIAM WHITMORE
. I stopped the prisoner, and gave him to Churchill.

THOMAS COPE
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, who said he did it through distress.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1868.
SIMEON SLIGO
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of July , 2 planes, value 5s., and three other carpenter's tools, value 9s. , the goods of
William Smith
, and another.

JOSEPH THOMAS TILLEY
. I am apprentice to Mr. William Smith and his partner; they are cabinet-makers , and live in Charter-house-lane - the prisoner was in their employ for a few days; a small saw was missing: on the 5th of July I was going up Old-street, and saw it exposed for sale in Mr. Penny's shop.

WILLIAM PENNY
. I bought this saw, this plane, this square, and these other tools, of the prisoner.

WILLIAM KIRBY
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and produce the tools.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing about them.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Confined One Month .

1869.
THOMAS WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of August , 5 loaves of bread, value 4s., and 1 basket, value 1s. , the goods of
William Duffield
.

WILLIAM DUFFIELD. I am a baker . I lost five loaves and a basket from the corner of Portman-place, on the 5th of August, while I was gone to serve a customer; a footman told me it was stolen - I found it in possession of the officer.

WILLIAM HINDS
. I am an officer. I stopped the prisoner with the bread.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded poverty.
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1870.
MARY ANN BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 3 blankets, value 6s.; 3 pillows, value 1s. 6d., and 2 sheets, value 6s., the goods of
Thomas Johnson
; 1 coat, value 6d.; 1 waistcoat, value 6d., and 1 shirt, value 6d., the goods of
Robert Rose
; 1 pair of trousers, value 6d., and 1 waistcoat, value 3d., the goods of
Charlotte Barrett
, and 1 sheet, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
William Cuttle
.

THOMAS JOHNSON
. I am a broker , and live in Rose-lane
. I lost three blankets, three pillows, and two sheets, from the lower room of No. 11, which belongs to me; the prisoner lodged in the two-pair front room of that house - the blankets were part of the furniture of that room; a coat, waistcoat, and shirt, were also taken from there, which belonged to Robert Rose.

MOSES SIMMONS
. I am an officer, and took the prisoner; I found this one blanket under the bedstead, in her room, and these other things in the cupboard.

SARAH JOHNSON
. I am the wife of Thomas Johnson. The prisoner lodged in one of our houses - these articles were part of the furniture of another room, and were our property.

LEONARD CLARE MATTHEWS
. I have a blanket which was pawned with me on the 2d of July, and a pillow on the same day; I cannot say it was the prisoner who pawned them - it was a female.
Prisoner. I pawned them, but they were my mother's property for years.

DAVID JAMES
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker, in Whitechapel. I have a pillow and a shirt, pawned at different times by the prisoner.

WILLIAM PUTMAN
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a pillow pawned on the 6th of August, in the name of Brown - I cannot say by whom.

MATILDA CUTTLE
. I am the wife of William Cuttle. This sheet is my husband's - it was lost from that house.

SOPHIA ROSE
. I am the wife of Robert Rose. This coat and shirt belonged to him, and were found in the prisoner's room.

SAMUEL GREEN
. I went with Simmons to take the prisoner, at No. 11, Rose-lane; I found this coat and shirt rolled up, and these duplicates were in the room.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating, that Johnson kept a fence and a brothel, and had two lodgers in prison- that the pillow and blanket were her mother's, and the shirt her brother's.

MARY ANN BROWN
. The prisoner is my daughter; this pillow and blanket, which were pawned at Mr. Matthews', are mine, and have been in my family for years.
COURT to THOMAS JOHNSON. Q. What house is this you keep? A. A ready furnished lodging-house - there are no women lodge there.
NOT GUILTY .

1871.
JAMES HARRIS
and
WILLIAM COLTNEY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , 7lbs. weight of lead, value 10s., the goods of
Charles Walker
, and affixed to a certain building; against the Statute .

EDWARD COCKERTON
. I am agent to Mr. Charles Walker; he has a house in Phoenix-street, Bethnal-green
; I was at that house on the night of the 28th of August, and all was right - this lead was afterwards found, and I fitted it to the roof, it matched exactly.

JOHN RIGG
. I am a watchman. On the morning of the 29th of August, about half-past two o'clock, I was sitting in my box and received information of some persons robbing a house in Phoenix-street; I went there but saw no one - there was a ladder against one of the houses, I went up it, and went down the middle house of the three; I there found a door fastened, and broke it open but found no one; I went up stairs again and found in one room a coat, a hat, and a pair of shoes, with a quantity of lead.- this was in the middle house; I wentup the ladder again and heard some one say, "Here they are." I sprung my rattle, and saw the prisoners coming along the parapet. I took Harris, and two other persons took Coltney, he was without coat, hat, or shoes; he asked for them, and those in the house belonged to him; there was nothing found on the prisoners, but a knife was found in the room, and ten pieces of lead.

SAMUEL HALEY
. I went to the house with Rigg. I asked Coltney if the hat, coat, and shoes belonged to him, he said they ought, for he bought and paid for them.

THOMAS DOLBY
. I went to assist the watchmen in taking the prisoners to the watch-house. I went to the premises and found these three pieces of lead between the cieling and the tiles, and this other knife there, which would have made such marks as are on this lead.

LEWIS MYERSON
. I am a constable. I went to the house and saw the prisoners - I heard Harris say before they came down, "I may as well be sent, out of the country as be starving here."

JOSEPH PAGOLIN
. I am a bricklayer and live next door to this house. I was ill in the night, and got up; I heard a noise; I went up to bed again, and said to my father, "I think there are thieves next door." My father got up, and I followed him, he went to the back, and I to the front; one of the men then looked over the parapet, but I cannot tell which it was; my father called up some bricklayers, and I went to the watchman; when I returned my father had raised a ladder; we could not find any one there, but the lead, coat, hat, and shoes, were in the middle house.

THOMAS WALKER
. I am a constable, I fitted the lead to the place.
The prisoners put in a written Defence, stating that they had gone to the premises to sleep, and declaring their innocence. Coltney received a good character.

HARRIS -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

COLTNEY -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Twelve Months .

1872.
JOHN TOOLE
was indicted for
stealing on the 10th of August 1 handkerchief value 4s., the property of
David Barber
, from his person .

DAVID BARBER. On the 10th of August I was in Little Earl-street Seven-dials
; I felt a twitch at my pocket, and missed my handkerchief; I looked round and saw the prisoner with it in his hand - I called to him to stop; he put it under his coat, and ran down a court; I pursued him, and saw him take the handkerchief; it was taken from him at the watch-house; this is it; it is mine.

THOMAS WILSON
. I am an officer; I took the prisoner and found this handkerchief on him.
Prisoner. I throw myself on the mercy of the Court.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 17.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor .
Confined Two Months .

1873.
ROBERT STOCKS
was indicted for
stealing on the 12th of July , 2 pairs of stockings, value 2s. , the goods of
Robert Romanis
.

ROBERT ROMANIS. I am a hosier , and live in Norton Falgate; the prisoner had been my shop-boy for twelve months, and before he was my father's: he had a good character, but on the 12th of July I found these two pairs of stockings secreted in his box - he said he brought them from home.

JOSEPH FRYER
. I took the prisoner.
Property prodnced and sworn to.

The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he received no salary, but was allowed 7 1/2d. a day for dinner and 2d. for supper; that his sister had wished him to purchase her some stockings, and he laid these aside for her.

GEORGE SMITH
. I live with the prosecutor - I sold the prisoner two pairs of stockings about six weeks ago - I cannot say whether these are them.

ROBERT STOCKS
. I am the prisoner's father. On the Sunday before he was taken I heard his sister tell him she wanted a pair of stockings.
NOT GUILTY .
Fifth Middesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1874.
SUSAN KING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of July , 1 watch, value 1l.; 1 watch-chain, value 1d., and 1 seal, value 6d., the goods of
Edward Croft
, from his person .

EDWARD CROFT. I am a labourer . I came from Bedfordshire on the 16th of July, late at night, and could not get a lodging - I was walking in the street, and met the prisoner between three and four o'clock in the morning of the 17th - she asked me to give her something to drink; I said it was late, and we could not find a place; she said she would find a place, and I went and gave her a glass of rum, and took one myself: we came out, and she wanted me to go home with her, which I refused, but I went with her into some alley, and she clasped her hands round me, and asked me to go home with her - I still refused; she drew her hand from me - I felt my fob, and my watch was gone - she then ran off; I pursued, but lost sight of her - I met Lewis, who asked me what was the matter - I told him; he took her- I am sure she is the person; I was a little the worse for liquor, but knew what I was about; I did not give her the watch, nor promise her any money.

JAMES LEWIS
. I met Croft in the street, on the morning of the 17th of July - he gave me information, and I went and took the prisoner in about five minutes in Whitecross-street; she wanted to know what she was taken for - I took her to the watch-house, and said she had robbed a man of his watch; she said "Well, what have you to do with it"- I said I had, and I took her along - she seized a knocker of a door, and said "I will be d - d if I will go any further till you show your authority;" I said "Anybody has a right to take a felon:" I saw Adams on the other side of the street - I called him to me, and said "I will thank you to ring that bell," which he did; Mr. Richardson, the officer, came down, and we took her.

CHARLES RICHARDSON
. I am an officer. I came down, and took the prisoner to the watch-house - she produced this watch from her pocket, and said it was given to her.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that the prosecutor had taken her to several public-houses, and got intoxicated, and had given her the watch to pledge.
CHARLES RICHARDSON. The prosecutor had been drinking, but was not drunk.

EDWARD CROFT
. I had not been into any house but where we had the glass of rum.
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1875.
SUSAN HIBBERT
and
ELIZABETH MEARS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of August , 1 coat, value 25s.; 1 waistcoat, value 7s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 8s., and 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Richard Moltoff
, from his person .

RICHARD MOLTOFF. I am a fur dyer , and live in Harris-square, Kingsland-road. On the night of the 22d of August, I was going home with a bundle containing these articles - I met Hibbert, who asked me to go home with her; I went to a house in Red-lion-court
, and up one pair of stairs; I put my bundle down between the bed and the table - I did not intend to stop there all night, but I threw myself on the bed, and Hibbert threw herself upon me - there was no one in the room when we went in, but I presently saw a man come into the room on his hands and knees - Hibbert took hold of the back of my neck, and held my mouth; I recovered myself as soon as I could, and threw myself off the bed, but the man and the bundle were gone - both the prisoners were then in the room, and another woman - the prisoners instantly blinded and muzzled me - the third woman disappeared; I told the two prisoners I knew them both, and they had better give me the bundle; I got down into the court, and the street door was immediately shut against me - I knocked, but there was no answer - I got the watchman, and he knocked, but could not get in; I went to the watch-house, but could not get in there; I then went to Kingsland-road, and met the Bow-street patrol - they got in, searched that house and the next, but nothing was found.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Where were you going? A. Home; it might be a quarter past twelve o'clock, or rather more - I had had part of a pot or two of beer at a shopmate's house: I am certain we had no more; I was not tipsy then - I never said that it was a woman that robbed me - the women muzzled me - no woman came in the room till I had sprung off the bed - I am married.

JOHN WILLIAMS
. I am a watchman. On the 22d of August, I was crying half-past twelve o'clock in Hackney-road - some one called me; the watchman said "This man has been robbed in the second court in Kingsland-road" - the prosecutor did not appear drunk - he spoke very well; when the Bow-street officer went, I saw the two prisoners - the prosecutor did not know them till they got up, and put their clothes on.

Cross-examined. Q. Did not Jefferies, the officer, say he would have nothing more to do with it? A. Yes, in coming out of the court he did say so; the prosecutor was there, and must have heard it; he was rambling on at a terrible rate - no property was found - not on any man; he said he had been robbed in the last house, and his property was brought and put into another house.

WILLIAM TITHERTON
. I am a Bow-street patrol. I went to the house about ten minutes past two o'clock - the prosecutor said he had been robbed of a suit of clothes - we knocked several times, but could get no admittance; when we got in, we found the two prisoners in bed with a young man; the prosecutor swore to Mears, but not to Hibbert till about half-past ten o'clock the next morning - they denied having anything to do with him: he appeared sober at two o'clock, when he spoke to me.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you search both the houses? A. We searched two houses - there was a third house we did not go into.

JAMES HILL
. I am a headborough. I produce the bundle which the prosecutor gave me.

RICHARD MOLTOFF
. A man and woman came to me at the office, and said if I would stop the prosecution they would tell me where the bundle was - I said I only wanted my property, and it was left at a public-house.
NOT GUILTY .

1876.
WILLIAM PYMM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of July , an order for the payment of 20l. the property of
William James Cleaver
, his master .

WILLIAM JAMES CLEAVER. I am a bookseller , and live near Portman-square; the prisoner was in my employ - I gave him a cheque for 20l. upon Mr. Laurie, the army agent in the Adelphi, to go and get change on the 3d of July, but he never returned; he had been with me about seven weeks as a porter and assistant - I did not see him again till the 11th of August, when he surrendered.
Prisoner. Q. Was the money your own? A. Yes, it was; it was not Mr. Maxwell's; I am the prisoner's master.

PATRICK LAURIE
. I paid the cheque on the 3d of August, I believe, to the prisoner - but when I paid the cheque, I did not observe his features.

RICHARD HARTLEY WALL
. I am an officer. The prisoner came to the Police-office on the 11th of August, just before eight o'clock - he said he wanted to give himself up; I said, why - he said, "Go to Mr. Cleaver, and he will tell you," and in going along, he said, "I may as well he prosecuted first as at last;" when I got to Mr. Cleaver's house, Mr. Cleaver gave him in charge for taking a cheque and not returning - he said, he did go away about six weeks ago; I asked where he slept last, he said seventy miles off.
GUILTY. Aged 24.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury -
Confined 4 Months .

1877.
MICHAEL ATHY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of August , 1 saw, value 8s., the goods of
John Farrow
, to whom he was servant .

JOHN FARROW. I am a carpenter ; the prisoner was in my employ; I lost a saw on the 13th of August, while I was at breakfast - I had seen it ten minutes before eight o'clock, and when I returned it was gone.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you owe this poor man any money? A. There was a little difference; I did not owe him 1l. 11d.; I do not know that I owed him any - I gave him 15s. on the Saturday; he not did work on the Monday and Tuesday; he came on Tuesday and asked me for money, but I would not give him any - I owed him none.

BENJAMIN LEE
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 13th of August the prisoner pawned this saw.

WILLIAM HOLT
. I apprehended the prisoner, and found the duplicate of the saw on him.

Prisoner's Defence. When he paid me 15s. he saidthe work must be stopped, as the gentleman would not pay for it; I went on Monday and asked if I was to go on with it - he gave me no answer; I went again on Tuesday. he would not tell me then, and I took the saw to raise 2s. which I wanted - he owes me 22s.

WILLIAM BARNETT
. I know the prisoner; I work for Farrow. I was at the prosecutor's on Monday; heard him ask for money - Farrow promised he should have some before the day was out; he said on Saturday he was short, and could not pay us, and could only let the prisoner have 15s. - he owed him about 1l. or more from what I saw him do.

COURT. Q. Do you work for Farrow now? A. No, I could get no wages, and left him.
NOT GUILTY .

1878.
ANN WALKER
,
ELIZABETH RANDALL
,
ELIZABETH WOOLER
, and
MARY SMITH
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of August , 8 pieces of cloth, value 12s., the goods of
Abraham James Scrivens
; and 2 shillings and 1 1/2d., the monies of
Ann Carne
, from her person .

ANN CARNE. I am a widow and keep a patten-shop
in Grub-street. On the 16th of August I went to Mr. Scrivens's in Golden-lane, and got some cloth to cut into trousers, and received 3s. 2d. for some work; I went to three wine-vaults, and had some gin at each; I then got a stone bottle with gin in it for my sister; I felt a giddiness, and sat down on the step of a door with my bundle and the stone bottle - I had two shillings and three half-pence left; I knew nothing more till about one o'clock in the morning - I found myself in the watch-house; I fell down in the watch-house, my bundle and money was missing; I lodged at the same house as the prisoner Smith - I have not found my cloth.

JANE SCRIVENS
. I gave the prosecutrix the cloth and 3s. 2d.

WINIFRED COX
. I live in Whitecross-street
. On Saturday, the 16th of August, I saw Carne sitting on a step opposite, with a bundle; she appeared very drunk - I saw three of the prisoners go up and speak to her as if they knew her; Walker took up the bundle, and said she would go and fetch her sister Mary - she walked off; Randall and Wooler followed her; they kept together and went into a house - and came out again and went into a pawnbroker's in Golden-lane; they brought the bundle out; I followed them to a private house in Red Lionmarket.
Prisoner WALKER. Q. Did you see anybody strike me and take the bundle from me? A. No, you stood outside the pawnbroker's.

ELEANOR CASEY
. I am the wife of James Casey, and live in Elizabeth-court. On the 16th of August I told Cox I saw the three prisoners coming down Whitecross-street - the prosecutrix sat on the step of a door with a bundle and bottle - I told Cox to watch them; I staid at my stall, and saw Walker with the bundle; Smith was standing by the prosecutrix when the others were gone - she only put her up against the door, because she was in liquor - I said to Smith "You have got her money" - she said, "I have, it is in my hand, and I will take care of it for her."

MARY DUDGEON
. On Saturday, the 16th of August, I saw Carn sitting on a step drunk - Smith put her hand into her pocket and took out some money - she shewed it to the people, and said she would take care of it for her.
Prisoner SMITH. Q. Did I do it in any clandestine way? A. Oh, no.

JOHN BROWN
. I am a headborough. I apprehended Randall, who said the bundle had been sold; the others were brought to me afterwards.
WALKER's Defence. I was taken the day it happened; Scrivens came to Guildhall and said he had got the property; Randall took the bundle - I ran away and would have nothing to do with it.

RANDALL's Defence. Walker took the bundle and bottle - she went to try to sell it but could not - I then took it to a pawnbroker's - such a dread came over me I came out, and said they would not have it; I gave it to Walker - Wooler struck her and took it from her.
SMITH's Defence. I had taken the prosecutrix home drunk on the Saturday before; I saw her again in the same state; I took out her money to take care of it; I did not intend to steal it.
WALKER - GUILTY. Aged 30.

Of
stealing but not from the person .
Transported for Seven Years .

RANDALL and others
NOT GUILTY .

1879.
GEORGE STEVENS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of August , 1 sack, value 18d. the goods of
Robert Johnson
, from his person .

ROBERT JOHNSON. I am a sweep ; on the 21st of August I was in Gee-street, St. Luke's
, with a sack on my shoulder - the prisoner came and took it from me; he said that is my sack; I have known him some years; he knocked me down; my mouth was much swollen.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you not accuse a man named Williams? A. Yes, at Worship-street; I was in Williams' company, but did not drink; I drank a pint of beer or so at two or three houses; the prisoner was outside the office when Williams was there; he was about four yards off; he came and asked me for 3s. to pay for brandy and water which he had when we were drinking - I refused, and he said he would take me up for taking bakers' sacks; I had seen him before he came up to me; I had been looking for him for a fortnight: if I had not seen him he would not have spoken; it was Williams struck me, not the prisoner - he was with him - that was on the 19th.
Q. The sack was taken on the 21st? A. Yes - I prosecuted two men here last November.

JOHN SHEPHERD
. I am a constable; I took up the prisoner.
Cross-examined. Q. Did not the prisoner go up to Johnson first, and ask him for money? A. Yes; and he said he owed him none, and had been looking for him; he then gave him in charge.

Prisoner's Defence. We drank together on the Tuesday; he said Williams had robbed him; we went to seven public-houses, and were drinking from two to eleven o'clock; there glasses of brandy and water were scored to us; I left him, and next morning the landlady called on me about it; I went to the office to ask him for it - he said he would not pay it.

JOSEPH EDWARDS
. I keep a public-house in Great Pearle-street, Spitalfields. On the 21st of August the prisoner was at work in my cellar, which he rents of me, till nine o'clock in the evening, from three in the afternoon; he had a pint of beer or two - he hung up the key and went home.

EDWIN WILKINSON
. I am a coach-maker, and live in Queen-street, Spitalfields. On the 21st of August I saw the prisoner in his cellar; I spoke to him, and was with him there from six to eight o'clock, helping him to empty some soot; he could not have been elsewhere.
NOT GUILTY .

1880.
JOHN COLEMAN
and
HENRY REYNOLDS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of July , 3 salmon, value 7s. , the goods of
John Wells
.

JOHN JONES
. I am errand-boy to Mr. John Wells - he is a fishmonger , of Norton-street
. The two prisoners are dustmen
; they came on the 7th of July, about a quarterpast five o'clock in the evening, for the fish guts, which they used to take away - I said they could not have them then: Coleman said he had met our man going to tea, who said I was to give him the key to get them - I let him have it, and they went down; Reynolds afterwards went away with the cart - Coleman came through the shop soon after: when Gibbard returned, the salmon were missing from the ice-box; three were taken out of eleven - they had just gone away; we went to look for them, and saw Coleman and another man with the cart - we asked where Reynolds was; he said over the way; just as he said that, Reynolds came out of the French Ambassador's house - we asked if they had any salmon; they both said No - that we might search them and the baskets, and all; the cart went on - I staid with Coleman at the corner of Harley-street; he wanted me to go home - I said I would not, and would follow him: I did so - we overtook the cart at the Yorkshire Stingo public-house, in the New-road; I there saw them take the heads of the salmon and some money, and divided them - I then saw something under Coleman's smock-frock, and asked him to let me look at it; he would not, but said he would wring my ears off if I attempted it - I followed him down Stingo-lane, into his house; I could not get in there.

THOMAS GIBBARD
. I am shopman to Mr. Wells. I went to tea at five o'clock, leaving eleven salmon on the ice; I met the prisoners, and told them the boy would show them what to take; when I returned, I missed three: Jones and I followed the prisoners as far as Weymouth-street; I searched Reynolds, but found nothing; I looked in the cart and nose-bag.

JOHN LEPAIR
. I am lampist to the French Ambassador. I trim the lamps; the men came to take our dust away - I said it was too late to do it; I saw a dirty rag under the hall window, covered over a salmon - I had not seen the prisoners there.
REYNOLDS' Defence. I have been to the house for this two years.
COLEMAN's Defence. I never was in the cellar at all, nor near it; there are a parcel of lodgers in the house.

JOHN JONES
. There are two lodgers.

COLEMAN -
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Confined Six Months .

REYNOLDS -
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Confined Four Months .

1881.
ELIZA BURKINSHAW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of July , 6 looking-glasses, value 4l.; 20 sheets, value 4l.; 3 pillows, value 5s.; 3 bed-curtains, value 3l.; 30 towels, value 1l.; 13 table-cloths, value 2l.; 9 drinking-glasses, value 5s.; 1 blanket, value 1s.; 2 pictures, value 2s.; 4 pillow-cases, value 2s.; 16 knives, value 2s., and 15 forks, value 1s. , the goods of
Catherine Barker
, spinster , and
Amelia Barker
, spinster .

CATHERINE BARKER. I am single, and live in Longacre - these articles belong to me and my sister Amelia, and were in Hart-street, Covent-garden
; the prisoner's mother had the care of the apartments, and lived there with her.

FRANCIS FAGAN
. I am an officer. On the morning of the 15th of August, I went with two others to No. 15, Carlisle-lane, and apprehended the prisoner, and in a box in her room found eighty duplicates; I then went to Hart-street, and took up the prisoner's mother - the prisoner had told me the duplicates were in a box; I found a bunch of keys in her room, and another in her mother's room - here they are; I tried them - one unlocks the drawers and another the padlock of the door.

ELIZABETH FEATHERSTONE
. I am the wife of William Featherstone - we live in Covent-garden. In the early part of last winter, the prisoner brought some sheets, looking-glasses, and bed-furniture, which I pawned for her at different times.

SARAH FEATHERSTONE
. I pawned some sheets, towels, and other things for the prisoner at Mr. Bird's.

GEORGE SMALLBONES
. I am a pawnbroker. I have some towels pawned by the prisoner, in December - here is also a table-cloth and some pillow-cases, pawned at different times - here are the duplicates I gave for them.

SAMUEL HAVLOCK
. I am a pawnbroker. I produce some sheets and other things, pawned by Featherstone and her daughter at different times.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I never put a key to the padlock - the door pushed open itself.
GUILTY. Aged 25.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Six Months .

1882.
ELIZABETH BOLDERIDGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of September , 1 coat, value 10s., and 1 pair of trousers, value 10s. , the goods of
John Maidment
.
JOHN MAIDMENT. I am a bricklayer . I lost these things on the 3d of September; I had not seen them very lately - I lodge in the prisoner's mother's house.

WILLIAM BOLDERIDGE
. I am the prisoner's brother - she pressed me to take these things a week before I did; she said she would give me 6d. to take them, and I did so - she was not present; she does not live at my mother's - I took them to her, at her lodgings.
NOT GUILTY .

1867.
MARY MAHONEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of July , 13 shillings, 60 pence, and 120 halfpence, the monies of
Samuel Richards
, her master .

SAMUEL RICHARDS. I keep a public-house in Great Wild-street, Lincoln's Inn-fields
. On the 7th of June, the prisoner came into my service, and on the 17th of July, I marked a shilling and put it on the bar floor with a basket on it; there was a crooked halfpenny, andanother with two holes in it, in a 5s. paper on the sideboard - I missed them and two half-crowns off the shelf. On the 22d of July I found this shilling and the marked copper in the officer's possession - I had directed him to search for my daughter's cap, which was missing; a key of my bar was found in her room - Rawlings called me up stairs; I went up and called the prisoner - she was coming up, and when she got about half-way, she ran down; two women caught her and brought her up - I shewed her the money, and said "Now Mary, are you honest?" she fell on her knees and begged my pardon.

ELIZABETH RAWLINGS
. I lodge at Richards. There was a search for the cap; I went into the prisoner's room and found a key of the bar, concealed in a rug in the cupboard - it opened the bar.

PHILIP RILEY
. I am a beadle. I have a quantity of halfpence and silver which I found on the sacking of the bedstead in the prisoner's room; Richards pointed out these two halfpence and a shilling, which he said he had marked; I found another parcel of halfpence and a sixpence.

Prisoner's Defence. I often found money, and gave it him; I took this copper, and said I would frighten him, because he should not put money in my way any more; there was no key in my room, but his niece said to me,"There is a key in my room" - I took a key from there, it would not open my door, and I put it into the cupboard - they often mislaid keys; I did not know what door it would open - I found this copper on the club-room table.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1884.
ROBERT FOLKS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of April , 2 sovereigns, 1 half-crown, and 7 shillings , the monies of
Robert Peppin
, his master.

ROBERT PEPPIN. I am a working silversmith , and live in Gray's Inn-lane. The prisoner was in my employ. On the 14th of April I gave him a bag of work to take to Goldsmiths'-hall, with 2l. 7s. 6d. in it, to pay the duty; he did not return, and was taken on the 17th of July - the work was taken to the hall.

CHARLES FLINT
. I am foreman to Mr. Peppin. I put two sovereigns and 7s. 6d. into the prisoner's bag to take to the hall; he never returned.
Prisoner. Q. I did not see the money in the bag - Did you put it in? A. Yes; you know I did.

HENRY DAVIS
. I took up the prisoner in Cloth-fair; he said he was very sorry, and asked me to ask his master to forgive him - I said I could not, as I understood it was a second offence; he said if I would intercede for him, he would pay his master so much a week, as he had done in a former case.
The prisoner put in a written defence, denying all knowledge of the money being in the bag; and stating his absenting himself was on account of the lowness of his wages.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Six Months .

1885.
GEORGE WALKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of July , 100lbs. of lead, value 15s., the goods of
Thomas Miller
, and fixed to a building .

THOMAS MILLER. I have some buildings in St. Luke's parish
. I did not miss the lead from them myself.

GEORGE TWEEDY
. I am servant to Mr. Miller, and look after his houses, which are in St. Luke's parish. On the morning of the 17th of July the lead was missed; I had seen it all safe the day before - part of it was left in the house, but it was all cut from the roof; I was looking over the premises, and discovered it - I afterwards compared some which was found at the watch-house, and it fitted exactly.

DANIEL NEWTON
. I am a blacksmith. On the morning of the 26th of July I was at work in my shop, and can see Mr. Miller's premises through a hole in my wall - I looked through, and saw the prisoner coming down the stairs with a load under his arm; I went after him, found him with a large quantity of lead, covered with an apron - I took him in the court, and saw the lead matched with the roof, it fitted exactly; he was taken to the watch-house - he had about 30lbs. under his arm, and up stairs I found about three quarters of a cwt.; I had seen him there before.

GEORGE WOODGATE
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner to the watch-house, with the lead; I saw it compared to the top, it fitted.
Prisoner's Defence. I never was in those houses; I was going to work - I ran into the privy, and there was this piece of lead.
GUILTY . Aged 37.
Transported for Seven Years .

1886.
JOHN EVANS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of July , 75lbs. of lead, value 10s., the goods of
Thomas Miller
, and fixed to a certain building .
THOMAS MILLER. The house in question is mine. I have lost two or three cwt. of lead at different times.

GEORGE TWEEDY
. I am servant to Mr. Miller. On the 4th of July I saw this lead safe; the prisoner was stopped next morning - I was sent for, and compared the lead, it fitted exactly, nail holes and all.

RICHARD BURT
. I was going to market that morning and saw a man come out of the court with a load; I went to Woodgate's door and told him.

GEORGE WOODGATE
. Burt gave me information; I went, and overtook the prisoner near Pitfield-street, with a soot bag, which he was resting on a post - I took hold of it, and it contained lead; I compared it with the roof of Mr. Miller's house, it fitted exactly.

JOHN SHAW
. I am a watchman. I was called to assist a man over the road; I went over to the George the Fourth public-house, and took the prisoner - I saw the lead fitted - it appeared quite right.

DANIEL NEWTON
. I was on the parapet on the 4th - the lead was all safe; next morning I saw this fitted.

MARY STEWARD
. I am bar-maid at the George the Fourth: the lead was left there - we let them have the same again.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going down the court, saw the lead lying down, and put into my bag.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .
EIGHTH DAY. FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 19.
Second Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1887.
JAMES WARNER
was indicted for
stealing certain copper monies , the monies of
William Farrington
.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 23.
Confined Three Months .

1888.
MARGARET WALKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of August , 2 gowns, value 12s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 3s.; 1 pair of stockings, value 6d., and 1 handkerchief, value 1s. , the goods of
Mary Hacket
.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 30.
Confined Three Months .

1889.
THOMAS PLAW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of July , 7 sovereigns, 1 half sovereign, 1 Bank note for 5l., 2 Bank notes for 10l. each and 1 Bank note for 20l., the property of
Joseph Mattocks
, from his person .
MR. BARRY declined offering any evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

1890.
JOSEPH BONNER
and
WILLIAM MARTIN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of September , 6 ducks, value 10s. , the goods of
Andrew Blyth
.

ANDREW BLYTH. I live at Edmonton
, and am a surveyor . I lost six ducks, on Sunday, the 7th of September, and six others were killed; I had seen them all safe the night before; and at eight o'clock that morning, I missed them from my shed, which is about thirty yards from my house; there was no violence on the shed door, but it appeared as if some animal (I presume a dog) had got under - there are some men about there who have dogs trained for that purpose: I saw my ducks at the watch-house; they were dead, and appeared as if worried and taken hold of by a dog - they were bloody.

WILLIAM MANN
. I am a watchman. At a quarter-past one o'clock that night, I saw the two prisoners, about one mile from the prosecutor's, with something under their arms; I told Overton - he went and took Martin, and I took Bonner; I found nothing on him.

HENRY OVERTON
. I was with Mann, and saw the prisoners coming down the road, with a bundle in Martin's possession; I followed, stopped him, and asked what he had got - I felt the bundle, and it appeared to me to be poultry; I took him and delivered him up to the constable - there was a dog of a whitish colour, running after them; he followed us to the watch-house, and there we lost him - the constable found six ducks in the bundle, which the prosecutor saw in the morning and claimed.

WILLIAM GILDERSON
. I am a constable of Edmonton. I was called up, between one and two o'clock, by the two watchmen; they gave charge of the two prisoners, and the bundle, which contained six ducks dead, but warm - they neither of them gave any account of them: I shewed the same ducks to the prosecutor, who owned them directly.
BONNER's Defence. I was on my road for Edmonton, and overtook the prisoner; I walked with him, but had not gone half a mile before the watchmen took him and me.
MARTIN's Defence. I went to Tottenham, and stopped rather late at a public-house; I kicked against this bundle and took it up - this young man overtook me.

BONNER -
GUILTY . Aged 19.

MARTIN -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

1891.
JAMES EDWARDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of July , 1 watch, value 2l. , the goods of
James Evans
.

JAMES EVANS. I am in a gentleman's service , and live at Chigwell, in Essex
- I rent a room of Thomas Day; the prisoner lodged in the same house. On the 29th of July, I lost a watch from the mantel-piece - I had seen it safe half an hour before; we found the prisoner, who said he had pawned it in Bishopsgate-street.

THOMAS SMITH
. The prisoner came to me and said he was in very great distress; that he had a watch in pawn for 8s. - he asked me to buy it, and said I should have the duplicate for 2s.; I gave it him and got this watch, which I gave the officer.

GEORGE SEAWARD
. I am a pawnbroker. I took in this watch from some man; I do not know who.

THOMAS WATERS
. I am an officer. I have the watch, which I got of Smith; I then took the prisoner - he has worked for my brother, and was very honest.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY. Aged 19.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury .
Confined One Month .

1892.
THOMAS KNIGHT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of July , 1 truck, value 50s. , the goods of
John Hall
.

JOHN HALL. I am a wheel-right . On the 18th of July, I let a truck to the prisoner, about half-past two o'clock - I heard no more of it till the next day; he said I had seen him before, but I could not recollect him; the next day I heard there was a truck stopped; I went and found it was mine - part of it was gone then.
Prisoner. Q. Did I borrow it of you or steal it? A. You borrowed it, and said you lived in Bunhill-row; he left 1s., and was to pay 3d. an hour for it - it was worth about 50s.

WILLIAM SMITH
. The prisoner came to me, on the 19th of July, about three or four o'clock in the afternoon; he brought two trucks - one was broken and was on the top of the other; he offered that part of a truck, which was claimed by the prosecutor, for 10s.; he left it with me about two hours - the prosecutor claimed it.

JOHN TWEEDY
. I am an officer. I went and got the truck, and took the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence. I borrowed the truck for my own use, as I am in the habit of doing work for myself; I sent it home by my labourer, and till the next morning I did not know whether it was gone home safe - I came home from my work; he had sent word that he had given a boy 2d., and he had left the truck at such a place - I went and took it to Smith's to ask what it would cost to make it good, as I was in a very awkward predicament; I was going back and was taken.
WILLIAM SMITH re-examined. Q. Did he bring it to sell or to mend? A. To sell.
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Confined Two Months .

1893.
SARAH HANCOCK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of July , 1 gown, value 14s. , the goods of
Elizabeth Williams
.

ELIZABETH WILLIAMS. I am single . I lost my gown, on the 12th of July, from a back parlour, in Bowling-street, Clerkenwell
; it was taken out at the back window, which I had left a little way open - I had seen it at five o'clock that evening, when I went out: I returned in half an hour- the prisoner lived next door.

RICHARD MOATE
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a gown pawned with me on the 12th of July; I am not quite certain of the prisoner's person, but I believe it was by her - I gave this duplicate for it.

MARY LEWIS
. I keep a little clothes-shop. On the 12th of July, the prisoner brought this duplicate to my house, and asked me to take care of it, as she was going to meet a gentleman; I said I would - there weeks after, the officer came to me, and I gave it to him.

JAMES TERRY
. I am an officer. I produce the duplicate which I got from this witness.(Property produced and sworn to.)

The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that she had taken the gown and pawned it to pay her rent, but intended to redeem it; that the prosecutrix was living in a state of adultery, and had perjured herself by giving the name of Clark at the office.
GUILTY . Aged 44.
Transported for Seven Years .

1894.
HANNAH HAGGERTY
and
MARY ANN SHAY
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of August , 4 handkerchiefs, value 4s. the goods of
Joseph Crane
.

HENRY CARPENTER
. I am assistant to Mr. Joseph Crane, draper , of Ratcliff
. The two prisoners came to the shop together on the evening of the 22d of August - Haggerty bought half a silk handkerchief for 7d.; they took the handkerchiefs off the line at the door, and brought them in to me; there were three parcels - I missed one from off the counter; I looked over the counter and they were on the floor - Shay took them up; I cut off the handkerchief for Haggerty, and then I missed some more - Shay was then gone; I asked Haggerty where she was gone - she said she did not know; I said I would detain her, but finding she had a bundle of more value than the handkerchiefs, I said if she would leave that, and bring Shay back, I would let her have it; she agreed to do so, and she went to the door, went across the road and joined the other - I followed and brought them both back - I found on Shay a bonnet in a little blue hat; I took that out, and in the crown of the bonnet were the handkerchiefs I had lost; I had asked Shay before if she had seen the handkerchiefs, and she said with an oath, she had not - nothing was found on Haggerty.

JAMES YOUNG
. I was sent for, and took the two prisoners - Shay said it was the first time she had done anything of the kind.(Property produced and sworn to.)

SHAY -
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Confined One Month .

HAGGERTY -
NOT GUILTY .

1895.
EDWARD GEAVES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th July , 1 1/2 bushel of oats, beans and chaff, mixed, value 6s. the goods of
John Kent
.

JOHN KENT
. I am the son of John Kent; he keeps a livery-stable , in Southampton-street; the prisoner used to supply us with food for horses; on the 30th of July he came with some tares about one o'clock, to another yard we have in Gloucester-street
; I saw him going away with a quantity of corn in a sack; he did not deal in corn, but I believe carried it for his horse; I went to call a man, and when I returned, he was out of sight - the sack of corn was then missing; I afterwards saw a sack with a mixture of chaff, corn and beans, it corresponded with a mixture we had at Gloucester-street yard, but I could not positively swear to it.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Is there not a way throught your premises? A. Yes; a person may go through - the prisoner has occasionally taken tares through there; I did not make any observations on the sack - I think it was his own; I believe he buys a quanlity of tares and sells them.

WILLIAM KIRK
. I am a coachman. I was in Mr. Kent's employ; he called to me and I went after the prisoner, but did not see him; I went into Southampton-street, and there his cart stood and his mate with it; I looked, and saw the prisoner at the corner of King-street beckoning his mate to come to him; I called him - he came and asked what I wanted - I said master wanted to speak to him; he said "I am going to Hatton-garden, and can't come, what can be want with me;" Mr. Kent then came running up the road and accused him of taking the corn - he said he had not and knew nothing about it.

RICHARD PURSSORD
. I am a cheesemonger, and live in Theobald's-road. On the 31st of July, I was in the shop, some persons came and asked me to let them leave a sack under my window, and they would call in ten minutes - I cannot say who it was.
NOT GUILTY .

1896.
JOHN GIRDLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , 1 carpet, value 40s., and 1 chest of drawers, value 40s. , the goods of
James Strachan
.

JAMES STRACHAN. I am a cabinet-maker , and live in Gerrard-street, Soho. I employed the prisoner, on the 1st of August, to take a pair of drawers to Mr. Jackson, in Bedford-street, and he never took them: I never saw him again till I caught him about a fortnight afterwards asleep on the flap of a wine cellar in Hart-street, Covent-garden; he said he had put them down at a public-house door, and went to have a pint of beer, and when he came out they were gone - Mr. Jackson is not here, nor any one from him, but I know they were not delivered, because they sent for them.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

1897.
WILLIAM FRASER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of August , 10 pair of stockings, value 8s. , the goods of
Samuel Castle
.

THOMAS SMEE
. I am a patrol of Bow-street. On the 19th of August, I was on duty - I saw the prisoner and another man in company - the other man took some stockings from Mr. Castle's door in Oxford-street
, which he gave to the prisoner and ran away; the prisoner ranover to Queen-street - a gentleman caught him, and brought him back with the stockings, and gave them to me; I had pursued him, but could not run as fast as the gentleman did; I wanted the gentleman to come to the office, but he would not.

WILLIAM SIMSON
. I am son-in-law to Samuel Castle. the officer brought in the prisoner and this bundle of ten pairs of stockings, which are his property; the gentleman came in with him, he said he had done his duty. and would have no more to do with it.

Prisoner. Q. Did the gentleman come into the shop till I was there for some time time? A. Yes, he came in with you, I am sure; I went into the parlour, and as I was coming out again the officer and the gentleman came in with you; he went away directly - my uncle had been in the shop before, and he came in again, and kept the people from the door.

Prisoner's Defence. There were two gentlemen who saw me pick up the stockings, and they came in and said"You have got some property which a person stole and ran away with;" I said "I have picked it up;" they said"Come into the shop, and clear yourself;" I turned back, and went into the shop, and in five minutes the officer and a gentleman came in, and asked what was the matter, as there was a mob round the door - these two gentlemen are kept out of the way.
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Transported for Seven Years .

1898.
JOHN KNIGHT
and
SARAH HAWKINS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 3 silver spoons, value 8s. , the goods of
George Goodeve
.

GEORGE GOODEVE. I live in China-walk, Chelsea
, and sell fruit . I lost three silver spoons from my back room behind my shop, between ten and one o'clock - they had been in use at breakfast time, and at dinner time we missed them; they were two tea-spoons and one salt-spoon- I went to the constable - Knight was taken the same day; I had seen his brother before.

JOHN HARRISON
. I am constable. I took up Sage and the two prisoners - I traced the property to the pawnbroker.

GEORGE HUGHSON
. I am a pawnbroker. I produce two tea-spoons and a salt-spoon, pawned with me by Knight; he offered them - I rather suspected him, and he said he would fetch his mother; he went and fetched Hawkins, who said they had been left her by her brother - this was on the 2d of August, between eleven and twelve o'clock.(Property produced and sworn to.)

HAWKINS' Defence. I will tell the truth about them - I had been up Piccadilly to help a woman to a coach; she gave me a shilling, and I returned and met Knight, who said that young Sage had given him these spoons to get some money; and the gentleman would not take them without some one went to speak for them, and I went - I know nothing about them; Sage was outside the door, he sent him with the spoons, and said they were for his master; the spoons had been there two or three hours before I went.

KNIGHT's Defence. I was at work, picking potatoes, and Sage said "I have three spoons of my masters;" I asked who his master was - he would not tell me, but he asked me to go and pawn them; I did so - they would not take them of me; I came out, and saw my aunt passing by - I asked her to go and speak for me, which she did.

JOHN HARRISON
. I have no doubt Sage was connected with them.

KNIGHT -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .

HAWKINS -
GUILTY . Aged 46.
Confined Six Months .

1899.
JOHN ROSS
was indicted for
embezzlement .

JOHN MANNING
. I am a baker , and live in New-street, Covent-garden. The prisoner was in my employ on the 13th of June; he was to receive money for me, and account to me every night.

SARAH KENT
. I live with
Samuel Kent
, a publican. I paid the prisoner several sums of money for his master- I paid him 3s. 4d. but I do not know the day.

MARY ANN KENT
. I took in some bread of the prisoner, and paid for it - we began to pay on the 7th of June - bread was brought every day by the prisoner - we paid for it as we had it; it was from the 7th to the 14th of June - I cannot tell any sum; I paid him, but I paid him some shillings.

JOHN MANNING re-examined. Q. During that week were you at home? A. Yes, the prisoner came and accounted for monies he had received, but he brought none from Kent's; he said he had not received it, and it was booked.
Prisoner. Q. Did I bring you any money? A. Yes, and said it was from several customers; but never during that week did I take so much of him as was received from the Kent's.

Q. Was it not customary for those employed by you to keep back part of the money they received as part of their wages? A. No, it was not customary, but you said sometimes that you wanted 1s. or 2s., and I put it down when you told me of it.

JAMES ASHLY
. I took up the prisoner.
Prisoner. I was advised when I was acquitted here last Sessions to go to my prosecutor for my wages, and then he made this charge against me.
PROSECUTOR. He was acquitted then, but not on this charge - I did not owe him any wages; he said he came for some things which he left in the bakehouse.

COURT. Q. But did he come for wages? A. I did not conceive I owed him any; I had paid him some money due, but I did not know of his having received this money at that time, till I took the bill to Kent's on the 14th of June.
Prisoner. I was remanded to Tothill-fields to see if there was any other charge against me.
PROSECUTOR. No, he was remanded to bring up other witnesses - it was on a charge of theft - for taking bread and selling it.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Confined Six Months .

1900.
JOHN ROBERTS
and
SOLOMON TAYLOR
were indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of June , 1 knife, value 2d., and 130lbs. weight of lead, value 16s. the property of
John Garnett
; against the Statute.

PETER ELISHA
. I have the management of Mr. John Garnett's property; he has a house in Bennett's-place, Bethnal-green-road
- three days after the robbery I went and fitted this lead to the house; it fitted exactly; I know nothing of the prisoner.

JAMES GRANT
. I am a watchman. On the 28th of June I was in South-street Bethnal-green at twenty minutes past two o'clock in the morning; and saw two persons go down Hart's-lane towards Bennett's-place; I could not see anything with them, but just as they had left me I saw a piece of lead lying near Mr. Watson's gates; I took that up; I then saw another piece in the kennel - I took them both to the watch-house: I came back and saw the two prisoners walking and talking. At past three o'clock I went again to the place and found two more pieces of lead among some timbers; I sprung my rattle; another watchman came, and we took the lead to the watch-house - I came back again and saw the two prisoners walking near the same place; I then looked about and found another piece of lead in a stone-mason's yard; I took that, came back again, and just before five I saw the two prisoners come to the place walking and talking, and looking towards where the lead had been; I said to a man, "I don't like those two lads, I have some suspicion of them;" we took them, but found nothing on them but three knives, a button book, and a handle of a door; one of the knives was sworn to.

VALENTINE STOKES
. I am a beadle; I saw the knives, the book, and handle of the door, laid on the table at the watch-house; I am sure they came from one of the prisoners, but I cannot say which; on the Tuesday following Mr. Elisha came and I showed them to him.

JAMES GRANT
re-examined. I did not see the knives taken from them; I was laying the lead down at the time; I did not speak to the prisoners when I first saw them; I saw them go to where the lead had laid; when I saw them the second time it was getting light; it was about three hundred yards from Bennett's-place.

PETER ELISHA
. This knife I had put on the premises in one of the rooms of the house where the lead was taken from.
ROBERT's Defence. We live within one hundred yards of the place, and had plenty of time to get away.
M. PALMER. I am in the ginger-bread line. Roberts has worked for me for two years; he had leave to go to the play that night, and said he should sleep at his father's.

SARAH TAYLOR
. I am the sister of Taylor; he knocked at my door at five o'clock that morning and said he was going to his work.

ROBERTS -
GUILTY . Aged 19.

TAYLOR -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Confined Six Months .

1901.
JOHN WALKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 3 frocks, value 5s.; 5 petticoats, value 2s.; 1 pelisse, value 4s., and 1 pinafore, value 2d. , the goods of
John Hicks
.

ELIZABETH HICKS
. I am wife of John Hicks - we live in Noble-street, St. Luke's
. I lost three frocks, six petticoats, a pelisse, a pinafore, and some other things out of my room where I live and sleep; they had been in a box; I wanted a night-gown for the child, and went to the box and missed them, on the 20th of August - I had seen them in the course of the day; the prisoner had lodged with me on the 2d of August, but I don't know where he lodged after that - these are the articles.
Prisoner. Q. Will you swear they are your's? A. Yes; they belong to the child, who is my grandson.

THOMAS KIRKWOOD
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a flannel petticoat which I took in of the prisoner, to the best of my belief, on the 20th of August; I gave this duplicate.

CHARLES WORLEY
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker in Old-street - I have a frock and four petticoats pawned with me by the prisoner.
JAMES - . I am an officer; I took the prisoner.

JAMES STANTON
. I am a pawnbroker - I have two frocks, a petticoat and pinafore, pawned by the prisoner on the 20th of August.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Transported for Seven Years .

1902.
DANIEL BRIANT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of July , 3 blankets, value 4s.; 2 sheets, value 3s.; and 1 bed, value 3l. ; the goods of
Elizabeth Robinson
, widow .

ELIZABETH ROBINSON. I am a widow, and live in Cartwright-square
near the London-docks; the prisoner lodged at my house about four years - he left me on the 1st of July, but did not tell me he was going; he locked the door of his room. On the 4th of July, I got an officer and opened the door; these articles were all gone, and there was nothing worth mentioning left - they had been let as part of the furniture of the lodging; the prisoner appeared to be married - there was a woman with him; he came back on the 4th of July, and abused me for opening the door.
Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Had you not taken some spirits that day? A. No, there was no abuse on my side; he said, he had taken the bed, and I might do my worst.

ELIZABETH ROBINSON
. I am the prosecutrix's daughter. On the 4th of July, we sent for an officer, and got the door open; the prisoner sent his sister-in-law, and then he came himself - he told my mother he had taken her bed and she might do her worst.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you not find the key of his door hanging outside? A. No, the officer drew the staple out: the bed has not been found.

JAMES ROBERTS
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner - he asked me what I wanted with him; I said for taking a feather bed and other articles from Mrs. Robinson - he denied it, but when he saw her, he said, he was willing to settle the matter; I questioned him about the bed - he said, it was made away with; he offered to pay Mrs Robinson 4s. a week.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Confined Two Months .

1903.
GEORGE BRINE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of September , 7 marble slabs; value 30s. the goods of
James Sim
the elder,
James Sim
the younger, and
Robert Sim
.
