They being the property of James Sim only, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

1904.
ANN BURFORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the the 8th of August , 1 tea-caddy, value 8s. , the goods of
James Ironside
.

THOMAS IRONSIDE
. I am the son of John Ironside, a carpenter , who lives on Saffron-hill. I went into the back room on the 8th of August; I heard a footstep in the front parlour - I came out and saw the prisoner going out; I followed and overtook her just outside the door - she threw this caddy from her apron; a person picked it up, and gave it to me - the officer took her.

JOHN IRONSIDE
. This is my property.

JOHN DENNIS
. I am an officer and took the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence. I went in for one penny worth of milk; I stood by the door, and while I was waiting, one of the cows turned round with great fury - I ran back with fright, and knocked this down against the door; I never had it in my apron nor near it - had I thrown it down, it would have broken.
GUILTY . Aged 49.
Confined Four Months .

1905.
JOHN BEDFORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of July , 1 wooden bowl. value 3d.; 4 half-crowns, 9 shillings, and 15 sixpences , the property of
James Smith
.

JAMES GEORGE SMITH
. I am the son of James Smith, a porkman , who lives in Bath-street, St. Luke's
. I saw the prisoner come to the shop on the 4th of July between three and four o'clock in the afternoon; I was in the back yard and saw him pass round the counter with the bowl of silver in his hand - this is it; it had been in the till.
Prisoner. He picked it up off the ground, and he took and hit me; I hit the bowl, and it fell on the counter, and he gave it to his mother. Witness. I took it from his hand.

JOHN COLSON
. I took the prisoner and found these four half-crowns, nine shillings, and fifteen sixpences; I said, "Why are you such a naughty boy?" and he said a man gave him 1 1/2d. to go into the shop, and take what he liked.
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Whipped and Discharged.

1906.
WILLIAM ABBOT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of July , 1 coat, value 5s.; 1 waistcoat, value 2s.; and 1 pair of trousers, value 2s. ; the goods of
Richard Marshall
.

RICHARD MARSHALL. I am a blacksmith , and live in Frederick-street. I lent my coat, waistcoat, and trousers, to Edward Potter, on the 21st of July; I was to have five shillings for the use of them for about an hour - I have never seen them since.

EDWARD POTTER
. I borrowed this coat, waistcoat, and trousers of Richard Marshall for the prisoner; I lent them to him - I told Marshall they were for a young man, but I did not say his name - the prisoner never returned them.

WILLIAM POTTER
. I met the prisoner in Weymouth-street, on the Wednesday; he said, the articles were left at a friend of his, and if I went with him I should have them - I went with him to Benjamin's, a salesman's shop, and he said, he had sent a person to sell them there; that he stood in the street, and got the money, 3s. 6d.

SOLOMON MOSES
. I am servant to Mrs. Benjamin; she is a widow - I bought a coat and waistcoat for five shillings of a young man - I did not see the prisoner.

HENRY RICHARD BUCKERIDGE
. I took up the prisoner; he had these trousers on, and said he had sold the coat and waistcoat to a young man, well-known at the Olive-branch public-house, but I could not find him; as he went to the office, he said, he wished he had taken my advice before.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

1907.
MARY CONNELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of July , 1 pair of half-boots, value 3s. , the goods of
John Edwards
.

CHARLOTTE SAUNDERS
. I am the daughter of John Edwards; he is a shoemaker , and lives in Bath-street
- I was there on the 8th of July, and saw the prisoner come to his shop; she asked if we had any second-hand shoes - after being told we did not sell them, she went away; when she was gone, a young woman gave me information - I went out, and saw the prisoner twenty yards or more from my father's house; I went after her to the end of Providence-street - there I saw her stop and take a pair of boots from her pocket-hole, and put them into her apron; I followed her till she came to Worship-street, and then I went into the office, and spoke to a gentleman, who took her with the boots - he was called away, and Eagles took them.

THOMAS EAGLES
. I received the boots and the prisoner.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

1908.
EDWARD EDMONDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of July , 1 shawl, value 9s.; 1 hat, value 2s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 3s., and 1 pair of overalls, value 2s. , the goods of
James Lynch
.

JAMES LYNCH. I live in Oxford-buildings, Bloomsbury
. The prisoner lodged at my house six nights in the course of July; he did not tell me he was going, but I got up on the 15th of July to work - I went into my apartment - the prisoner was gone; I missed a shawl, a jacket, a hat, a pair of shoes, and a pair of overalls - I had seen them all safe the night before; I have never seen them since - I met the prisoner about seven weeks afterwards, and said, "I think you have seen my face before;" he said,"Yes, James, I have seen you - I am very sorry for what I have done, and if you will go to work, I will go to work and make you recompence for it;" I said, "If you will go home I will consider about it" - I gave him in charge; he said he had pawned the shawl for 3s., and sold the duplicate for 6d. - the other things he had sold.

THOMAS PERRING
. I took the prisoner - he said he knew nothing about the robbery, but at the watch-house he said he pawned the shawl on Saffron-hill for 3s., and made away with the rest of the property.

Prisoner. The prosecutor held out hopes to me, that if I acknowledged what I had done with these things he would let me go - I said Yes, to get away, but I know nothing of them; I was only a nightly lodger, and the door was open - any one could get in.
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Transported for Seven Years .

1909.
ELIZABETH FULLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of July , 1 pillow, value 1s.; 1 bolster, value 2s.; 1 quilt, value 3s.; 1 frying-pan, value 10d.; 1 saucepan, value 9d.; 1 teaboard, value 6d., and 2 chairs, value 2s. , the goods of
Elizabeth Purland
, widow .

ELIZABETH PURLAND. I am a widow, and live in the Curtain-road
. The prisoner lodged with me one week - I did not know she was going, but she did go; I went to see if my property was safe, and missed the articles stated - these are them.

REBECCA DAVIS
. The prisoner brought a pillow and a bolster to me in July; she said she was in great distress and cried very much - I bought this saucepan and fryingpan of her.

HENRY FREAKS
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a rug pawned by the prisoner on the 26th of July for 1s.

CHARLES CONSTABLE
. I am an officer. I took up the prisoner, and found this duplicate of the rug on her.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I throw myself on the mercy of the Court.
GUILTY . Aged 50.
Confined One Month .

1910.
PATRICK GRAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of August , 3 lbs. weight of pork, value 2s. 6d. the goods of
Anthony Hagmire
.

ANTHONY HAGMIRE. I am a pork-butcher , and live in Ratcliff-highway
. I lost a loin of pork on the 9th of August; I was just outside the door - I went after the prisoner and found the pork on him; he had got about ten yards - it was my pork; he said he would pay for it, and at the watch-house he pulled some money out - he said before the Magistrate that he had never been in the shop.

ELIZABETH STALL
. I am servant to Mr. Hagmire. I saw the prisoner come and take this pork from the window - he came into the shop, and stood a few minutes, as if to have it weighed; he then went out with it, and I told Mr. Hagmire, who followed him; it was about ten o'clock on Saturday night - when I saw him go out I got under the flap and followed him.
Prisoner's Defence. I never was in the shop.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1911.
DANIEL HOLLIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of June , 1 coat, value 35s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 15s.; 3 waistcoats, value 18s.; 2 pairs of stockings, value 1s. 6d.; 1 shirt, value 5s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 6s.; 1 sovereign, and 1 half-sovereign , the property of
James White
.

JAMES WHITE
. I am a journeyman shoemaker , and live in New Tothill-street, Westminster
; the prisoner lodged in the same house. On the 26th of June I went home about ten o'clock in the evening, and missed the shoes from a basket - I then found the lock of my box was wrenched; I then missed all these articles stated - I had seen them safe at seven o'clock, when I left work; the money was in the box, and that was gone - a shoulder-stick and some tools were taken from my bench; the prisoner did not return.

JOSEPH HARRIS
. I am a shoemaker, and live in the same house. I saw the prisoner in the course of this month - he sent for me to the One Tun public-house; I asked where he had been: he said at different places round the country, and that on the 26th of June he came home, found us all out, and he took a chisel off my seat, wrenched the lock off this box, and took out the money and clothes, and took the shoes out of the basket.

JOHN KILBY
. I am a constable, and took up the prisoner; I found this waistcoat on his person, and these shoes were at a pawnbroker's, where the prisoner said he had pawned them; I found this shoulder-stick and tools at his lodging.

Prisoner's Defence. The man who has come against me is a bad character himself; the landlord of the Cock public-house will not suffer him to come into his house, for stealing some cloth from a hawker, and living with a girl whom he cannot support, except by prostitution or theft; he told me he had been chased out of the place he lived in, for stealing a tea-caddy.

JOSEPH HARRIS
. I was never charged with theft.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

1912.
WILLIAM HARRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , 1 watch, value 2l.; 4 spoons, value 30s., and 1 pair of sugar-tongs, value 10s. , the goods of
James Ralph
.

MR. JAMES RALPH. I lost a watch, four spoons, and a pair of sugar-tongs, on the 7th of August; the prisoner had been my servant for about six weeks - he was a very good servant, and I was much surprised, as I had seen all these articles safe about half an hour before; they were taken from my kitchen; my servant came and said the prisoner was gone - he did not return at night: I had paid him part of his wages.

HENRY REID
. I apprehended the prisoner on the 12th of August, and asked how he came to do this; he said he did not know, but it came into his head all at once - I asked if he had taken any spoons; he said Yes, two, and had sold them and the watch for 30s.
Prisoner's Defence. I never had them.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

1913.
CHARLES JUST
and
ROBERT ENGLISH
were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 3 lbs. of starch, value 3s. , the goods of
Richard Jones
.

CELINA JONES
. I am the wife of Richard Jones - we keep a shop in Camden-street, Islington
. On the evening of the 8th of September I was in the back room, and caught a glimpse of a hand taking something from the window; he came close to the counter, and took something from the window, and either gave it to another man at the door, or else he passed that man and the other came in - I went to the door, and called Stop thief! my husband followed me- I passed one of them just in the shop (I believe that was English;) my husband followed the other, who was running - English walked out after the other; he did not run.

RICHARD JONES. My wife called out; I came out - she said, "There he goes;" I saw a man running, and pursued him; English (who was just at the door) put his foot forward to trip me up; I think it was intentional - I still followed the other man; I lost sight of him as he turned the corner, and when I turned I found him in custody - it was Just; I believe him to be the man: I putmy hand on his shoulder, and he dropped the starch on the ground - it was one of my parcels, and on returning to the shop I missed one parcel of starch.

RICHARD STEVENS
. I stopped just in Colebrook-row, as he turned the corner from a cry of Stop thief! the prosecutor and some others came up; I saw him drop the starch behind him; he tried to drop it into the river; English was then close behind me, endeavouring to interfere; I said, "You had better be off - I shall know your face again;" he went off.

EDWARD SPENCER
. On the night in question I saw Just running, with a blue paper parcel in his hand; I saw English near the shop - he put his foot out, and tried to trip up Mr. Jones.
Cross-examined by Mr. BODKIN. Q. Where were you standing? A. At the corner of Camden-street, opposite the shop; they ran from me - it was between six and seven o'clock in the evening.

THOMAS COPE
. I am a constable. I took Just; I saw English in the crowd - he afterwards came to the office.

JAMES ISAACS
. I was in the waiting-room at the office - Just was brought in; English came in, and Just said to him, "You know, George, when I left you, I had been to take a watch home; there was a crowd, and a cry of Stop thief! they took me, and said I thieved this parcel;" English said, "You are lucky, by G-d;" Just said, "Go and tell my old woman where I am:" English then walked round, and looked at the bills; one Wilson came up to him, and said, "You had better bolt or run, George, or else you will be grabbed:" he was going out - I said, "Your friend wants you," and he was detained.
Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. A harnessmaker; I assist my father, who is a watch-house-keeper.

THOMAS COPE
re-examined. Wilson was only charged with being in the crowd, and saying, "As a gentleman, I will see you do your duty."
JUST'S Defence. English was not in my company. I had been to take a watch home.
ENGLISH'S Defence. I was taking a walk, and happened to run against Mr. Jones - I begged his pardon: soon after a friend of mine was taken to Hatton-garden - I went there, and was committed.

JUST -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

ENGLISH -
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Seven Years .

1914.
WILLIAM LUSH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of September , 1 pewter pot, value 2s. , the goods of
William Dodds
.

WILLIAM DODDS. I keep the Dover Castle, public-house, Weymouth-mews, Portland-place
. On the 9th of August I lost a pot, but did not miss it till I saw it at Bow-street - this is it.

WILLIAM BERRYMAN LUSH
. The prisoner is my son: I live in St. Giles', near the workhouse. I met him with this pot, and asked him how he came by it - he first said it was thrown at him by a boy, and then said it was given him to go and sell; I gave him in charge.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Whipped and Discharged.

1915.
PHILIP BENJAMIN MARSHEA
&
GEORGE McDONALD
were indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of July , 1 pair of shoes, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Alexander Cowan
.

WILLIAM JONES
. I am a shoemaker, and live in Warner-street, Clerkenwell. On the afternoon of the 10th of July I saw the two prisoners together in Ray-street, Clerkenwell; Marshea had a pair of shoes, tied together with a piece of string; they stopped behind a hearse, and were breaking the string - this gave me suspicion: I told the constable, and he took them.
ALEXANDER COWAN. These shoes are my property; they were safe at three o'clock on the 10th of July.

WILLIAM ROBERTS
. I was desired by Jones to stop the prisoners: I took the shoes from Marshea, who said his mother sent him to pawn them.

MARSHEA'S Defence. My mother desired me to take the key to my brother, and as I was returning I picked up the shoes, and tied a handkerchief round them; the officer took me, and I said they belonged to my mother, for fear they should take them from me; they were not tied together.
McDONALD'S Defence. I saw this lad, who told me he had found the shoes.

MARSHEA -
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Whipped and Discharged.

McDONALD -
NOT GUILTY .

1916.
MARY ANN READING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of April , 1 petticoat, value 1s.; 1 apron, value 6d.; 1 flat iron, value 1s. 6d.; and 1 pair of bellows, value 3s. , the goods of
Dennis Welch
.

DENNIS WELSH. I am a labourer , and live in Adam and Eve-court, Whitecross-street
. On the 22d of April, about seven o'clock in the evening, when I came home, I missed these articles from my lodgings; they were safe in the morning; the prisoner slept there the night before, but not before that: I met her in July, and she said she did not know me - I gave her in charge, and she said she would give me half a crown if I would go to her house.

BRIDGET WELSH
. I am the wife of Dennis Welsh. On the 21st of April the prisoner came to me and slept in my room; she was a stranger - she went away in the course of the morning; we had been drinking together, and when she was gone I missed these things.

WILLIAM HOOKER
. I am a labourer. On the 22d of April I was standing at the bottom of Adam and Eve-court; the prisoner came down with a bundle - I saw a pair of bellows and something round them, and a pair of bellows at the top; Mrs. Welsh came down in a few minutes, and asked if I had seen her - I directed her towards St. Luke's church.

CHARLES RICHARDSON
. I took the prisoner in charge; she wanted to settle the matter, but I would not suffer it.
Prisoner's Defence. Dennis Welsh was gone to a fight - we had nothing in the house, and she gave me the bellows to make money of - she wanted me to stay, but I would not.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Confined One Month .

1917.
JAMES RING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of July . 2 trowels, value 3s., the goods of
James Buck
, and 1 trowel, value 1s. 6d , the goods of
Samuel Hanaford
.

JAMES BUCK
. I am a plasterer . On the 6th of July I was working in Frederick-street, Gray's Inn-lane
; when I went to dinner I left two trowels, and on returning found the prisoner in custody with them at the door.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. You do not know who had been there in your absence? A. No; other persons were at work there.

SAMUEL HANAFORD
. I am a plasterer. I left my trowel at the same place, and on returning found it had been taken from the prisoner.

WILLIAM BLISS
. I am a carpenter. I was at work at Mr. Cabit's shop, in Frederick-street; the prosecutors were working at a house there; I saw the prisoner coming out of the door - I asked if he worked there; he said Yes; I saw some tools under his arm; I went after him and took him.
Cross-examined. Q. Where were you? A. Just coming out of our back gate; I saw nobody else there; the prisoner said somebody gave them to him.

SAMUEL MOUNT STEVEN
. I am an officer, and took the prisoner; some people in the crowd said somebody had been seen to come out at the back door.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY. Aged 21.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1800.
ELIZABETH SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of July , 1 sheet, value 3s. , the goods of
Mary Burke
.
MARY BURKE. I am a widow . On the 16th of July I missed a sheet off a bed, which I let to the prisoner with a lodging, and found it in pawn.

THOMAS WOLSTENHOLME
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 16th of July the prisoner pledged this sheet.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Transported for Seven Years .

1918.
CHARLES SHERWOOD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of July , 2 decauters, value 30s.; 4 dishes, value 50s.; 1 pepper-castor, value 3s.; and 1 cruet-frame, value 7s. , the property of
William Morse
.

WILLIAM MORSE. I am a china and glass dealer , and live in Whitecross-street, and have a stand in Fleetmarket
. On the 11th of July the prisoner, who is a journeyman upholsterer , came to me with the pattern of a decanter on a piece of paper; he said he was furnishing a house for Captain Morris, and wanted it - he said he was afraid I was detaining him too long, as the Captain went out at nine o'clock in the morning; I let him have two; on the 14th he came again for three dishes, a pepper-castor with a silver top, and a cruet frame; I let him have them; he said he would let me know about them; I lent him a silk handkerchief to put them into; he said he got them for Captain Morris, York-terrace, Regent'spark; I heard no more of him till the 22d, when I went to his house with a dish under my arm, expecting, as he had not let me know, that the others would not suit him, and this was one of a superior quality; I saw him - he said the Captain could not give more than 4l. 5s. for the dishes; he then said he thought the Captain would like the one I had brought much better, and I left it with him; on the 29th I went to York-terrace, but could find no such person as Captain Morris.

CHARLES WORTHY
. I have a pair of decanters, three glass dishes, and a pepper-castor, pawned by the prisoner on the 14th of July; he said he brought them from Captain Dean, in the Fleet Prison, and gave the name of Sherwood.

JOSEPH HALL
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a trifle dish pawned by the prisoner on the 23d of July.

PETER HALL
. I am a carpenter. I called on Morse, and assisted him in taking the prisoner; he sent for his wife, who advised him to let Morse know what he had done with the property; he at last said he had pawned them, and took the duplicates out of his pocket.
- WATTS. I am an officer. I was sent for and took the prisoner, and found some duplicates on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Confined Three Months .

1919.
LYDIA SYRETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , 1 frock, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Elsey
.

MARY ANN ELSEY
. I am the wife of Thomas Elsey, a tailor , and live in Playhouse-yard
. On the 29th of August this frock was taken from the first-floor room, where it hung to dry; the prisoner lodged in the house.

ELIZABETH LEONARD
. I am the daughter of Thomas Leonard. On the 29th of August I saw the prisoner take a white frock off the line and put it into her bosom; she went down stairs; a little boy was in the passage, she took him away with her.

CHARLES BARFF
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a frock pawned by the prisoner on the 29th of August.

CHARLES RICHARDSON
. I am an officer, and took her into custoday; she was intoxicated; the prosecutor asked her to give up the frock or the duplicate; she solemnly declared she knew nothing of it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I am innocent; I have pawned other things with the pawnbroker. but not this.
GUILTY . Aged 43.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1920.
CHARLES BANKS
and
HANNAH SOLOMONS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of September , 2 sovereigns, 8 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
James Winter
, from his person .

JAMES WINTER. I am a lighterman . On Saturday, the 6th of September, I received three half-crowns, one shilling, and two sovereigns - I had half a crown and one shilling besides; I went to a public-house, had a beefsteak, a pint of beer, and a glass of gin, with a fellowservant; I then came out and met Solomons, who asked me to give her some gin, which I did; I was sober - I went to her lodgings in Bell-yard, and gave her 3s. 6d. to get some supper; I sat in a chair and went to sleep; I had been up four nights and was very tired; I was awoke by Banks rumbling me over - I jumped up and said, "You have robbed me;" he went round the bed and gave something to Solomons, who was sitting up in the bed; I went to seize him, he seized hold of me and got me down the stairs, ill-used me, and turned me out; I called Watch!two watchmen went up stairs into the same room with me, the prisoners were then both in bed - we could find nothing in the room; we took them to the watch-house, then returned, and found my money in a silk handkerchief between the sacking and mattress.
Prisoner BANKS. Q. Were you not very drunk? A. No; I was not locked up myself.

ROBERT PHILLIPS
. I heard a cry of Watch! went up the passage and saw the prosecutor, who said he had been robbed and ill-used; we went up stairs and found the prisoners in bed - Banks was undressed; Winter said, "That is the young man who ill-used me;" we ordered him to get up and dress, which he was very loath to do; Solomons would not get out of bed, but seemed fumbling about to put something away; she got up, we took them both to the watch-house, then returned to the room, and found two sovereigns, eight shillings, and three farthings, in the handkerchief.

RICHARD BRIDGE
. I was with Phillips - what he has stated is correct.

JOHN DANGATE
. The prisoners were brought to the watch-house; the watchman afterwards brought the money in the handkerchief - Solomons claimed the handkerchief before the Magistrate.

SOLOMONS Defence. When I met him he was so drunk he could not stand - he gave me the money to get supper, and I went out; he had got his things off - he got up, put them on, and said he had been ill-used; he had slept full a quarter of an hour on the ground while I while I went out for the supper.

BANKS' Defence. Bridge said he had seen the prosecutor in Bell-yard with two women; he was locked up, the prosecutor being disorderly; I had been to a fair, as I returned I met Solomons, who asked me to go home with her, which I did; I saw the prosecutor there - I was going to retire; she said, "No, don't go away, wake him, and he will go;" I awoke him - he got up and put his things on, and went to strike me; I put him out and called the watchman.

WILLIAM BRIDGE
. I had seen Winter with two of his comrades, but no women.

ROBERT PHILLIPS
. The prosecutor was detained to give the charge, not for being drunk or disorderly.

JAMES WINTER
. I had nothing off but my jacket when Banks was rumbling about me; my trousers pocket is cut where they got my money out.
Banks received a good character.

BANKS -
GUILTY . AGED 18.
Confined Six Months .

SOLOMONS -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported Fourteen Years .

1823.
JANE EDWARDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., of
John James Hodgson
, from his person .

JOHN JAMES HODGSON. On the 28th of July, I was in Bath-place, New-road
- I left my handkerchief go, turned round, and saw the prisoner with it in her hand; I seized her, but she was too strong for me; I called the watch, but no one came; I pulled a second time, and she let go of it.

Prisoner. I did not take it from his person - I am an unfortunate girl, and was with him for half an hour - he told him to feel in his pocket to see if he had any money; he said I carried him across the road; and he said "You hussy, if there was a watchman I would give you in charge;" I was on the other side of the way - he saw a watchman by the Adam and Eve - he crossed over, and gave charge of me; I have no parents or friends.
JOHN JAMES HODGSON. I was not in her company at all - she did drag me across the road, and asked me for 2d.; I would not give it her, and she took my handkerchief.

JAMES DAYTON
. I am a watchman. The prosecutor came up to me, and gave the prisoner in charge - at the watch-house, he gave me the handkerchief from his pocket.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1922.
GEORGE JURDEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of July , 1 handkerchief, value 6s., the goods of
William Foreman
, from his person .

WILLIAM FOREMAN. On the 22d of July, I was going up Broad-street, St. Giles'
, between twelve and one o'clock in the morning - I had spent the evening out with some friends - three or four females came up and asked where I was going; the prisoner then came up and took my handkerchief; I made a snatch at it - he drew it from me and ran off; I pursued him thirty or forty yards, and overtook him at the corner of Middle-row, but my handkerchief was not found.
Prisoner. Q. What part of Broad-street was this? A. A few yards from George-street; I was not accusing the girls of taking it; I gave charge of him.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been up late settling some business - I was returning home, and saw the prosecutor pulling three girls about, and accusing them of taking his handkerchief - I passed on, and soon heard the cry of Stop thief! I turned round, he came up, and accused me of taking it; if I had, it must have been found on me or in the street.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1923.
JOHN LUKES
and
JOHN BUCKERIDGE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of July , 1 necklace, value 2s., the goods of
Christopher Taylor
, from the person of
Martha Taylor
.

ANN TAYLOR
. I am the grandmother of Martha Taylor- she is nineteen months old, and is the daughter of Christopher Taylor, my son. On the 15th of July, I took her out with a necklace on - I did not miss it till a gentleman asked if I had lost it.

THOMAS HOBBS
. On the 15th of July, I saw Buckeridge go up to this child, which Mrs. Taylor was holding by the hand - he unclasped the beads, and Lukes took them off the child's neck: they both ran off; I pursued, and took Lukes, and he then dropped these beads at his feet - I took them up.

DANIEL RIERDON
. I received Lukes in charge with the beads.

THOMAS WALTERS
. I received information, and tookBuckeridge two days afterwards - I found a string on him with a hook to it.(Property produced and sworn to.)

LUKES -
GUILTY . Aged 11.
Whipped and Discharged.

BUCKERIDGE -
GUILTY . Aged 14.

Confined Three Months and
Whipped .

1924.
JOSEPH WATERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of August , 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 seal, value 1d., and 1 key, value 1d., the goods of
John Roach
, from his person .

JOHN ROACH. I was at the Admiral Hagel public-house, between nine and ten o'clock at night, on the 2d of August - I lost my watch from my pocket; I did not feel it go, nor see who took it; I saw the prisoner in the house - I had been drinking, but was not in liquor; I had my head on the table, and went to sleep; I awoke, and missed my watch - I have not found it.

WILLIAM SULLIVAN
. I was at the public-house with some friends. and saw the prosecutor fall asleep - I saw the prisoner take the watch from his pocket, and put it into his own; when the prosecutor came in, the prisoner stood up and shook hands with him, and they drank together; the prisoner and another man went out together, and then the prosecutor said he had been robbed, and went out; I am certain the prisoner took the watch.
Prisoner. Q. Where did I sit? A. At his right-hand side; I sat at the corner of the table - you sat next him, and his friend on the other side of him; you came in before them.

Prisoner to
JOHN ROACH
. Q. Did we not go out together for the beer? A. No, when I went in, you stood up and shook hands with me, and asked me to sit down and drink.

EDWARD HEDGES
. The prosecutor came to me on Monday morning - I went with him, and took the prisoner, who was in bed with a little girl, but found nothing on him; I charged him with the theft - he said nothing.

Prisoner's Defence. Sullivan was tried here last Session; when I went out, the prosecutor had not missed his watch - he came out himself to the corner of the street- his friend asked if he had lost anything; he said Yes, his watch - his friend accused me of stealing it; I said,"Search me," but he would not; they suspected Sullivan, and went back to the house, and on Monday morning they sent for me.

WILLIAM SULLIVAN
. I was tried last Session, and acquitted. I did not see the prosecutor and his friend come back to the house; I saw the prisoner in the street, but did not give charge of him; I had heard of the loss - there was some wrangling in the street; I went up, and said he ought to return the watch - he said he would knock me down.

JOHN ROACH. I did not suspect Sullivan - I missed my watch just as I came out at the door; my friend and I came out just after the prisoner, and my friend accused him of it; he said he could knock his head off.
WILLIAM SULLIVAN. I did not hear what passed at the door - I kept my seat in the house.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Fourteen Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1925.
MATTHEW DUNN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of August , 4 half-crowns, 15 shillings, and 10 sixpences, the monies of
Morris Fitzgerald
, from his person .

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY .
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1926.
WILLIAM CAREY
and
ANN CAREY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of August , 1 watch, value 3l.; 2 seals, value 5s.; 1 snuff-box, value 15s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 13s.; and 13 shillings , the property of
James Hughes
.

JAMES HUGHES. I am a tradesman out of business. On the 4th of August this watch and money were in my trousers, and the snuff-box in my coat pocket; I met Ann Carey in Camden-town, at one o'clock on Sunday morning. the 3d of August, and went with her to a room in a house at Battle-bridge
- I went to bed with her, having put my clothes on something that felt like a chair, but I went to bed in the dark; I did not awake till the morning, and then missed my property, and accused her of being an accessory - I had heard a great noise in the night, which she attributed to rats; I said, "They must be very large ones indeed" - when I accused her of the robbery, she said she knew nothing about it, nor who had taken them, but she admitted they were gone; I saw the watch, seals, and snuff-box at Hatton-garden on the 9th, but I have not got the trousers and money.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were you tipsy? A. I was sober enough to know what I was doing - I was as conscious of it as I am now; she took me to Providence-row - I have heard she was married.

Q. Do not you know that the rat was her husband who came and took your trousers to punish you? A. My opinion is, that he was in the room under the bed at the time - Ann Carey went to the pawnbroker's to get me a pair of breeches to put on; the pawnbroker lent them to me, as I had no money.

FRANCIS CURTIS
. I am a labourer. On Monday morning, the 4th of August, about nine o'clock I was at breakfast, the male prisoner came and asked if I would take a walk; I said I was going to work - he urged me to take a walk, and I did; and while I was changing my trousers, he came up stairs, pulled out a watch, and asked the value of it - I said I was no judge, but would go and inquire; I went to Mr. Pickett's, who said it was worth three guineas and a half - he then asked me to go and pawn it, which I did for 2l., and gave him the money; he then pulled out the snuff-box, and asked me to pawn that, but I would not, and he pawned it himself.

WILLIAM PACKER
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker. On the 4th of August Curtis pawned the watch.

JOHN HARRIS
. I am assistant to a pawnbroker, and have a silver snuff-box pawned on the 4th of August, by William Carey.

JOHN LIMBRICK
. I am an officer. I have a sovereign, a half-sovereign, three half-crowns, a shilling, a sixpence, and some halfpence which I found on the female prisoner on the 4th of August; the prosecutor gave me information, and I took both the prisoners at the Bell public-house - the pawnbroker described the money as what he had given.

DANIEL DUTCH
. I am an officer of Mary-le-bone. Itook up Curtis on the 7th of August; I have a duplicate which I got from a man named Gorgat.

WILLIAM RAVEN
. I assisted in apprehending the prisoners.
FRANCIS CURTIS re-examined. Carey had a pair of black trousers on, which he went and changed at a Jew's shop for a pair of corded ones; I stood outside while he went in.

WILLIAM CAREY's Defence. I was out about nine o'clock that night, and I met a friend, who detained me till about four o'clock the next morning; I got home about six o'clock, went up stairs, and saw this dress thrown on a chair - I took down the trousers, and found some things in them; I took them on purpose to bring this thing to a discovery.

WILLIAM CAREY -
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Transported for Seven Years .

ANN CAREY -
NOT GUILTY .

1927.
EDWARD BROOKS
and
ELIZABETH SMITH
were indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of July , 1 bed, value 5s.; 2 sheets, value 2s.; 2 blankets, value 2s.; 1 coverlid, value 3d.; 1 bedstead, value 2s.; 1 broom, value 1s.; 1 pail, value 6d.; 1 water-butt, value 1s.; and 1 stove, value 2s. , the goods of
Sarah Thomas
.

SARAH THOMAS. I am a widow and I live in Whitecross-street
. The prisoner Smith took a room of me for herself, her husband, and child; when they had been there a week I found she did not live with her husband - she staid there about three weeks; I did not live in the house - I received information, went to the house, and found Smith was not there; I found a key to fit the door, I got in, and missed these articles - I once saw Brooks there, but not when the things were taken.

MARY FLOWERS
. I am a widow. I live in the house with the prosecutrix; I saw Brooks in a shed with the water-butt in his hand; I do not know when it was.

ELIZABETH WEAVER
. I am a widow. On the 17th of July, Smith came to me and said she was going into the country for ten weeks, and asked me to take care of a bed, a bolster, some chairs, and a little crockery, and she would give me 4d. a week - Brooks soon after brought a bed; I said, "You are not the person I agreed to take it of, without her I will have nothing to do with it;" she came directly after, and said it was all right - I took it in, but had nothing more.

THOMAS ELMER
. I am a broker. I bought a bedstead and stove of Brooks; he said he was going to harness-work, and wanted to sell them - I gave him 5s. and a pint of porter for them.

THOMAS HARRISON
. I am a constable. I found the prisoners at a house in Crown-court, Golden-lane, both intoxicated.

JOHN TOWNLEY
. I am a watchman. I assisted in taking Smith to the watch-house; on the road she said money would be no object, and I think mentioned a sovereign.(Property produced and sworn to.)
BROOKS' Defence. I never knew but they were Smith's things - I carried them for her, as she said she wanted money.
ELIZABETH SMITH's Defence. The man did not know but they were my own - I was in great distress.

SMITH -
GUILTY . Aged 43.
Confined Two Months .

BROOKS -
NOT GUILTY .

1928.
FRANCES ELLIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August , 1 bolster, value 6s.; 1 pillow, value 3s.; 1 blanket, value 2s.; 1 quilt, value 1s. 6d.; and 2 sheets, value 2s. , the goods of
James Bye
.

ANN BYE
. I am the wife of James Bye, and live in Hamilton-row, Clerkenwell
. On the 20th of May the prisoner came to lodge with me, and staid till the 20th of August, when I suspected all was not right; I got a constable, and missed these things, which were let with the room.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did not her husband have them? A. Yes; she told me she pawned the things herself - not that her husband watched at the door.

JOHN BUTTON
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a blanket, one sheet, and a pillow, pawned by a female - I do not know who.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you look outside the door? A. No.

JOHN ABETHELL
. I am a pawnbroker, and have a bolster, sheet, and quilt pawned by the prisoner.

SAMUEL MOUNTSTEVENS
. I am an officer, and took the prisoner - she told me the things were pawned, and the duplicates were at her daughter's house - a little boy came in, and she sent him for them, and he brought them; her husband was present, and said they were pawned with his knowledge, and he said so at the office, but was discharged.
GUILTY . Aged 48.
Confined Six Weeks .

1929.
THOMAS BULGER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of August , 19 shillings, and 15d. in copper monies , the monies of
Richard Tomlinson
.

RICHARD TOMLINSON. I am a simpler for the chemists . On the 17th of August, between two and three o'clock in the afternoon, I went to a public-house, and had a pot of beer: I fell asleep, and had 19s. in silver, and about 2s. 6d. in copper, in my pocket - I had seen the prisoner before I went to sleep, and when I awoke my silver was gone from my left hand trousers pocket, and my copper from the right; the prisoner had left the place; he came to the same house in about a week, and instead of asking my pardon, he was rather saucy, and I had him taken.

JOHN DICKS
. I am a coal-porter. On the 17th of August I was in the Blue Boar public-house, Cock-lane
; the prisoner went and sat by the side of Tomlinson, and soon after I saw his hand in his pocket; I said I would not see such a thing done where I was - he jumped up, and challenged me to fight; after some time he came and sat down, and took up a bag which fell out of the prosecutor's hat, which was on the table; I got up, and went to another part of the room; when the prosecutor awoke he was gone.

JOHN SHEPHERD
. I saw the prisoner take a simple bag out of the prosecutor's hat; Dicks said, "What business have you with it?" he said, "I will let you see."

CHARLES STEED
. I am a watchman. On the 27th ofAugust, I was passing the Blue Boar, and the prosecutor said, "Here is a man who has robbed me ten days ago:" the prisoner came out, and went down a court; the prosecutor said he was the man - I took him, and found nothing on him.
Prisoner. I never moved from the post. Witness. Yes; he tried to escape.

Prisoner's Defence. I went there to have a pot of beer; I went out, and came in again.
NOT GUILTY .

1930.
RICHARD BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , 3 carpets, value 10l.; 2 hearth-rugs, value 1l., and 1 druggett, value 3s. , the goods of
Richard Bartram
.

RICHARD BARTRAM. I live in Union-place, Battlebridge
, and am a carpet-beater . On the 31st of July I locked up my place, and left these three carpets and other things safe; between four and five o'clock next morning, I found the place broken open, and the things gone.

ANDREW MITCHELL
. I open Copenhagen-gate. On the 1st of August I went out mushrooming, at a quarter-past three o'clock in the morning; at the bottom of the first field from Maiden-lane I heard three voices; I went down to the side of a bank - three men came up; I heard one say,"Here is a good place to hide them:" they hid one there. then went and hid the others about fifty yards off - I went and told the watchman; I do not know the men.

RICHARD DEACON
. I superintend the watch. Mitchell came to me; I went with him, and found a large carpet under a elm tree, with some shrubs over it, and about fifty yards further found these hearth-rugs concealed; I left a man there to watch them, as I was called away - he left them, and they were taken away.

WILLIAM BALDWIN
. I am a watchman. On Friday morning, about eleven o'clock, I saw the prisoner with a bag on his shoulder, and took him; I found two hearthrugs in the bag - I asked where he got them; he said,"Find it out."

ROBERT TEASDALE
. I took him into custody - he told me he had found them.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was going over Kentish-townbridge; a young man employed me to carry the bag to the turnpike-house - he said he would overtake me, but he did not.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1931.
GEORGE ROBERTS
,
JOHN WARREN
,
BENJAMIN BATEMAN
, and
ROBERT BROWN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , 12 tame pigeons, price 35s. , the property of
Robert King
.

ROBERT KING. I am a bookbinder , and live in Collegeplace, Highbury-vale
. On the morning of the 7th of August I found my stable broken open, and twelve pigeons gone; I found seven of them, which I know - the prisoners are strangers.

BENJAMIN STEVENS
. I am a watchman. I stopped the prisoners in Holloway, about half-past one o'clock in the morning - one had a bundle, the other a bag, and Warren and Roberts had pigeons about them; I took them all to the watch-house - they said they had found the pigeons by a corn-field, about one o'clock in the morning.

Cross-examined. Q. How many had Warren? A. I cannot say - he had some, and let them fly before I got up to him; they were all together - the pigeons flew up from both of them; there were also six pigeons in the bundle, and six in the bag - they all had some.
COURT. Q. Did you show them to Mr. King? A. Yes.

ROBERT KING
. I saw them; seven of them were mine.
ROBERT'S Defence. We were mushrooming, and met the other two lads; we saw these pigeons by the side of a bank - there was nobody to own them; we took them, and the watchman stopped us.
One witness gave Warren a good character.

ROBERTS -
GUILTY . Aged 15.

BATEMAN -
GUILTY . Aged 13.

BROWN -
GUILTY . Aged 14.

Confined Fourteen Days and
Whipped .

WARREN -
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Whipped and Discharged.

1932.
JOHN READ
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of September , 1 trowel, value 2s. , the goods of
George Walker
.

GEORGE WALKER. I am a plasterer . I lost my trowel from a house in Lower Grosvenor-street
, on the 9th of September, I had used it just before dinner and when I returned, it was gone from the mortar-board.

SAMUEL SHARP
. I was at a public-house about ten minutes to six o'clock on the 9th of September, and saw the prisoner on the top of the scaffold, folding something in his jacket - he came down the ladder; I took him and took the trowel from him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was in Grosvenor-street - the trowel lay on the pavement; I went up to give it to the man, but there was nobody there.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined One Month .

1933.
ANDREW READING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of July , 1 jacket, value 1s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 1s., and 1 pocket-book, value 6d. , the goods of
Mark Prime
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1934.
ANDREW READING
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of July , 2 pairs of trousers, value 2s., and 1 handkerchief, value 6d. , the goods of
Alfred Stibbins
.

ALFRED STIBBINS. I belong to the ship Amey ; on the 6th of July, she was at the North-quay, London-docks
. I missed two pairs of trousers and a handkerchief out of my chest; I saw my handkerchief on the prisoner's neck- when he was taken, he said it was his own; my chest was locked on Saturday night - I found it broken open on the Sunday morning.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me on board? A. No.

ARCHIBALD McDONALD
. The prisoner was in custody on another charge - the prosecutor came to the watch-house, and claimed the handkerchief on his neck.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Seven Years .

1935.
MARY STEWART
and
AMELIA PIDDINGTON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 17th ofAugust , 1 purse, value 2d.; 2 sovereigns, 19s., and three 5l. Bank notes, the property of
Richard Webb
, from his person .

RICHARD WEBB. I am a sailor and live at Blackwall. On the 17th of August, at night, I went to the Black Boy public-house with Stewart, between nine and ten o'clock- I went home with her and went to bed; I had two sovereigns, and 19s. in silver, in a purse, in my trousers pocket, and five 5l. notes in my fob; I did not take my trousers off at all, and am sure I had all safe when I went to bed - when I awoke, I got up and left Stewart in bed; I felt my pockets and found only two 5l. notes - the purse sovereigns, 19s. and three 5l. notes were gone; I asked her where it was - she said she had put it all into my pocket again; I had given her a sovereign the night before, and took out my purse to get it.

SARAH ANN SMITH
. I live in Black Boy-lane. I was at the Harrow public-house that night and saw the prosecutor and Stewart come in, both very much intoxicated - they went out together; Stewart returned with some papers in her hand which looked like Bank notes: a person asked her if they were songs - she said No, they would like to have such songs in their pockets; I afterwards heard somebody say they were 5l. notes - I did not see Piddington.

JAMES BEACHY
. I am a Thames-police surveyor. On the morning after the robbery, Webb came to me; I went to the Black Horse public-house, at Poplar - I heard some of the girls say "Here is Beachy coming;" I then heard a rush towards the back-door - I ran up then, and somebody passed me at the front; I went on to the back-door, and took Stewart there - I told her I wanted her for felony, and asked where the notes were which she had taken from the sailor; she said she had not got them, but would give me two sovereigns if I would go into the long-room and see blackguard Nance (meaning Piddington), who had got the money - I went with her to the long-room, but Piddington was not there: I then took Stewart, and she said she had taken three 5l. notes and two sovereigns from the prosecutor, but had left him two 5l. notes, and he ought to be satisfied with that, and she was sorry now that she did not take the whole - I asked her what she had done with the rest of the money: she said that I had got to find out - she said Webb had given her a sovereign, and showed me the bed they had been on; she said he had his jacket off, but not his trousers; that she took them for fear anybody else should, as there was another bed in the room.

JEREMIAH BULKLEY
. I am a constable. On the 18th of August, I was going up East Smithfield, and saw two sailors who had hold of Piddington; they said she had robbed a shipmate - I took her in charge, and found this purse in her bosom; I asked her where she got it - she said Stewart had given it to her, and four sovereigns; that she had returned two, given one to a coachman, and one is in it now.

RICHARD WEBB
. This purse is mine.
STEWART's Defence. The prosecutor was very tipsy.

STEWART -
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

PIDDINGTON -
NOT GUILTY .

1936.
JOSEPH SIBLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of July , 1 pair of shoes, value 3s. , the goods of
James Wilson
.

JAMES WILSON. I go to a charity school, and live with my parents. I lost a pair of shoes, on the 17th of July, from behind a row of houses in Church-street
; I gave them to John Fox, a little boy, to take care of for me - I did not see who took them, and have not got them again.

Q. You have been examined before, and if you do not speak the truth it will be worse for you - you were behind some houses, where were they? A. Near New-cut-street, Lisson-grove; Wear was there - I gave my shoes to Fox to hold.

WILLIAM WEAR
. I saw Wilson by Lisson-grove, and saw him give his shoes to Fox; I saw the prisoner go up to Fox, snatch the shoes out of his hand, put them under his coat, and run away - I told Wilson of it.
Q. Why did you not run after him? A. The other boys said they would jump on me if I did: Fox is about seven years old.

PHILIP WEBSTER
. I took the prisoner into custody.
Prisoner's Defence. Wilson was fighting with another boy and Ware, and presently he lost his shoes; I went to get my father's sapper and was taken.
NOT GUILTY .

1937.
EDWARD JONES
and
SARAH JONES
were indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of July , 2 sheets, value 2s., 2 table-cloths, value 9s., and a shift, value 2s. , the goods of
William Laurence
.

MARY LAURENCE
. I am the wife of William Laurence. The prisoners lodged with us, at Hampton-wick
, from the 15th to the 25th of July; the woman came as a traveller - I missed a table-cloth and a shift on the 22d; on the 24th I missed a blanket and gave them in charge - I do not think the man knew anything about it.

WILLIAM HARRISON
. I am a pawnbroker. I have two sheets, one table-cloth, and a shift, pawned by Sarah Jones, on the 19th of July, and another table-cloth on the 22d.(Property produced and sworn to.)

SARAH JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 38,
Confined Three Months .

EDWARD JONES -
NOT GUILTY .

1883.
EDWARD HILL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of September , 1 hat, value 8s. , the goods of
William Simmons
.

WILLIAM SIMMONS. I am a servant . On the 7th of of September I was in St. James-street
. near the door of No. 50; my hat had been in the inner hall; I saw the prisoner come with it down the steps; he ran up the street; I pursued and took him with it in his hand - he said "Is this it."

JAMES ADAMS
. I am an officer - I took the prisoner and bring the hat.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. A person ran by me and dropped the hat, and when the prosecutor came up to me I told him so; on the way to the watch-house; he said, "I think I have made a mistake, and I wish to let him go," but I said"I will not be let go, I am given in charge, and let the officer do his duty." At the watch-house he had his doubts, but he was persuaded to press the charge.

WILLIAM SIMMONS. He never told me that a person had dropped the hat; I never expressed any doubt about his person and - I it would cause me a good deal of trouble had I not better let him go; but the watchman said"You have given him in charge and he must go:" he said he did not wish to be let go; he had a companion with him.

JAMES ADAMS
. I did not hear the prosecutor express a wish to let him go; he said it would cost him a great deal of trouble, might he not as well let him go; he never expressed any doubt about his person.
GUILTY Aged 28.
Transported for Seven Years .

1939.
JOHN DOWNES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of July , 4 books, value 8s. , the goods of
Cephas Cox
.

CEPHAS COX. I am a bookseller and live in Gray'sinn-road
. I lost four books from a box at the side of my door about two o'clock in the afternoon on the 24th of July; I saw the prisoner take them and run away; I went after him and saw him stopped by another person.

JAMES GOLDSMITH
. I heard a cry, Stop thief! I looked out and saw the prisoner; he threw down these books at the corner of a street; a man took them up and gave them to me; I looked at them till the prisoner was brought back, and then I gave them up.(Property produced and sworn to.)

SAMUEL MOUNTSTEPHENS
. I am an officer. The prisoner was given to me; I took him to the office; he said it was the first time he had ever been guilty of such an act, and he hoped the prosecutor would forgive him.

Prisoner's Defence. Another young man and I were walking down Gray's Inn-lane, and he wanted to go home to dinner; I said if he would stop I would pay for his dinner; he ran away and I after him; I suppose some other person took the books.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined One Months .

1940.
HENRY BURTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of September , 2 caps, value 12s., and 1 pricker, value 8d. , the goods of
Francis Edmond
.

FRANCIS EDMOND. I am a ship-chandler and slopseller . I lost a pricker used for sail-making, on the 11th of September, from the counter in my shop, No. 141 High-street, Wapping
; I did not see it taken; the officer brought it in shortly after I missed it, with two caps.

THOMAS CURRANT
. I am a Bow-street patrol. On the 11th of September I stopped the prisoner in Petticoat-lane offering these two caps for sale to a Jew; I asked whose they were; he said they belonged to his father; I went to the prisoner's father who said he did not deal in caps; when I came out the prisoner said he should give me no more trouble; that they had gone to the prosecutor's to buy a needle, and the other one took the caps and pricker.
Prisoner's Defence. I went with the other boy to buy a needle; he took the caps and pricker and gave them to me to sell.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 17.

Judgment Respited
.
NINTH DAY. SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 20.
Fourth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1941.
JOSEPH GUEST
was indicted for
feloniously receiving 1 watch, value 20l.; 1 chain, value 2l., and 2 seals, value 2s., the goods of
James Roche
, well knowing the same to have been feloniously stolen .
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1942.
WILLIAM LANE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of July , 4 lbs. weight of bacon, value 2s. , the goods of
William Softley
.

WILLIAM SOFTLEY. I am a cheesemonger , and live at Old Brentford
. On the 8th of July, between nine and ten o'clock in the morning, I was at the door putting some goods into the cart, and when I returned I missed a piece of bacon - I saw it again in ten minutes under the prisoner's coat; I knew him before, but he was not in my employ; he had not left the shop; I took it from him; when I first asked him, he said he had not got it - I asked him again, he denied it; I opened his coat and took it from there.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Did he not say anything about it? A. No; he said he wanted 1 oz. of tea, and he put down a shilling to pay for the tea - the bacon was not in his hand; his coat was buttoned, and his hand against it; he did not put the bacon on the counter and the money to pay for it - I did not put it under his coat again, and call my man to see where it was, and say,"Now you can swear you saw it under his coat;" my man came before the bacon was put down at all; I served him with the tea, and then charged him with the bacon - he did not say he had no notion of taking it without paying for it - but he said afterwards, he would do anything if I would forgive him, he did not offer to pay for it till I found it on him - he then said he did it for want.

HENRY LINKFORD
, I am in the prosecutor's employ. I saw the prisoner come into the shop as I was putting some bacon into the cart; I went into the shop just after he was served with the tea - my master said, "What have you got under your coat?" he said, Nothing; my master said, "You must have something, let me see what;" I forced his coat open, and there was this piece of bacon; my master told us to fetch a constable - he said he would do anything if he would forgive him.

JOSEPH DICKINSON
. I am an officer. I went to the shop, and saw the prisoner in the prosecutor's parlour - I knew him, and said, "I am very sorry to see you here Lane;" he denied his name several times, but I knew him very well; I said to the prosecutor, "What is your intention;" he said, "I give you charge of him, take him to a Magistrate;" the prisoner then went on his knees and begged for mercy, and said, "You don't know my circumstances;" I found near 16l. on him.

Prisoner's Defence. I saw a piece of bacon which I thought would suit my family; I took it up and put it under my arm; I then had some tea, and paid for it; the prosecutor said, "What have you got here?" I said, "A piece of bacon, which I intend to pay you for;" I put it on the counter and half a crown to pay for it - he then took it up, put it under my coat, and called the man, and said,"Now you can swear."

MR. HENRY HAINES. I am an auctioneer and appraiser,and live in Fore-street. I have known the prisoner more than twenty years - I have had several transactions with him to a considerable amount, and during that time he has always conducted himself in an honest and proper manner; he has seven children, and his wife is now pregnant.

MR. BODKIN to MR. SOFTLEY. Q. Did you say to Mr. Haines that it would be a great injury if you did not convict this man? A. No; I said it would be a great injury if I did not appear against him; he wrote to me, wanting me to make a flaw in the indictment.

COURT. Q. Did you say, that in consequence of some letter written by somebody? A. Yes, because they wanted me not to appear; Mr. Haines came to my place, and began a conversation on the subject of this prosecution - the letter came by post from the prisoner.
MR. BODKIN to MR. HAINES. Q. Do you remember going to the prosecutor's? A. Yes, and he said to me, that it would be a great injury, if he did not succeed in convicting the prisoner.

COURT. Q. Are you sure those were the words he used? A. Yes; I went to him and he said, it was his duty to prosecute, but in consequence of his family, I hoped he would be as lenient as he could; I was very cautious in my expression - this was about ten days ago.
GUILTY . Aged 41.
Confined Six Months .

1943.
MARY BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of July , 2 sheets, value 10s.; 1 pair of boots, value 2s.; the goods of
Richard Marks
- 1 pair of stockings, value 1s.; and 1 handkerchief, value 1s. ; the goods of
Elizabeth Moorm
.

RICHARD MARKS. I live in Old-street-road; the prisoner was my servant - I lost two sheets, and a pair of boots, on the 7th of July; my niece, Elizabeth Moorm, brought down the prisoner's bag to me, and I found a number of duplicates in it.

ELIZABETH MOORM. I lost a pair of stockings and a handkerchief, on the 7th of July; I found the stockings in the prisoner's box in her room, and my handkerchief under her bed - the duplicates were in a blue bag in her box.

JOHN BURGESS
. I am a pawnbroker; I have a sheet pawned on the 10th of June; a young man, who is not now in my service, took it in, and gave this duplicate.

LEONARD CLARE MATTHEWS
. I am a pawnbroker; I have a pair of boots pawned at my shop, but I did not take them in - this is the duplicate.

THOMAS WATERS
. I am an officer; I was sent for, and took the prisoner - I found in her box a sheet cut up in pieces, and these stockings; here is a mark on the sheet - I found those duplicates also.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined Six Months .

1944.
ROBERT DURANT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of July , 2 sovereigns, the monies of
Charles Hogg
, from his person .

JAMES TAYLOR
. I am a watchman. On the 9th of July. I was called at a quarter before ten o'clock to take the prisoner at a public-house in Ratcliff-highway; I asked if he had any silver, he said, Yes - I asked if he had any gold, he said, No; I took him to the watch-house, and found two sovereigns on him - a man named Hogg gave charge of him, but I do not know his Christian name; he said, he had lost two sovereigns, and he swore to the piece of paper they were in - he is not here.

GEORGE DEVERELI
. I am an officer. I took the sovereigns from the prisoner in the piece of paper - the prosecutor said he had been out all day, and the prisoner took them from him; the prisoner said they were his own, and he had received them from his master by the Dog and Duck.

Prisoner's Defence. I came from Sunderland with one sovereign and eight shillings in my pocket, which was to pay the ship; instead of which, I worked my passage; the prosecutor came to my house at Deptford, and asked me to go out drinking with him; we went to several public-houses and drank, and then came to Ratcliff-highway - we went to a public-house, and I went to sleep, and so did Hogg - I was taken sick, and went out and came in again, and laid my head down to go to sleep; when I awoke, my hat was gone, and a handkerchief in it - Hogg then awoke up, and said he had lost two sovereigns; I said, "Charles, I know nothing about it."
NOT GUILTY .

1945.
RICHARD DAVIES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of September , 3lbs. weight of cheese, value 1s. 6d.; 4lbs. weight of ham, value 2s.; 1 tub, value 6d.; and 4 cloths, value 1s.; the goods of
John Green Winter
and
Robert Winter
, to whom he was servant
.

JOHN GREEN WINTER. I am in partnership with my brother Robert: we are cheesemongers
- the prisoner was in our employ; on the 8th of September I sent him behind the counter while I wrote a letter - during that time the till was robbed; when the prisoner came the next day, I accused him of this felony - he was given in charge, and I went to his house, where I found a butter firkin, and four butter cloths, which are my property, and some flats which are not mine.

MARGARET HEWSON
. I am servant to Mr. Winter. On the 15th of August, I was coming down stairs - I looked into the warehouse, and saw the prisoner put some ham and a Dutch cheese in a flat; he brought down the flat, and put it into the cart, and took it to the stable - I came down and asked the prisoner if the meat was bad; he said, "What do you mean" - I said, "Never mind," and I stood there till he took it off

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Have you a fellow-servant named Betsey? A. Yes, she had a sweetheart, but he could not take the prisoner's place - he is not allowed to come to the house; I saw this on the 15th of August - I did not go and tell my master instantly; I did not mention it till the money was gone from the till - some weeks had passed - my master was at home at the time.

DANIEL DUTCH
. I am an officer. I went with Mr. Winter to the prisoner's lodging, on the 9th of September- I found this butter tub and four cloths; I found no ham or cheese.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you take the poor man into custody? A. No, he was at the watch-house; I did not hear his wife say she had taken away some dirty things in the tub.
MR. WINTER. Hewson told me about taking the ham and cheese on the 8th of September.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Can you swear to the tub? A. Yes, and to these cloths; one of these have a mark on - the prisoner is married; the witness did not say a word to me for some weeks - the prisoner never left my service.

Prisoner's Defence. I bought a lot of clothes of the shopman, and took them to the stable, the shopman went with me with some corn; on the Monday I told my wife there was a lot of things I had bought of the shopman - she came to fetch them, but she had no apron on; I said,"Here is a tub, you may take them in that."

JOHN GREEN WINTER re-examined. Q. Did the prisoner say this at the time? A. No; he was in custody; the tub was filled with cut up flats at the time I found it; he has been five or six months in my service as carman.
NOT GUILTY .

1946.
THOMAS GIGG
and
WILLIAM BALL
were indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August
, 1 bushel of oats, beans, and clover-chaff, value 2s. , the goods of
James Scott
and
William Scott
, their masters; and CHARLES PRATT
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, knowing it to have been stolen ; against the Statute.

PHILIP WEBSTER
. I am an officer. On the 29th of August, about three o'clock in the afternoon, I was in a field near the Red Lion public-house, at Westbourn-green
, lying down on the bank, looking through the hedge; I saw two of Mr. Scott's carts draw up - he is a brick-maker
the two carts were driven by Gigg and Ball; they stopped near the stable - they were both loaded with breeze, and upon each cart was a sack, with corn in it; Gigg took down his sack, and filled his horses' nose-bags about half full - Ball did the same out of his sack, but his sack was not so full as Gigg's; Gigg then rested his corn bag by the side of the wheel, and then they both went into the public-house - in four or five minutes I saw Pratt, the ostler, come and take the fullest sack, and carry it into the stable of the Red Lion; I jumped over the ditch, followed him into the stable, and said, "You brought this sack in, which belongs to Mr. Scott;" he said, "I brought it into take care of:" I said, "Yes, I am well aware of the manner you take care of it - it is not the first time." I asked to look at the corn in the bin, and told him I had seen the same thing done before, but he denied it; I went to the corn-binn - two men were sitting there; they got up, and the corn-bin was full of the same description of corn as this; I called my brother-officer to take charge of the sack and the prisoner Pratt - I went into the tap-room; Gigg and Ball were taking some refreshment. with two other men, who had come before; I said, "Who drove up the two last carts?" they said they did - I said, "The ostler is in custody, and I shall take you;" Gigg said he hoped I should overlook it this time, and it should never happen again; Ball said, "You never saw me." The sack was brought to the Police-office, and Mr. Dean saw it there.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were not these men acquitted on a charge yesterday? A. Pratt was not, but the others were.

DANIEL DUTCH
. I am a constable. I was with Webster at the Red Lion, on the Harrow-road; he called to me- I went in; he said, "Keep this man and the corn while I go and take the others;" I said to Pratt, "This has been the way for some time - how came you to take the corn?" he said, "Gigg desired me to take it."

GEORGE DEAN
. I am servant to James Scott and his son - they are in partnership; Gigg and Ball were in their service. I saw a sack with corn in it, which was in every respect like that belonging to Messrs. Scott's - there were oats, beans, clover and chaff in each; Gigg and Ball had their corn measured out to them every week, and they mix it themselves - it is not mixed in the bulk; each of them keeps his own corn, and each takes out corn to give his horses in the day: Gigg has been in the employ eight years, and had a good character.
PRATT'S Defence. I have lost several things, and I took it in to take care of.
NOT GUILTY .

1947.
WILLIAM BENSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , 1 time-piece, value 2l. , the goods of
Charles Mayo
.

CHARLES MAYO. I am a watch-maker , and live in Sidney-place, in the Commercial-road
. On the 7th of August, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening, I went out, and when I came back there was a mob of people round the door; this time-piece was produced, which I had seen that day.

WILLIAM THOMAS MOORE
. I am an officer. I was sent for, and found the prisoner in custody; I took this time-piece.

THOMAS PUGH
. I live next door to Mr. Mayo. On the evening of the 7th of August Mrs. Mayo came to me; I went into the street, and saw the prisoner running along with the time-piece; I went and took it from him - when he got to a corner he turned and walked deliberately down a street, with it under his left arm.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I throw myself on the mercy of the Court.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

1948.
JOHN CLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 1 coat, value 50s.; 1 waistcoat, value 10s., and 1 pair of trousers, value 20s. , the goods of
John Wilkins
.

JOHN WILKINS. I am a Venetian-blind maker , and live in Bell-street, Westminster. On the 9th of September, I lost a coat, waistcoat and trousers, from Hyde-place, Vauxhall-road
, from a drawer in the back parlour; I had seen them on the 7th - I did not miss them till the morning of the 9th, about seven o'clock; the prisoner slept with me on the Sunday night, but not on the Monday - the drawer was not locked; I have not seen any of them since.

HANNAH WRIGHT
. I am the wife of Thomas Wright. On Monday, the 8th of September, I saw the prisoner come to my house, where he had slept for a week with the prosecutor - he came that morning about half-past eight - he had a large bundle with him; I asked him for my rent - he said he had no money, but would come in the afternoon and pay it, but I never saw him again; he hadno property there, except a shirt - Wilkins missed the property the next morning.
Prisoner. Q. Why did not you ask what was in the bundle? A. Because I did not suspect you - I was in a hurry.

ELIZABETH SOUTHATE
. I saw the prisoner go to his lodging on the Sunday evening, a little before ten o'clock- he had a shirt and a red shawl on the top of it: the next morning, at half-past eight I was at breakfast. and my window was up - he came out of the house with a bundle under his left arm.

JAMES WALKER
. I am a Bow-street patrol. On Tuesday, the 9th of September, I went with Wilkins to take the prisoner, in Chapel-street - he denied all knowledge of the clothes; I found nothing on him but a key and 1s. 6d.

JOSEPH SUTTON
. My brother-in-law keeps the Crown and Sceptre public-house; I met the prisoner in the street, on the 9th of September - I said there was a charge against him - he said he was entirely innocent, and would go anywhere - he went to the Crown and Sceptre; I went for an officer, and when I returned, he was taken.

JOHN WILKINS
re-examined. Q. Do you know what clothes the prisoner had? A. No more than he stood up in and a shirt; there was no servant in the house - no one but him slept with me.

MRS. HANNAH WRIGHT re-examined. Q. Was there anybody there but the prisoner on Monday? A. No, there are other persons who live up stairs, but they never come into my place - they could have got in; the parlour door is sometimes open, but the street-door has always been shut.

Prisoner's Defence. On the Monday morning, I got up at half-past eight o'clock, and when I came out of my room I brought away my dirty things; I had put my clean ones on - I had a black waistcoat, one pair of Angola stockings and one pair of clean white ones, and two handkerchiefs; they were tied up in a loose red shawl; my landlady had pressed me for the rent; I did not return; when this man came up to me, I said I would go anywhere, and I went to the Crown and Sceptre, and staid there an hour and a half; I then came out, and met the constable.
NOT GUILTY .

1949.
ANN ELY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of August , 1 gown, value 7s.; 1 shirt, value 6s.; 1 waistcoat, value 2s.; 1 petticoat, value 3s.; 1 shift, value 1s.; 1 cap, value 5s.; 1 towel, value 1d., and 1 pair of stockings, value 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Vickers
.

JANE VICKERS
. I am the wife of Thomas Vickers, and live at Poplar, On the 9th of August, I gave the prisoner the articles stated in the indictment, to wash; she was to return them at six o'clock in the afternoon, but she did not- she lived in Green Arbour-court: I have never seen any of them since - in the afternoon I went to her place, and she was not there; I went again next morning, but she was not there - I met her about three weeks afterwards in Cloth fair; I called her by name - she pretended she did not hear me; I followed her till I came in front of her, and then asked her how she was, and where she lived; she said at Hoxton - I said "You might as well come and see me;" she said she did not like on account of the things - I said "Never mind the things at all; you may as well come and see me" - she said she did not like to come on account of the people in the next room; I said they had nothing to do with me, for I had had words with them - after a good deal of persuasion, I got her to come; when my husband came home, I gave charge of her - she said at first she had pawned the flannel petticoat, and then she denied it - when the officer came, she said she had had a little drink and lost the things.

ISAAC NEWTON
. I am a street-keeper. I was sent for and found the prisoner there; I asked her if she had pawned the things; she said No, they were stolen from her, either in going home or bringing them home - I forget which: I searched her and found nothing - I again asked her if she had pawned them, and said it would be better to give up the duplicates; she said No, they were stolen.
COURT to JANE VICKERS. Q. Did she say in the officers presence that she had pawned the petticoat? A. Yes.
Prisoner. I did not say so.
GUILTY . Aged 46.
Confined One Year .

1950.
CHARLES FERGUSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of September , 2 pairs of boots, value 1l. 16s. , the goods of
John Huttley
.

JOHN HUTTLEY. I am a boot and shoemaker , and live in Middle-row, Broad-street, St. Gile's
. I did not miss these boots till the officer brought them - I looked into my place, and when I came to make a calculation, I found there were more than these gone.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You cannot say that you have seen the prisoner? A. No - I have between four and five hundred pairs; I am confident these had not been sold - my shopman, who sometimes sells in my absence, might have sold them; I can only answer for myself - when we sell boots and shoes, we enter in the book the price they sell for; every boot in the house is numbered, but we do not enter the numbers, only the price: we cannot tell the numbers of the boots we sell.

JAMES LEDGER
. I am an officer. I produce two pairs of boots which I found on the prisoner, in King-street, Seven-dials, about two hundred yards from the prosecutor's place, at a quarter past nine o'clock, that night - he was carrying them in a bag, and I asked him what was in it: he said "Two pairs of boot;" I asked him what kind of boots - he said "One pair of top, and one pair of Wellington" - I asked where he got them from - he said they were his own making, but declined to give me any more answers.(Property produced and sworn to.)

WILLIAM BEE
. I am shopman to the prosecutors. I did not sell either of these pair of boots to the prisoner; I have a slight recollection of him - he might have been in our shop to have bought things - I cannot tell when I last saw these boots in the shop; I do not know whether he has been in the shop for the last six weeks.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you been shopman? A. About twelve months. I will not swear I might not have sold them to the prisoner; I know this pair of boots to have been my masters, because his markis in them - they are our own manufacture, and we know the man's work; I might have sold them to the prisoner; or he might have bought them from anybody who might have bought them of us.

SAMUEL HUTTLEY
. I am the prosecutor's son. I assist in the shop, and know these boots have not been sold- on the Saturday week before they were missed, I can positively state that these top-boots were in the shop - I noticed them that day; we sold a great many in the course of that week.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought them in Houndsditch.
NOT GUILTY .

1581.
MARY ANN HARRISON
and
MATILDA HARRISON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , 2 pillows, value 5s., and 2 pillow-cases, value 6d. , the goods of
John Sirkett
.

JOHN SIRKETT. I live in Union-street, Somers-town
, and am a coal-dealer . I let these two pillows and pillow-cases as part of the furniture of a room to the two prisoners, about the 28th of August; they were taken about the 8th of September - they did not leave the lodging, but they did not pay their rent; I took an officer, and missed these goods.

FRANCIS PARKER
. I am a pawnbroker. I have two pillows, and two pillow-cases, pawned by the two prisoners together; one on the 5th of September, the other on the 28th of August - the prisoners both came each time.

JOSEPH CADBY
. I am an officer. I took the prisoners in charge, and found these two duplicates on Matilda.(Property produced and sworn to.)
MATILDA HARRISON's Defence. We did it through distress; we took home some work, but did not get paid for it: we wanted the prosecutor to wait half an hour, but he would not.

MARY ANN HARRISON -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

MATILDA HARRISON -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Confined One Month .

1952.
ANN LESTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of July , 1 frock, value 3s., and 1 handkerchief, value 6d. , the goods of
John Brickhell
.

ROBERT YOUNG
. I am in the service of Mr. John Brickhell. On the 17th of July I was informed that a person had come into a box in his shop; I went round and found the prisoner there - I asked what she had in her apron - she said nothing but what belonged to her - I looked into her apron and found this frock and handkerchief belonging to us - they were both marked; she said she bought them in the market; I had seen them that morning before.

THOMAS FRAMPTON
. I am an officer; I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that she had purchased the articles of a Jew, in Tottenham-court-road.
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1953.
THOMAS PERKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of July , 2 pairs of upper leathers, value 1s. 6d. the goods of
John Lawrence
.

JOHN LAWRENCE. I am a shoe-maker , and live in Widegate-alley, Bishopsgate-street. On the 26th of July I went to Lambeth-street Office, and found those two pairs of upper-leathers which I had given to Ann Cole to bind, on the 22d of July; I know nothing of the prisoner.

ANN COLE
. I received this pair of upper leathers from Mr. Lawrence on the 22d of July; on the 23d the prisoner came and asked me for all the upper leathers I had done; I gave him three pairs, and this is one of them.

GEORGE BURRELL
. On the 25th of July the prisoner brought these upper leathers to me to sell - I asked him what he wanted for them; he said 2s.; I said that was more than they were worth - he said they were his father's; he gave me his name and address - I bought them of him for 1s. 9d.; in the course of the day I went to look for his father, and could not find him by the direction which he had given me - on the following Saturday I was going to the leather-cutter's, I met the prisoner, and gave him in charge.

THOMAS SIMSON
. I am headborough. I was sent for, and took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1954.
CATHERINE ROGERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of July , 1 jacket, value 3s. , the goods of
John Cross
.

RICHARD EDWARD BARBER
. I am in the service of Mr. John Cross, pawnbroker , of Clerkenwell
. On the 15th of July - the prisoner came to our shop between four and five o'clock - she pawned an article, and then went away; a person then told me something - I went into the street, and saw the prisoner walking from the house; I asked her what she took from our shop - she said nothing at all; I lifted up her cloak, and found this jacket, which is Mr. Cross' - I had hung it up in the morning.

JOHN BOWYER
. I took her up.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I throw myself on your mercy.
GUILTY . Aged 62.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1955.
HENRY HARRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 1 table, value 5s., and 1 counter, value 3s. , the goods of
Edward M'Lean
.
The prosecutor did not appear .
NOT GUILTY.
